END OF SECTION Implementation Temporary Environmental Controls Page of January SECTION TEMPORARY ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A .
Temporary environmental controls to control erosion and prevent sediment laden runoff from leaving the construction site and areas under the Contractors control. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Geotextiles .
REFERENCES A. AASHTO M Geotextile Specifications for Highway Applications B. AASHTO Construction Stormwater Field Guide C. ASTM D Deterioration of Geotextiles by Exposure to Light Moisture and Heat in a Xenon Arc Type Apparatus D. ASTM D Water Permeability of Geotextiles by Permittivity E. ASTM D Determining Apparent Opening Size of a Geotextile F. Utah Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Utah Construction General Permit UCGP .
DEFINITIONS A .
Check Dam A fiber roll or stone structure placed across a roadside ditch to temporarily protect ditch from channel erosion by slowing velocity of stormwater runoff and intercepting and trapping sediment .
B .
Disturbed Area Areas within a construction site where existing vegetative cover or existing stabilized areas have been removed or altered and exposed soils are susceptible to increased erosion and sedimentation .
Implementation Temporary Environmental Controls Page of January C. DropInlet Barrier A barrier placed around a storm drain inlet grate situated outside of roadway pavement condition that is designed to intercept and trap sedimentladen runoff before entering the storm drain system .
D. Fiber Roll Wood excelsior rice or wheat straw or coconut fibers rolled or bound netting to form a tubelike structure used to intercept and trap sediment .
E. Final Stabilization Procedures and controls completed as the final measure to protect disturbed areas of a construction site from erosion and sedimentation until vegetation regrowth occurs to provide ultimate erosion protection. . Includes work within areas to be vegetated such as establishing final grades placing topsoil incorporating seed roughening slopes by walking trackmounted equipment up and down slopes applying mulch erosion control blanket flexible channel liner and installing other landscape treatments to protect exposed soils from erosion. . Includes work within areas intended to remain unvegetated such as placing final pavement installing stone gravel and other stable material that will prevent erosion of underlying soil .
F. GutterInlet Barrier A device designed and prefabricated to secure to the top envelop or hang below a storm drain inlet grate situated within roadway pavement condition that keeps sediment and debris from entering the storm drain system .
G. PipeInlet Barrier A barrier placed at a pipe inlet that intercepts and traps sediment before entering the pipe .
H. Sediment Trap A small temporary excavated basin installed at low points on a construction site designed to trap sedimentladen runoff to allow sediment to settle out before leaving site .
I. Silt Fence A geotextile fabric fence used to intercept and trap sediment in a sheet flow situation along the perimeter of a disturbed area .
J. Slope Drain A polyethylene pipe temporarily placed on a slope to collect and transport storm runoff down the face of a slope until permanent drainage facilities are installed or vegetation growth is adequate .
K. Stabilized Construction Entrance A layer of stone underlined with a geotextile fabric placed at a construction site entrance or exit used to reduce the amount of sediment or mud tracked onto adjacent paved roadways by vehicles leaving the construction site .
Implementation Temporary Environmental Controls Page of January L. StrawBale Barrier Temporary barrier installed by placing straw bales end to end along perimeter of a disturbed area designed to intercept and slow sediment laden runoff before it leaves a construction site .
M. Temporary Berm A ridge of compacted soil with or without a shallow ditch that diverts stormwater runoff from a slope to a controlled release point .
N. Temporary Environmental Fence A highvisibility fence barrier used to delineate and prevent encroachment on sensitive areas. . SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers product data sheets and recommended installation instructions .
PART PRODUCTS .

Provide protection to entire inlet opening. . Types a .
Above Inlet Grate Mount securely to the top side of the inlet grate at each corner with cable ties wire or similar .
b. Inlet Cover Grate Sewn geotextile fabric that envelopes entire inlet grate .
Must have builtin lifting straps or other device to allow removal of inlet grate and barrier .
c. Below Inlet Grate Mount device securely to the inlet grate or have independent frame that allows geotextile bag to hang below grate to capture runoff .
Must be designed with a bypass feature that allows stormwater to be conveyed into the conveyance system when geotextile is filled to capacity .
Must be able to remove from storm drain inlet and maintain device without dumping captured sediment into the storm drain system .

PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION A .
Install appropriate controls as shown before beginning earth disturbing activities .
Implementation Temporary Environmental Controls Page of January B .
Refer to installation procedures outlined in EN Series Standard Drawings and the AASHTO Construction Stormwater Field Guide .
C. Install temporary environmental fence in the required locations before construction activities begin . .
Install posts at a ft maximum spacing so the fence does not sag more than inches between posts. . Weave the fence over the support posts alternating every two loops and secure it to the posts with fasteners .
D. Install GutterInlet Barrier according to manufacturers recommendations . .
INSPECTION A .
Check installed controls before and after each rain event to verify proper working function and compliance with the UCGP .
B .
Replace controls that are not properly working to prevent erosion and sedimentation . .
MAINTENANCE A .
Maintain controls to function properly until surrounding disturbed areas have met final stabilization measures .
B .
Remove accumulated sediments from controls when depth reaches percent of the control height or when it interferes with the performance of the control .
C. Properly dispose of accumulated sediment . .
REMOVAL A .
Remove temporary environmental controls when surrounding disturbed areas have met final stabilization measures except as follows .
Do not remove perimeter controls such as silt fence fiber rolls or straw bales when they protect a wetland or waterway unless the surrounding area meets final stabilization requirements identified within the UCGP .
When the Engineer determines that controls should remain in place .
B .
Remove temporary environmental fence and posts upon completion of construction .

DIRECTED SURVEY A .
Conduct directed surveying if directed by the Engineer. . Includes work needed for changes and extra work . .
Provide labor materials and equipment including total stations global positioning system GPS LiDAR scanning or other equipment. . COMPUTATIONS AND PLOTS A .
Use crosssections to calculate volume measurements. . Superimpose final cross sections with original cross sections and calculate final quantities using the average end area method . .
Develop crosssections from field measurements .
a .
Take cross section measurements both before and after excavation and before backfill .
b .
Take cross sections at a maximum centerline spacing of ft when the centerline curve radius is less than or equal to ft. c. Take cross sections at a maximum spacing of ft when the centerline curve radius is greater than ft. d. Take additional cross sections at breaks in terrain and at changes in typical sections .
e. Measure and record points at breaks in terrain for each cross section but at least every ft. f. Measure and record points to at least the anticipated slopes and reference locations .
g. Reduce cross section distances to horizontal distances from centerline .
h. Take cross sections at right angles to tangents and normal to curves .
i .
Include in cross sections grades locations and existing ground line profiles. . May develop volumes from digital terrain models if a .
Ground survey locations do not exceed ft in any direction .
b .
Major horizontal and vertical breaks in terrain are also included .
c. Horizontal and vertical control for the project is used .
d. DTM is verified accurate to required tolerances as indicated in the UDOT Survey Geomatics Standards manual by spot checking throughout the length of the project .
Refer to httpwww.udot.utah.govgostandardsreferences to view this manual .
Implementation Survey Page of January .

Follow the guidelines set in the UDOT Survey Geomatics Standards manual . .
Refer to httpwww.udot.utah.govgostandardsreferences to view this manual .
B .
Amend the survey control diagram as requested for the project. . Have the amended diagram sealed signed and dated by a Professional Land Surveyor in accordance with UC and Utah Administrative Code R. .
Refer to httpwww.udot.utah.govgostandardsreferences for Utah Code and Utah Administrative Code .
C. Relocate initial horizontal and vertical survey control points in conflict with construction to areas that will not be disturbed by construction operations. . Furnish to the Region Surveyor in coordination with the Engineer the coordinates and elevations for the relocated points before the initial points are disturbed .
D. Protect benchmarks from construction activities . .
Position benchmarks to allow a level rod to stand vertically and squarely on the mark .
E. Reference benchmarks to centerline and horizontal measurements . .
Compensate or correct for systematic errors including those associated with instrument calibration .
Select the appropriate equipment and methods and use trained personnel .
Implementation Survey Page of January .
Use appropriate error propagation and other measurement design theory to select the proper instruments field procedures geometric layouts and computational procedures to control random errors .
F. Apply appropriate procedures to verify that the allowable positional tolerance of such points is not exceeded if radial survey methods GPS or other acceptable technologies or procedures are used to locate or establish points on the survey .
G. The positional tolerance may be tested by .
Comparing the relative location of points in a survey as measured by an independent survey of equal or higher accuracy or .
The results of a minimally constrained correctly weighted least squares adjustment of the points on the survey .
H. Employ field procedures instrumentation and adequate survey personnel in order to achieve a precision of .
feet or mm ppm. . See Table for construction staking tolerances .

Staked positions are generally checked using electronic stakeout reports and if within tolerances the stated position is accepted .
Reference points may also have an accuracy relative to each other for precise measurements such as structures .
Implementation Survey Page of January .
Survey Staking Methods a. Furnish reference stakes for slope stakes and stakes used for setting items for work .
b. Furnish the following for projects using Conventional Survey Methods Establish and set slope stakes and references on both sides of centerline at cross section locations .
a Place slope stakes at a maximum centerline spacing of ft when the centerline curve radius is less than or equal to ft. b Place slope stakes at a maximum spacing of ft when the centerline curve radius is greater than ft. c Place reference stakes at a maximum centerline spacing of ft on tangents .
Establish slope stakes in the field as the actual point of intersections of the design slope with the natural ground line .
Set slope stake references outside the clearing limits .
Include reference point and slope stake information on the reference stakes. . Furnish the following for projects using Machine Control Guidance Methods a .
Establish and set location stakes and references on one side of centerline at cross section locations .
Place cross section stakes at a maximum spacing of ft. Crosssection stakes reference physical points in the proposed crosssection such as edge of pavement or top back of curb b .
Place slope stakes at a maximum spacing of ft. c. Establish slope stakes in the field at the actual point of intersections of the design slope with the natural ground line .
d. Set slope stake references outside the clearing limits .
e. Include reference point information on the reference stakes .
f. Provide adequate bench marks throughout the project for construction equipment equipped with MCG to check setup and tolerances .
Perform equipment checks at least once per day .
Record equipment checks in a log for verification by the Engineer. . Staking limits ReferenceLocation stakes can serve the purpose of the following staking requirements as long as required information for both purposes can be written on the stake .
a .
Stake clearing limits on both sides of centerline at each established station .
Implementation Survey Page of January Locate the clearing limit on the ground as shown by the cut and fill limits on the plans .
b .
Stake right of way limits or temporary construction easement TCE if one exists every ft maximum on tangents every ft maximum on curves where ROW is not delineated by existing fence lines or other obvious boundaries .
Stake Right of Way limits at right of way breakangle points along the right of way lines .
Reduce the distance if staking distance is affected by line of sight .
c. Stake environmental control limits on both sides of centerline at each established station .
Locate the environmental control limits on the ground as shown by the slope rounding contours and environmental and silt fence locations as shown on the Plans .
Stake environmental control limits every ft in environmentally sensitive areas .
Provide staking as needed to guarantee the silt fence is located inside of right of way in standard silt fence installations where stationslocations are not called out on the environmental control plan sheets .

CLEANING PROCEDURES A .
Do not damage the final pavement surface .
B .
Only use equipment with rubber tread on the final pavement surface .
Implementation Final Cleanup Page of January C. Clean and finish areas within the clear zone as follows .
Remove protrusions or depressions greater than inches within the clear zone such as rocks boulders ridges and stumps . .
Remove trees and provide proper sight distance . .
Determine clear zone according to AASHTO Roadside Design Guide when not shown .
D. Clean drainage facilities of debris and obstructions caused by construction . .
Dispose of material removed .
E. Remove or cover with fine material from roadway excavation or borrow large rocks or boulders on fill slopes with the following exception .
Large rocks and boulders protruding from the final graded surface six inches or less on slopes steeper than or beyond the clear zone .
F. Do not undercut the slope on cut slopes . .
Remove all overhanging rocks . .
Solid ledge rock or partially buried boulders .
yd or more may be left in place on slopes steeper than beyond the clear zone. . G. Clean and finish areas within rightofway limits as follows .
Remove all dead trees and shrubs. . Prune trees and shrubs as required . .
Trim and shape trees to provide horizontal sight distance and ft vertical clearances above the roadway . .
Remove undesirable live trees shrubs and all fruit trees to a depth of inches below natural ground . .
Dispose of trash and debris .
H. Clean and finish areas within staging and office sites as follows .
Clean up and finish as specified for finishing local material source sites including seeding and mulching .

Section Flowable Fill .
REFERENCES A. AASHTO M Classification of Soils and SoilAggregate Mixtures for Highway Construction Purposes B. AASHTO T Materials Finer than m No .
Sieve in Mineral Aggregates by Washing C. AASHTO T Sieve Analysis of Fine and Coarse Aggregates D. AASHTO T MoistureDensity Relations of Soils Using a . kg .lb Rammer and a mm inch Drop E. AASHTO T MoistureDensity Relations of Soils Using a . kg lb Rammer and a mm inch Drop F. UDOT Materials Manual of Instruction G UDOT Minimum Sampling and Testing Requirements .
DEFINITIONS A. Wellgraded material Material having an even distribution of different particle sizes .
This even distribution of particles of different sizes results in a dense mass upon compaction. . SUBMITTALS A .
Provide the following before delivering material to the project .
Supplier and source of materials. . Gradation analysis .
Refer to AASHTO T and T . Implementation Embankment Borrow and Backfill Page of January .

Refer to AASHTO M. a. Wellgraded material .

Maximum aggregate size is  inches for plastic pipe inches for all other pipes. . Flowable fill .
Refer to Section .
a .
Use only for drainage pipe backfill .
B .
Other materials or trench configurations for drainage pipe bedding and backfill may be used only upon approval of the Contractors engineering proposal .
Proposals using this option may include the use of native material or uniformly graded materials enclosed in an appropriate drainage geotextile .
Any proposal must include all of the following .
Stamped drawings and specifications signed and sealed by a Professional Engineer licensed in the state of Utah . .
Evaluation of site specific conditions and surrounding soils including potential for migration of fines. . A structural evaluation of the pipe support system for the proposed pipe that includes the pipe structural capacity and the depth of fill . .
Complete bedding or backfill source information including gradation soil classification and laboratory testing reports .
Implementation Embankment Borrow and Backfill Page of January PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL A .
Complete clearing grubbing stripping and stockpiling topsoil before placing material .
B .
Requirements when placing material during freezing or snowy conditions .
Do not place embankment on frozen or snowcovered areas .
a .
Remove snow and frozen material from embankments foundations and borrow areas and furnish embankment material that can be compacted to the specified density. . Measure removed material and provide quantities to the Engineer . .
The Department does not pay for removed material frozen embankment replacement or replacement material for a working platform or foundation meeting specification requirements if unfrozen. . Do not deliver or use frozen material .
C. Use appropriate compaction equipment adjacent to pipes abutments back walls approach slabs wing walls retaining walls and other structures . .
Expand the width of the trench to accommodate necessary compaction equipment . .
Compact by hand areas where compaction equipment can not compact the soil .
D. Overexcavate unsuitable material as directed by the Engineer .
E. Do not use unsuitable material for embankment or backfill placement .
F. Density Requirements .
Borrow Granular Borrow Granular Backfill Borrow Embankment for Bridge and Drainage Pipe Bedding a .
Meet minimum density test average of percent of maximum laboratory density with no single determination lower than percent .
Use AASHTO T Method D for A soils and AASHTO T Method D for all other soils .
Maintain appropriate moisture for compaction during processing .
Implementation Embankment Borrow and Backfill Page of January .
Drainage Pipe Backfill a .
Meet minimum density test average of percent maximum laboratory density with no single determination less than percent .
Use AASHTO T Method D for A soils .
Maintain appropriate moisture for compaction during processing .
b .
Meet the pavement section material density requirement for pipes that encroach into the pavement section or use flowable fill. . Meet percent of the developed field density for material with more than percent retained on the  inch sieve .
a .
The Department develops a field density compaction curve according to UDOT Materials Manual of Instruction Section . . FreeDraining Granular Backfill a .
Meet percent of the developed field density .
The Department develops a field density compaction curve according to UDOT Materials Manual of Instruction Section . . EMBANKMENT AND BORROW PLACEMENT A .
Place roadway excavation or borrow or both in embankment section with the highest quality material in the top portion of the embankment .
B. Scarify and compact the top inches of the surface of the working platform or foundation to at least percent of maximum laboratory density when the embankment height is ft or less .
C. Break and scarify all underlying concrete pavement surfaces so that pieces do not exceed ft before placing embankment over an existing concrete pavement surface that is outside the limits of removal or excavation shown . .
Remove other pavement surfaces that are not Portland Cement Concrete .
D. Maintain Drainage .
Grade and maintain the roadway to ensure adequate drainage . .
Maintain drainage pipes and drainage ditches or provide temporary facilities when interrupting items such as irrigation systems sewers and underdrains .
Implementation Embankment Borrow and Backfill Page of January E. Place an initial layer to act as a working platform over soft wet ground when approved by the Engineer. . Density requirements do not apply to the working platform. . Meet density requirements for embankment placed above the working platform .
F. Do not place initial layer of embankment until Engineer inspects and accepts the working platform or foundation .
G. Spread embankment materials uniformly in layers not exceeding ft uncompacted depth and compact to the density requirements. . Reduce the lift thickness or modify operations if tests show unsatisfactory density .
H. Finish subgrade surface within .
ft of line and grade .
I .
Do not use rock or broken concrete materials over ft in any dimension .
J .
Distribute larger particles so space exists for placing and compacting embankment material .
K. Do not place rocks larger than inches or broken concrete within ft of the subgrade surface .
L. Do not use compacting equipment that causes shear failure in the embankment. . GRANULAR BORROW GRANULAR BACKFILL BORROW AND BACKFILL PLACEMENT A .
Finish surface within .
ft of line and grade .
B .
Compact material in maximum inch layers uncompacted depth to the density requirement .
C. Backfill for structures such as bridges foundations box culverts drains and other structures. . Place Embankment unless otherwise shown. . DRAINAGE PIPE FOUNDATION BEDDING AND BACKFILL PLACEMENT A .
Place in inch layers uncompacted depth and compact to the density requirement .
Implementation Embankment Borrow and Backfill Page of January B .
Place uniform layers of drainage pipe backfill on both sides of the pipe and compact to the density requirement before placing successive lifts .
C. Fully compact the haunch areas. . EMBANKMENT FOR BRIDGE PLACEMENT A. Construct bridge approach embankments from the existing ground up with the specified material to the limits defined in this Section and according to DD Series Standard Drawings . .
Approach Embankments a .
Place embankment beneath the bridge except riprap or other described materials used for MSE walls .
b .
Place embankment from the bridge abutment centerline station to a point measured at least ft away from the abutment along the approach roadway centerline and on the inside of abutments .
c. Use the described material throughout the length of the walls where retaining walls are located beyond this delineation. . Intersecting Roadway Embankments a .
Place embankment from approximate edge of approach roadway at least ft along intersecting roadway centerline. . Adjoining Embankments a .
Place embankment at least ft outward from edge of approach roadway pavement when adjoining embankment is not an approach embankment .
C. Do not place initial layer of embankment until foundation or working platform is verified by the Engineer .
D. Spread embankment materials uniformly in layers not exceeding ft uncompacted depth and compact to the specified density requirements before placing the next layer .
Reduce the lift thickness if tests show unsatisfactory density .
E. Finish surface within .
ft of line and grade. . FREEDRAINING GRANULAR BACKFILL PLACEMENT A .

ft of line and grade .

PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL A .
Place geotextile on areas that are smooth and free of projections or depressions. . Do not drag the geotextile across the subgrade . .
Roll geotextile out as smoothly as possible in the direction of vehicle travel .
B .
Do not operate construction equipment or traffic directly on geotextile .
C. Cover the geotextile with indicated cover material as soon as possible when placed for construction. . Do not leave uncovered for more than five days .
D. Place cover material on the geotextile in a manner that the geotextile is not torn punctured or shifted. . Use at least a inch thick cover layer or twice the maximum aggregate size whichever is thicker. . Do not enddump cover material directly on the geotextile except as a starter course .
Implementation Geotextiles Page of January E. Limit construction vehicles in size and mass so rutting in the initial layer above the geotextile is not more than inches deep or half the layer thickness whichever is less. . Do not turn vehicles on the first layer . .
INSTALL SILT FENCE GEOTEXTILE A .
Refer to Section . .
INSTALL EROSION CONTROL GEOTEXTILE A .
Install at locations shown .
B .
Overlap the geotextile at least ft at all longitudinal and transverse joints or sew the geotextile unless otherwise specified .
C. Place overlapped geotextile so that the upstream sheet overlaps the downstream sheets .
D. Overlap each sheet over the next downhill sheet for placement on slopes .
E. Anchor the geotextile using key trenches or aprons at the crests and toes of the slope .
F. Repair Place patch over damaged area and extend ft beyond the perimeter of the tear or damage . .
INSTALL DRAINAGE GEOTEXTILE A .
Install at locations shown .
B .
Place and secure geotextile to provide direct contact against the excavated surface .
C. Overlap successive sheets of geotextile at least ft in the downgradient direction of flow .
D. Overlap geotextile at least ft at the top of the trench where applicable .
E. Place fill beginning with the sheets overlapped above subsequent sheets to hold geotextile in place .
F. Repair Place patch over damaged area and extend ft beyond the perimeter of the tear or damage .
Implementation Geotextiles Page of January .

B .
Overlap the geotextile at least ft at all longitudinal and transverse joints or sew the geotextile unless otherwise specified .
C. Repair Place patch over damaged area and extend ft beyond the perimeter of the tear or damage .
D. Place fill beginning with the sheets overlapped above subsequent sheets to hold geotextile in place .
E. Use pins inches long to help secure the geotextile during installation . .

B .

C. Overlap each sheet over the next downhill sheet for placement on slopes .
D. Repair Place patch over damaged area and extend ft beyond the perimeter of the tear or damage .
E. Place fill to hold geotextile in place beginning with the sheets overlapped above subsequent sheets .
F. Use pins inches long to help secure the geotextile during installation . .
INSTALL WEED BARRIER GEOTEXTILE A .
Preparation .
Remove sharp objects large stones and undesirable vegetation. . Cut an X over each plant and push geotextile under plant base if placing geotextile over an existing bed . .
Roll geotextile over soil and cut an X for each plant hole if placing over a new bed . .
Fold excess geotextile under and cover with specified landscaping materials .
B .
Surface Cover .
Provide at least inches of cover on all areas on the geotextile .
Implementation Geotextiles Page of January .
Increase thickness of cover material over geotextile to three times the diameter of the largest rock material if using large landscape rock. . Do not leave any portion of geotextile exposed to direct sunlight .
C. Repair .
Repair immediately if damaged. . Place patch over damaged area and extend ft beyond the perimeter of the tear or damage .
D. Maintenance .
Maintain surfaces and supply additional landscape materials where necessary including areas affected by erosion. . SEW A .
Perform sewing as specified in AASHTO M Appendix Seaming .

Implementation Asphalt Paving Fabric Page of January PART PRODUCTS .
ASPHALT PAVING FABRIC A .
Use needlepunched nonwoven fabric constructed exclusively of manmade polymeric fibers resistant to rotting mildew insects chemicals and ultraviolet UV light . .
Refer to AASHTO M Paving Fabric Requirements .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Prepare Pavement Surface .
Remove all dirt water oil and foreign materials. . Clean out and fill cracks wider than  inch with sand and asphalt emulsion filler material .
B .
Apply tack coat to the prepared surface at a rate of .
to .
galyd as determined by the Engineer .
Refer to Section . . Additional tack coat is required on overlapped areas . .
The Engineer determines the tack coat rates according to manufacturer recommendations and the following performance requirements a .
Satisfy asphalt retention properties of fabric .
b .
Bond the fabric and overlay to the underlying surface .
c. Do not create a slippage potential for the overlay . .
Uniformly spread excess tack coat before it cools . .
INSTALL FABRIC A .
Place fabric over tack coat with a mechanical unit that produces a wrinkle free placement . .
Remove small wrinkles by hand brooming. . Cut the fabric overlapping in the direction of paving for wrinkles in excess of inch wide .
B .
Overlap transverse joints inches in the direction of paving and bond with additional tack coat .
C. Overlap longitudinal joints inches and bond with additional tack coat .

SECTION INCLUDES A .
Removal of existing asphalt surfacing from bridge decks and approach slabs. . RELATED SECTIONS Not Used .
REFERENCES Not Used .
DEFINITIONS Not Used .
SUBMITTALS Not Used PART PRODUCTS .
REMOVAL EQUIPMENT A .
Use equipment capable of removing the full depth of asphalt on the deck and the approach slabs without damaging the underlying concrete surfaces and bridge superstructure for fulldepth removal .
B .
Use equipment capable of removing a uniform thickness of asphalt from the deck and the approach slabs without damaging the underlying asphalt waterproofing membrane and concrete surfaces for partialdepth removal .
PART EXECUTION .
FULL DEPTH REMOVAL A. Verify total asphalt depth before removal at the locations shown . .
Notify Engineer of any discrepancies between depth measured and the depth shown .
B .
Remove asphalt as shown .
C. Remove existing waterproofing membrane from the deck and concrete approach slabs .
Implementation Asphalt Surfacing Removal Structures Page of January D. Notify Engineer of damage to the deck or approach slab surface that occurs during the removal .
E. Protect existing features to remain from damage . .
PARTIAL DEPTH REMOVAL A .
Refer to the plans for the asphalt surfacing removal depth .
B. Verify total asphalt depth before removal at the locations shown . .
Notify Engineer of any discrepancies between depth measured and depth shown .
C. Notify Engineer of damage to the existing waterproofing membrane on the deck and approach slabs that occurs during the removal .
D. Allow no traffic on the asphalt surface after partial depth asphalt removal .
Return traffic only after placing the final surfacing .
E. Protect existing features to remain from damage. . ASPHALT DISPOSAL A. Asphalt surfacing material removed becomes the property of the Contractor unless otherwise specified .
B .
Dispose of removed asphalt material .

DEFINITIONS A .
Clear Remove and dispose of trees stumps logs limbs sticks vegetation debris and other material on the natural ground surface .
B. Grub Remove and dispose of roots buried logs debris organic matter and other deleterious materials under the ground surface. . SUBMITTALS A .
Copies of disposal permits agreements or both. . PAYMENT PROCEDURES A .
Site Clearing and Grubbing when no bid item is included in the proposal .
This work is considered incidental to other items of work and no separate measurement or payment will be made . .
Include all costs in other items of work .

B .

B .
Stumps roots and nonperishable solid objects may remain in cleared areas where the embankment is .
ft or more above the natural ground. . At least ft away outside the slope stake lines .
C. Completely grub stumps and roots where a structure is to be constructed piles are to be driven or unsuitable material is to be removed. . BACKFILLING A. Backfill all stump holes cuts depressions and other holes resulting from clearing and grubbing within areas to receive embankment . .
Compact backfilled areas to the density of the surrounding ground .
B .
Measure and pay separately for materials used for backfilling under Roadway Excavation or Borrow .
C. Consider Roadway Excavation and Borrow as incidental to the work when these items are not included in the bid proposal. . No separate measurement or payment made in this case .

ACCEPTANCE AND PAYMENT PROCEDURES A .
Payment is plan quantity by the cubic yard. . Make no adjustment to plan quantities if staked quantities differ by percent or less .
B .
Notify the Engineer before beginning excavation in any area if the Contractor determines that the staked quantities differ from the plan quantities by more than percent .
The following procedures then apply .
Provide calculations and plots according to Section . .
Evaluate the plan quantities to staked quantities by individual cuts or balances as determined by the Engineer to provide the necessary accuracy. . Do not begin excavation of any cut sections that the Contractor determines to differ from plan quantities by more than percent until the calculations and plots have been submitted reviewed and approved by the Engineer .
a .
No payments partial or final will be made until submissions are provided and approved .
C. Approved quantities become the adjusted plan quantities and are paid at the original unit bid price when the Engineer determines the staked quantities differ from plan quantities by more than percent .
D. Payment includes excavation removal transportation and disposal when existing pavement is included in Roadway Excavation plan quantity .

EXCAVATION STANDARD PROCEDURES A .
Finish excavation to reasonably smooth and uniform surface .
B .
Provide and maintain satisfactory access to roads streets and adjacent property during all phases of construction according to the Traffic Control Plan .
C. Remove material in all cut sections to the depth shown. . Scarify to an inch depth and compact subgrade to at least percent of maximum laboratory density before placing pavement section .
D. Excavate and waste unsuitable material .
E. Material for backfilling or finishing .
Use suitable granular material encountered in excavation to construct the top layers of embankment finishing the roadbed or backfill when directed by the Engineer . .
Haul the granular material directly from excavation to the final position on the roadbed when practical. . ROCK REMOVAL NONEXPLOSIVE METHOD A. Excavate solid rock inches to ft below subgrade and backfill with acceptable material. . Rock removed more than ft below subgrade will not be measured or paid for. . Backfilling depth greater than ft below subgrade will not be measured or paid for. . ROCK REMOVAL EXPLOSIVE METHOD A .
Comply with OSHA Constructions Standards Subpart U Blasting and the Use of Explosives .
B .
Comply with NFPA Explosive Materials Code .
C. Provide a qualified explosives expert to act as an advisor and consultant during drilling and blasting operations .
D. Do not blast beyond designated areas .

Structural excavation includes .
Excavating foundations for structures. . Control and removal of water .
a. Dewater the excavation if ground water is encountered .
b .
Continue dewatering activities as necessary to prevent damage to the work . .
Installation and removal of facilities required to complete the work unless specified or allowed to remain in place .
B. Excavate rock and other hard strata to elevations and dimensions shown. . Clean and cut to a firm surface as shown .
a .
Foundation can not contain loose material. . Clean out seams and fill with concrete mortar or grout .
C. Do not overexcavate unless directed by the Engineer. . Overexcavate and waste material unsuitable for the structure foundation to at least ft below the design elevation .
Cost of overexcavation is paid as extra work when directed by the Engineer .
D. Clean the space under structures in channels and adjacent areas affected by operations to prevent drift and scour .
E. Dispose of all unused excavation material .

DEFINITIONS A. Gabion A doubletwisted wire mesh enclosure uniformly partitioned into internal cells interconnected with other similar units and filled with rock to form flexible permeable monolithic structures .
B. Revet mattress Similar to gabions but having a larger footprint and smaller height .
C. Rock diameter The equivalent diameter average width of a given rock .

END OF SECTION Implementation Rolled Erosion Control Products Page of January SECTION ROLLED EROSION CONTROL PRODUCTS PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A .
Rolled Erosion Control Products RECP installed on disturbed areas of a construction project including steep slopes and roadside ditches to prevent erosion and sedimentation and assist in establishment of vegetation growth. . RELATED SECTIONS Not Used .
REFERENCES A. ASTM D Deterioration of Geotextiles by Exposure to Light Moisture and Heat in a Xenon Arc Type Apparatus B. ASTM D Tensile Properties of Geotextiles by the WideWidth Strip Method C. ASTM D Determination of Rolled Erosion Control Product RECP Performance in Protecting Hillslopes from RainfallInduced Erosion D. ASTM D Determination of Rolled Erosion Control Product RECP Performance in Protecting Earthen Channels from StormwaterInduced Erosion E. ASTM D Measuring Nominal Thickness of Rolled Erosion Control Products F. ASTM D Ultimate Tensile Properties of Rolled Erosion Control Products G. ASTM D Determination of Unvegetated Rolled Erosion Control Product RECP Ability to Protect Sand from HydraulicallyInduced Shear Stresses under BenchScale Conditions Implementation Rolled Erosion Control Products Page of January .
DEFINITIONS A .
Erosion Control Blanket ECB Temporary RECP composed of processed natural or polymer fibers mechanically structurally or chemically bound between two natural fiber or synthetic nettings to form a continuous matrix used to provide erosion control and facilitate vegetation establishment along slopes .
B .
Flexible Channel Liner FCL Temporary RECP machineproduced mat consisting of elongated natural materials that are bound between two slow degrading natural fiber or synthetic nettings to form a continuous matrix used to reduce erosion and aid vegetation establishment within recently constructed channels ditches and swales .
C. Rolled Erosion Control Products RECP Prefabricated blankets or netting formed from both natural and synthetic materials designed to be installed to a disturbed area and with vegetative growth used to prevent or reduce erosion .
D. Turf Reinforcement Mat TRM Permanent RECP composed of non degradable synthetic fibers filaments nets wire mesh or other elements processed into a permanent threedimensional matrix designed to protect high flow channels ditches and very steep slopes. . SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers product data sheets and recommended installation instructions . .
DELIVERY STORAGE AND HANDLING A .
Deliver products in original ultra violet UV weatherresistant factory labeled packages showing the name of the manufacturer and product description . .
Protect from damage due to climatic conditions or construction operations .

PREPARATION A .
Complete all required grading topsoil placement and seeding in designated areas before installing RECP .
B .
Make soil surface stable firm free of rocks roots and other obstructions .
C. Apply the RECP within hours after seeding . .
INSTALLATION A .
Minimize disturbance of the prepared seedbed when installing the product .
B .
Install product according to manufacturers recommendations .
Implementation Rolled Erosion Control Products Page of January C. Unroll product parallel to the primary direction of flow and place it in direct contact with the soil. . Do not stretch the product or allow it to tent or bridge over surface inconsistencies during installation .
D. Install flexible channel liner or turf reinforcement mat within a channel ditch or swale to allow runoff to flow directly to the centerline of ditch not undermining or bypassing the lined ditch .
E. Place additional staples in areas such as swales base of humps against rock outcrops and as required achieving maximum contact between the product and the soil .

DEFINITIONS A. BOR Beginning of redrive conditions .
B .
Driving criteria Hammer energy setting minimum pile embedment minimum hammer stroke or energy and minimum blow counts .
C. Dynamic testing High strain dynamic testing of pile driving in accordance with ASTM D using PDA equipment and signal matching .
D. EOD End of driving conditions .
E. PDA Pile driving analysis .

B .

a .

E. Preliminary schedule for driving. . PRICE REDUCTIONS FOR NONCONFORMING WORK A .
Price Adjustment Reduction for Deficient Strength Concrete .
The Department may accept concrete in pipe piles that is below the specified strength according to Section . .
The quantity of the bid item for which the pay factor is applied consists of the price of the entire piles for which the deficient strength tests are below the specified strength .
B .

Demonstrate technical adequacy for piles driven out of plumb or plan location . .
The Department will a .
Reject piles driven outside the upper deviation limits shown in Table below .
No payment made for the rejected pile .
b .
Use the Contractors unit bid price and the pay factors schedule presented in Table to calculate the price reduction for compensation .

ACCEPTANCE A .
Do not move pile driving equipment away from the pile foundation area until the Engineer verifies conformance with specifications of the driven piles for the current foundation .
B .
Do not demobilize pile driving equipment from the site until the Engineer verifies conformance with specifications of all driven piles for the project .

CONCRETE A .
Class AAE concrete Refer to Section . . Air entrainment requirements are waived . .

REINFORCING STEEL A .
Meet AASHTO M Grade .
B .
Refer to Section for vertical and spiral reinforcing steel as shown. . PILE DRIVER A .
Use pile driving equipment that is capable of driving the piles to the required driving resistance without damaging the pile and without requiring an excessive number of blows to achieve the required tip elevation and capacity .
B .
Obtain authorization of pile driving equipment before mobilizing the pile driving equipment to the site .
C. Remove pile driver and related equipment found to be inadequate for the project pile driving conditions . .
Revise and resubmit the Pile and Driving Equipment Data form as necessary until an acceptable pile driver system is determined. . Mobilize the acceptable pile driver system .
D. Equip the pile driver according to manufacturers recommendations .
E. Leads .
Use with all hammer types . .
Hold in the required position with guys stiff braces or both . .
Hold the pile parallel to the leads . .
Accommodate the maximum length of the pile segment and extend leads to the lowest point that the hammer must reach. . Use fixed leads if necessary to maintain required driving tolerances as described in this Section article .
paragraph C. F. Drive Cap or Drive Head .
Fits the top of pile and provides full bearing. . Drive cap to have a machined surface to fully engage the end of the pipe for pipe piles .
Implementation Driven Piles Page of January G. Hammer .
Fully operable adjustable settings . .
Rated energy greater than or equal to the value shown . .
Replace the cushion when it loses percent or more of its original thickness .
a .
Inspect hammer cushion in the presence of the Engineer before beginning pile driving and after every hours of pile driving .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Excavate foundations before driving piles .
B. Dewater excavation to at least ft below bottom of foundation and maintain at all times during pile foundation operations .
C. Notify the Engineer of conflicts between the designated location of new piles and the locations of existing piles from previous construction existing utilities old foundations and other potential conflicts . .
The Engineer will revise new pile locations as required . .
DYNAMIC ANALYSIS OF PILE DRIVING A .
Notify the Engineer at least seven calendar days before pile driving begins on the project and at least five calendar days before pile driving begins on each subsequent abutment and bent foundations .
B .
The Department conducts at least one dynamic test for each foundation abutment or bent phase .
Refer to ASTM D . .
The Department performs an EOD dynamic test using PDA equipment on the first pile driven at each foundation and foundationphase to prevent overstressing the pile and to verify pile capacity .
C. Cooperate with the Department in conducting dynamic testing including the following .
Provide adequate space and conditions for the PDA vehicle and related equipment . .
Attach check and remove PDA gauges as necessary by one of the following methods a .
Climb the driver leads Implementation Driven Piles Page of January b .
Provide a platform at least ft square with a ft high safety rail equipped to be raised to the top of the pile located in the leads to provide Department personnel safe access . .
Install PDA gauges after placing pile in the leads .
a .
Allow up to one hour per pile for installation of PDA gauges if Department personnel is conducting the dynamic testing .
b .
Allow one additional hour for installation of measuring equipment after splicing if splicing is performed and additional testing is required. . Reduce the energy of the hammer or make other adjustments as necessary if the pile stress exceeds the specified limit during the test. . Drive the pile until the required driving resistance is achieved as determined by the dynamic testing and the other pile driving criteria is achieved unless otherwise indicated by the Engineer .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph D. D. The Engineer in coordination with the Departments Geotechnical Engineer of Record evaluates the driving resistance and driving stresses and establishes driving criteria using a wave equation analysis program with signal matching. . Do not complete the driving of other piles in the foundation until the Engineer gives notice that the test results indicate that sufficient capacity has been obtained and the driving criteria for the remainder of the piles in the foundation has been established .
E. Maximum allowable driving stress is .
x pile yield stress Fy. . Reduce hammer energy or make other appropriate adjustments to keep driving stresses below .Fy .
F. The Department will perform a BOR dynamic test on the pile after a sufficient time period to allow for setup capacity. . or more hours after the initial driving of the pile. . BOR dynamic testing is not performed using a cold hammer .
G. The Department may require the dynamic testing of additional piles and reestablishing driving criteria for the remaining piles within the foundation if pile does not meet the established driving criteria. . PILE INSTALLATION A. Predrill or preauger as shown if the designated pile tip elevation can not be reached by the pile driver or if otherwise authorized by the Engineer. . Do not drill holes with a diameter larger than the maximum pile dimension .
Implementation Driven Piles Page of January B .
Pile Splicing .
Use no more than one spliced section less than ft in length and no more than one other spliced section less than ft in length for each pile . .
Examine the driven pile section for distortion from its original shape or other damage from pile driving operations before splicing pile sections .
a .
Remove the damaged portion before splicing the next segment . .
Match the alignment of the new pile segment to the previously driven pile segment . .
Butt weld the entire pile crosssection using full penetration welds as shown according to the authorized Welding Procedure Specification WPS for pile welds and conforming to the limitations of AWS D .. a .
Table ..
Both ASTM A and ASTM A Grade and may be treated as prequalified base metals under Group .
b. ASTM A Grade will not be considered a prequalified base metal unless the steel has a Carbon Equivalent CE of .
percent or less .
c. Develop a Procedure Qualification Record PQR for all welding using Grade steel or provide documentation that the chemistry of the steel meets the CE requirements. . Use welders qualified according to AWS D. Clause .
Part C Performance Qualification for the position process and pile size used on the project . .
The Engineer may request additional nondestructive testing NDT such as ultrasonic testing of welds .
Ultrasonic defect indications will be evaluated according to the statically loaded criteria of AWS D .. a .
Perform repair and additional inspection if additional testing identifies defects warranting rejection .
b .
The Department will pay the cost of the additional testing and inspection if the additional NDT does not identify defects warranting rejection .
C. Keep driven pile within inches of the designated plan location and within percent of vertical plumb throughout the total length of the pile including bending of the buried portion of the pile equivalent to .
inches in one foot or .
inches in inches. . Keep side of pile at least inches away from nearest edge of pile cap. . Do not fill pipe piles with concrete until the Engineer notifies that the criteria have been met .
Implementation Driven Piles Page of January .
Drive additional piles as required to replace damaged piles and piles driven out of plumb or plan location at locations designated by the Department .
D. Redrive piles that are raised due to the driving of adjacent piles after initial driving .
E. Notify the Engineer of any water collecting in open pipe piles so the piles can be evaluated for possible damage .
F. Cover open ends of openended pipe piles to prevent the collection of precipitation other sources of water or debris .
G. Cutting Piles .
Verify that each driven pile has met the established driving criteria before cutting piles . .
Remove damaged material from the top of the piles. . Cut off piles with clean straightline cuts to the designated elevation at a right angle to the pile axis. . Embed the tops of piles in the concrete pile cap as shown .
H. Fill space between the pile and the surrounding soil with grout or flowable fill to reestablish lateral support .
I .
Remove loose and displaced materials from the foundation area around the completed piles leaving a clean solid surface to receive the concrete .
J .
Level irregularities of granular fill in the foundation area before placing abutment or pile cap . .
CONCRETE FILLING OF PIPE PILES A .
Remove water and debris from pipe piles before filling with concrete .
B .
Do not fill pipe piles with concrete before the Engineer confirms that the piles comply with the specified tolerances and pile driving criteria .
C. Avoid segregation of the concrete .
D. Use a tremie or drop chute to prevent concrete from contacting either the rebar cage or the pipe wall . .
Arrange placement aids such as chutes and pipes so concrete does not separate and flows freely without being pushed or shoveled .
Implementation Driven Piles Page of January E. Use high frequency internal vibrators to consolidate concrete to at least ft below the bottom of the rebar cage or to at least ft below the pile cutoff level whichever is deeper. . Do not vibrate concrete that has taken initial set. . Vibrate concrete again after inserting cage to eliminate voids around the cage if rebar cage is inserted after concrete has been placed .
F. Place the rebar cage into the pipe pile when the concrete reaches the planned bottom elevation of the rebar cage. . Support the rebar cage from the top until the concrete reaches the top of the pile. . Keep rebar cage within inches of the required vertical location .
G. Secure rebar cage in position until concrete is set .
H. Provide lighting to the work site if concrete placement is to occur after daylight hours so all operations are plainly visible .

SECTION INCLUDES A. Drilled shafts for structure foundations. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Portland Cement Concrete B .
Section Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire .
REFERENCES Not Used .
DEFINITIONS Not Used .
SUBMITTALS A .
Procedure to place concrete under water .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph A. . NONCONFORMANCE A .
A drilled shaft is nonconforming when it fails to be completed within the required tolerances. . Furnish equipment materials and work necessary to correct outof tolerance drilled shaft construction . .
ACCEPTANCE A. Drilled shafts may be accepted at a reduced price when the concrete compressive strength is less than the specified day minimum compressive strength. . Use price adjustment pay factors according to Section . .
The Department applies the price reduction for day compressive strength to the measured length of each shaft containing concrete with tested strength less than the specified compressive strength .
Implementation Drilled Shafts Page of January PART PRODUCTS .
CONCRETE A .
Class AAE Refer to Section . . Keep slump between and inches when tested at the truck .
B .
Modify as follows when placed under water .
Use at least seven bags of cement per cubic yard . .
Provide equipment capable of pumping specified concrete. . Use high range water reducers super plasticizers according to Section .
. .
REINFORCING STEEL A .
Refer to Section . . DRILLING EQUIPMENT A .
Capable of .
Drilling holes to the required diameter location alignment and depth in the type of materials present at the shaft locations . .
Installing and removing casing .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Drilling Shaft Excavations .
Drill straight vertical shaft excavations to the tip elevations shown or as directed by Engineer . .
Remove all loose material from the bottom of the excavations before placing concrete. . Do not use water or slurry for drilling operations. . Do not begin drilling for a shaft located three diameters centerto center or closer to an adjacent completed shaft until at least hours after placing concrete for the completed shaft. . Do not begin drilling for a shaft located between three and five diameters centertocenter from an adjacent completed shaft until at least hours after placing concrete for the completed shaft .
B. Casing .
Furnish and place casing when necessary to prevent the drilled hole from caving including when groundwater is encountered . .
Remove casing as the concrete is placed .
Implementation Drilled Shafts Page of January a .
Keep the bottom of the casing between ft and ft below the top of the concrete surface when withdrawing .
b .
Prevent concrete separation when withdrawing the casing .
C. Uncased Shaft Excavations .
Drill uncased dry noncaving shaft excavations in a continuous operation without interruption .
D. Remove all muck laitance and degraded concrete from the shaft. . CONSTRUCTION TOLERANCES A .
Install the drilled shaft within inches horizontally of the plan position at the plan elevation for the top of the shaft .
B .
Install the drilled shaft so the vertical alignment of the shaft excavation does not vary from the plan alignment by more than .
inches per foot of depth .
C. Install the drilled shaft so the top of the reinforcing steel cage is no more than inches above or below the plan elevation. . REBAR CAGES A. Rigidly brace the reinforcing cage with additional reinforcing steel as needed to retain its configuration during handling and construction. . Do not use loose bars . .
Pick cage in several locations as necessary to maintain cage shape and alignment during placement . .
CONCRETE PLACEMENT A .
Fill uncased dry noncaving holes immediately after drilling and in a continuous manner . .
Fill cased drilled holes within hours after drilling .
B .
Use a tremie or spout to prevent concrete from striking the steel reinforcing cage. . Do not allow concrete to freefall more than ft. C. Vibrate the concrete for at least the top ft of the shaft . .
CONCRETE PLACEMENT UNDER WATER A .
Obtain Engineers authorization to place concrete under water .
Implementation Drilled Shafts Page of January B .
Use concrete pumping equipment capable of pumping at least ydhr against a minimum ft head of concrete measured from the discharge end of the pump hose extension of the tremie pipe .
C. Use a rigid steel pipe pump hose extension for the tremie pipe with tight couplings straight to within  inch in ft. .
Length of extension At least the depth of the shaft . .
Inside diameter Greater than or equal to the concrete pump discharge hose but not more than one half the inside diameter of the reinforcing cage .
D. Purge the tremie pipe of water. . Insert a sturdy plastic ball or equivalent into the top of the pump hose extension before connecting the hose from the concrete pump . .
The ball must fit snugly into the pump hose extension when the hose is filled .
The hose must be strong enough to resist rupture. . Prime the hose and pipe with cement slurry .
E. Lower a small diameter pole with an attached flat plate into the hole to determine the top surface of concrete. . Mark both pole and pipe so that the length of penetration can be immediately determined . .
Prevent the end of the pipe from becoming plugged with soil from the bottom of the hole .
F. Begin pumping the concrete immediately after setting the reinforcing cage and tremie pipe in the hole .
Do not begin raising the tremie pipe until the concrete surface is ft above the bottom of the pipe .
G. Keep the bottom of the tremie pipe at least ft below the top of the concrete until the placement is complete and all muck laitance and degraded concrete is removed .
Provide a positive hold down if the pipe floats so the minimum ft penetration is maintained .
H. Do the following if the tremie pipe plugs equipment breaks down or loss of the seal at the end of the pipe occurs .
Pull the tremie pipe reset it ft below the top of the concrete and purge it. . Lower the tremie pipe to at least ft below the top of the placement and continue pumping concrete until all degraded concrete has lifted to the top of the shaft . .
Remove all muck laitance and degraded concrete .

DEFINITIONS A. Deflection Deviation from a pipes original shape .
B. NASSCO National Association of Sewer Service Companies .
C. Nominal Diameter Inside diameter of the pipe specified .
D. Pipe Interior Roughness .
Corrugated Interior surface that is formed into a series of alternating crests and valleys with a Mannings n coefficient greater than .. .
Smooth Lined Interior surface that is essentially smooth with a Mannings n coefficient less than or equal to .. E. Profile Wall Pipe Pipe that has a smooth interior wall with an exterior that is either is ribbed corrugated or smooth . .
The wall may contain hollow cores .
F. Spring Line Location of the maximum horizontal dimension of a pipe .
G. Thermoplastic Pipe Pipe made from plastic materials such as HDPE PVC and Polypropylene. . SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers certificate of compliance .
B .
Manufacturers data sheets and installation instructions .
Implementation Drainage Pipe Page of January C. Documentation from AASHTO NTPEP showing compliance with Table for the thermoplastic pipe material and diameter supplied for information .
D. NASSCO Pipeline Assessment certification for remote video technician for information .
E. Pipe inspection report for each pipe for review .
Include at least the following .
The project number date and time of the inspection for each pipe inspection the pipe identification used in the plan set and type and size of pipe. . A video recording of each pipe inspection in a digital format for remote inspection . .
Written and still image documentation of locations where alignment deviations joint gaps pipe damage and any other deficiencies were observed . .
Written documentation of deflection testing and measurements . .
ACCEPTANCE A .
General .
Each pipe is accepted for payment after verifying that the following criteria have been met a. Alignment b. Deflection c. Joint gap d. Damage .
Proposed resolutions for nonconforming pipes require the seal of a licensed Professional Engineer competent in the structural design of the pipe material being evaluated .
B. Alignment .
Do not exceed the installation horizontal and vertical alignment tolerances in Table .
Table Installation Alignment Tolerances Design Grade Horizontal Vertical inch ft Not to exceed the pipe manufacturers requirements  . .  Increase tolerance by percent for pipes with silttight joints .
Implementation Drainage Pipe Page of January C. Deflection .
Do not exceed a percent shape change from the nominal diameter .
a .
Proposals for acceptance of pipes with a deflection greater than .
percent will be rejected .
D. Joint Gap .
Do not exceed the joint separation measured along the length of pipe in Table .
a .
Repair or replace joints that show visible signs of soil or water infiltration .
Table Joint Gap Tolerances Nominal Diameter inches Separation inches to .
to .
to .
to .
E. Damage .
Pipes are to be free from a .
Cuts cracks spalls chips or punctures .
Cracks are allowable up to .
inch in width for reinforced concrete pipe b .
Loss or delamination of coatings .
c. Exposed reinforcing steel .
d. Imperfect concrete mixing and casting such as honeycomb or open texture .

The Engineer will determine which pipes to inspect when the percentage of pipes to inspect is less than percent .
a .

Inspection is not required for pipes less than ft in length . .
Notify the Engineer at least hours before performing an inspection. . Clean and flush the pipe with water immediately before the inspection .
a .
Remove and dispose material and debris from pipes .
B .
Remote Inspection .
CCTV Equipment a .
Record video using a crawler mounted camera capable of panning and tilting to a degree angle with the axis of the pipe and rotating degrees .
b .
Center the camera head in the pipe both vertically and horizontally to allow a clear picture of the entire periphery of the pipe .
Implementation Drainage Pipe Page of January c. Video image must be continuously illuminated clear focused and free from roll static or other image distortion qualities that may prevent the reviewer from evaluating the pipes condition .
Calibrate the videos lighting and focus to view the internal markings within the pipe. . CCTV Inspection a .
Remote video inspection operator must have a current NASSCO Pipeline Assessment certification .
b .
Use the video image to observe horizontal and vertical alignment deviations joints gaps and pipe damage .
Document all observations with captions in the video .
Note each location and provide a still image in the inspection report .
c. Do not move the crawler through the pipe at a speed greater than ftminute .
Stop the crawler and video the entire circumference at each joint .
Stop the crawler and zoom when necessary to video observations .
C. Manual Inspection .
Perform manual inspection for pipes in the presence of the Engineer .
a .
Follow UOSH requirements for inspecting confined entry spaces . .
Observe and document the following a. Deflection Take the following measurements every ft along the length of the pipe to the nearest  inch Vertically from the crown to invert .
Horizontally at the spring line .
Two measurements each diagonally at degrees to the pipe springline .
b .
Cracks Measure cracks using a device capable of measuring .
inch .
c. Joint Gaps Measure the widest separation at each joint to the nearest  inch .
d. Damage .
D. Mandrel Inspection .
Perform the mandrel inspection for pipes in the presence of the Engineer or representative .
a. Verify the diameter of the mandrel with a proving ring or other method according to manufacturers recommendations .

Mandrel a .
Contain at least nine equally spaced runners degree angles .
b .
Length not less than the diameter. . Deflection test a .
Pull a mandrel that is percent less than the pipe nominal inside diameter .
b .
Perform the following if the mandrel does not pass Record the maximum distance achieved from the inlet side .
Remove the mandrel and continue the inspection from the outlet end of the pipe toward the inlet end .
Record the maximum distance achieved from the outlet side .
Repeat inspection with a mandrel that is .
percent less than the pipe nominal inside diameter .

PREPARATION A .
General .
Perform all work within the limits of the Department right of way unless written agreements are in place with adjacent property owners . .
Provide adequate control of water in the host pipe when necessary .
a .
Repair damage caused as a result of flow control or lack thereof . .
Provide the necessary controls to prevent pollutants from being transported downstream .
B .
Host Pipe Cleaning .
Remove material to include sediment rocks and miscellaneous debris to inspection and install the pipe liner. . Use a cleaning method and tools that will not cause damage to the pipe or surrounding roadway features .
a .
Notify the Engineer when cleaning could result in damage .
b .
Do not cause erosion of surrounding areas from cleaning operations .
c. Minimize sediment from being transported downstream . .
Collect and properly dispose of all material removed .
C. Host Pipe Inspection .
Perform remote inspection for pipes with a nominal diameter less than inches using a closedcircuit television CCTV crawler . .
Perform a visual inspection for pipes with diameter greater than inches .
Implementation Drainage Pipe Liner Page of January .
Inspect the condition of the host pipe and the suitability of the pipe liner installation .
Document and notify the Engineer of the following a .
Collapsed or impassable sections of the pipe b. Horizontal or vertical alignment deviations c. Structural concerns d. Loss of material surrounding the pipe exterior e. Infiltration of water f. Repairs required to perform the installation D. Drainage Pipe Liner .
Verify host pipe internal size and length before ordering pipe liner. . PVC foldandform and CIPP liner dimensions a .
Size the pipe liner to have an outside diameter that will tightly fit the inside of the host pipe .
b .
Provide sufficient pipe liner length to continuously line the host pipe with no intermediate joints. . Segmental Thermoplastic and Metal liner dimensions a .
Size the pipe liner to have an outside dimension that will freely pass through the host pipe and accommodate grout placement .
b .
Use only one type of pipe liner and joint system in any single host pipe . .
INSTALLATION A .
General .
Remove sediment and debris that might have accumulated after the initial cleaning immediately before installing the pipe liner . .
Handle and install the pipe liner in a manner that will not cause damage to the pipe liner . .
Provide a smooth finish and a tight seal between the pipe liner and the drainage structure walls at pipe penetrations . .
Restore lateral and inlet connections . .
Inspect the rehabilitated pipe upon completion and before acceptance by the Engineer .
a .
Evaluate pipe liners that contain dry spots wrinkles delamination holes cracks joint gaps soft spots blisters or other defects .
Implementation Drainage Pipe Liner Page of January B. PVC foldandform and CIPP Liner .
Meet minimum installation requirements according to ASTM F or ASTM F for PVC foldand form .
Meet minimum installation requirements according to ASTM F or ASTM F for CIPP . .
Follow the manufacturers recommended curing and relaxation period required to hold the pipe liner against the host pipe .
a .
Provide sufficient gauges monitoring devices and tests to determine the effectiveness of the curing .
C. Segmental Thermoplastic and Metal Liner .
Construct a bulkhead at each end of the host pipe to fully support the fluid thrust loads exerted by the placement of grout .
a. Vent bulkheads to allow release of trapped air as the grout flows into the annular space . .
Provide a minimum of hrs for the pipe liner temperature to equalize within the host pipe before placing grout . .
Fill the entire full length of annular space between the host pipe and the pipe liner with grout .
a .
Provide sufficient gauges monitoring devices and tests to determine the effectiveness of the grout placement. . Do not exceed the pipe liner maximum specified grouting pressure .
a .
Use a pumping unit with a pressure meter and valves capable of limiting grout pumping pressures to the maximum pressure recommended by the manufacturer at the end of the discharge pipe. . Place grout in lifts to avoid excessive buoyant forces or grouting pressures .
a .
Allow each lift to cure sufficiently before proceeding with next lift . .
Remove any internal braces or bands once the grout is sufficiently cured and before acceptance .

PREPARATION A .
General .
Perform all work within the limits of the Department right of way unless written agreements are in place with adjacent property owners . .
Complete backfill and embankment placement over the pipe before concrete lining . .
Provide adequate control of water in the host pipe when necessary .
a .
Repair damage caused as a result of flow control or lack thereof . .
Provide the necessary controls to prevent pollutants from being transported downstream. . Verify host pipe internal diameter and length before ordering concrete .
B .
Host Pipe Cleaning .
Remove material to include sediment rocks and miscellaneous debris in order that an inspection and concrete lining can be properly performed .
Implementation Concrete Lined Pipe Invert Page of January .
Use a cleaning method and tools that will not cause damage to the pipe or surrounding roadway features .
a .
Notify the Engineer when cleaning could result in damage .
b .
Do not cause erosion of surrounding areas from cleaning operations .
c. Minimize sediment from being transported downstream . .
Collect and properly dispose of all material removed .
C. Host Pipe Inspection .
Perform a visual inspection .
Inspect the condition of the host pipe and the suitability of the concrete lined invert installation .
Document and notify the Engineer of the following a .
Collapsed or impassable sections of the pipe b. Horizontal and vertical alignment deviations c. Structural concerns d. Loss of material surrounding the pipe exterior e. Infiltration of water f. Repairs required to perform the installation .
PLACEMENT A .
Shape and support the welded wire reinforcement to provide inch clearance from the crest of the metal corrugations .
B .
Place concrete at least inches above the crest of the corrugations and to a width one third of the circumference of a round pipe or the maximum span of an arch pipe. . Control the thickness of the concrete by installing noncorrosive pins nails or other gauging devices into the crest of the corrugations perpendicular to the surface .
C. Finish the concrete to a floated surface finish according to Section .
D. Cure concrete according to Section . .
Provide a minimum of hours before allowing water to flow through the pipe after applying the curing compound .

Location .

a .

B .
Concrete Removal .
Make saw cuts inch deep to define the work areas . .
Remove concrete using lb class handoperated jackhammers or smaller .
C. Reinforcing Steel .
Cut steel encountered during concrete removal operations so that the final catch basin opening is unencumbered as shown on the plans. . Expose a minimum of inches of reinforcing steel in both the bottom and upper mats of the existing approach slab on at least three sides of the new catch basin location. . Repair the surface of damaged rebar before placing concrete .
a. Epoxy coating repair Refer to ASTM D . b. Galvanized rebar repair Refer to ASTM A . D. Excavation .
Excavate sufficient material to construct the catch basin to the required size and depth .

DEFINITIONS A .
Catch BasinDrop Inlet A structure accepting drainage from gutters or medians or other channels and discharging the water through a conduit .
Refer to the CB and DB Series Standard Drawings for shape and dimensions of Standard Catch Basins .
B. Inlet A grated surface connection to a closed conduit such as a storm drain .
A structure at the upstream end of a cross culvert .
The upstream end of any structure through which water may flow .
C. Manhole access hole A circular structure for access and joining pipes .
Refer to the CB Series Standard Drawings for the Standard Detail for a Manhole .

C. Repair Procedure .
Submit to the Engineer for approval before performing any repairs .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph B. .
ACCEPTANCE A .
Select and construct or install castinplace precast drainage structures according to this Section . .
Cast in place construction. . Precast construction .
a .
Field verify the fit and function at structure locations before manufacturing .
b .
The Department will not reimburse the Contractor for precast structures that do not fit existing field conditions .
B .
Repair or replace any structure that has the following .
Fractures or cracks passing through the wall except for a single end crack that does not exceed the thickness of the precast unit . .
Defects showing improper proportioning mixing or molding. . Honeycombing and open texture. . Damaged or cracked ends that prevent joining manhole or inlets grade rings and sections. . Any continuous crack with a surface width of .
inch or more that extends more than inches anywhere on the wall. . Limit cracks or fractures for grade rings or similar structures .
Refer to ASTM C . C. Precast Structures .
Furnish precast drainage structures according to the CB Series Standard Drawings .
a. Prequalify the supplier according to the UDOT Quality Management Plan PrecastPrestressed Concrete Structures .
b. Furnish precast structures that are plumb and square within  inch per foot so that precast adjoining elements fit .
Implementation Concrete Drainage Structures Page of January c. Mark structures with date of casting and supplier identification .
D. Obtain acceptance from the Engineer upon completing each installation and before placing backfill. . Verify the structures and pipe connections appear watertight. . Test according to this Section Article .
when directed by the Engineer .

Implementation Concrete Drainage Structures Page of January a .
Locate lifting devices to avoid interference with the reinforcing steel. . Do not ship precast units until after day compressive strength has been attained .
a .
Protect the unit from any damage . .
Refer to ASTM C . Comply with manufacturer installation guidelines .
a .
Inspect precast drainage structures for defects before lowering into excavation .
b .
Clean mating surfaces of all foreign materials such as dirt mud and stones and apply proper joint sealing material where applicable .
c. Assemble all joints tightly .
d. Use care when joining precast elements in cold weather .
Do not force joints together with mechanical equipment .
e. Sufficiently warm all sealing materials to flow without causing damage to precast joint elements. . Furnish structures with appropriate openings for connecting pipe .
a .
Cast or cut structure openings .
Do not expose reinforcing steel or reduce reinforcing steel covering at openings .
b .
Do not modify precast units in the field by cutting or enlarging holes or by making any other changes without the manufacturers and Engineers approval .
c. Modify precast units only according to manufacturer requirements. . Do not place precast drainage structure in excavation that has water and frozen surfaces. . Plug lift insert recesses with a sand to cement grout mix .
a .
Finish flush with top bottom or both surfaces of concrete .
D. Castinplace concrete drainage structures . .
Refer to CB and DB Series Standard Drawings. . Construct according to Section . .

TESTING A .
Conduct either a vacuum test or exfiltration test to verify the drainage structures are watertight at the direction of the Engineer upon failure of the visual inspection referenced in this Section Article .. . Furnish all necessary equipment and materials for repair and re test any structures that fail any tests. . Do not conduct vacuum and exfiltration tests concurrently .
Implementation Concrete Drainage Structures Page of January B .
Vacuum Test Follow the test procedure outlined below .
Vacuum test precast structures after assembly and before backfilling .
a .
Form a seal between the vacuum base and the manhole rimprecast structure cover .
Secure pipe plugs to prevent movement while the vacuum is drawn .
b .
Draw a vacuum of inches of mercury Hg .
Record the time for the vacuum to drop to inches .
c. Passing drop rates for the time to drop to inches are DiameterWidth Time to Drop inch Hg up to ft seconds ft and larger seconds d. Make necessary repairs if the structure fails the test .
Repairs and repair procedures must be acceptable to the Engineer .
e. Disassemble the manhole and replace the gaskets if preformed plastic gaskets are pulled out during the vacuum test .
C. Exfiltration Test Follow test procedure ASTM C as modified below .
Plug all pipes leading into or out of the precast structure for a watertight seal . .
Fill precast structure with water to a level inches below the casting rim or lid. . Let the water stand for two hours before beginning the test to allow absorption into the precast structure. . Place additional water to bring the water level back to inches below the rim or lid after the two hour stabilization. . Test for at least two hours and verify the leakage is less than shown on table .
Implementation Concrete Drainage Structures Page of January Table Precast Structure ExFiltration Test Allowable Leakage Water Depth measured from invert to water level Allowable water drop per hour Feet Maximum Horizontal Internal Dimension ft. ft ft gals inches gals inches gals inches .
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Adjust volume loss proportionally for different size not shown Provide an engineering analysis for equivalent exfiltration rates for depths greater than feet .
D. The Department will reimburse the Contractor for the actual cost of each test required by the Engineer to meet vacuum or exfiltration requirements not to exceed per test .

MANUFACTURE A .
