B .
Line posts must have a minimum circumference of inches .
Implementation RightofWay Fence and Gate Page of January C. Gate brace and corner posts must have a minimum circumference of inches .
D. All posts must be sound free of decay and defect and structurally suitable . .
TREATED WOOD POSTS AND WOOD BRACE RAILS A .
Sound Douglasfir hemlock or pine that is free from decay splits multiple cracks any other defect and structurally suitable .
B .
Round or sawed rectangular post and braces . .
Round posts must have a minimum diameter of inches. . Gate brace and corner posts must have a diameter of at least inches. . Rectangular posts must have a dimension of at least inches x inches. . Square members at least inches x inches may be rough sawn or SS lumber. . No post or pole rail may deviate from a straight edge placed along its length by more than  the diameter of the post or pole rail. . Taper diameter differential in round members must not exceed inches in ft. . Fabricate posts and brace rails before pressure treating the wood members . .
Refer to Section for post and brace rail treatment . .
Apply field treatment preservatives according to AWPA Standard M after field drilling .
Refer to AWPA Standard M Section for accepted field treatment preservative systems. . Keep round posts free of bark protruding knots and other irregularities. . METAL POSTS AND BRACES A .
Refer to AASHTO M or ASTM F . .
Omit anchor plate only if the post is set in a concrete footing with a minimum cross sectional dimension of inches and a depth equal to full penetration of the post .
B .
Coat fasteners with a Class Coating according to ASTM A . . Hotdipped galvanized posts or painted posts may be used .
Refer to AASHTO M . . TUBULARSTEEL FRAME GATE WITH WIRE FABRIC A .
Gates are not to exceed feet in width .
Implementation RightofWay Fence and Gate Page of January B .
Gates greater than feet require one vertical support of .
inch galvanized steel tubing. . Place pipe braces vertically in the center of each gate .
C. Provide an adjustable truss rod of  inch minimum diameter to prevent sagging on gates .
D. Dimensions shown and specified are the minimum clear openings between gate posts .
The supplier must provide a gate with fittings to fill the opening .
E. Use wire mesh fence for gates .
F. Supply hotdipped galvanized steel fittings .
Refer to AASHTO M . G. Frame and walk gates must be made of .
inch galvanized steel tubing .
H. Fastener for single gates must be an inch length of galvanized chain secured to the gate at one end and fitted with a snap fastener on the loose end .
I .
All double drive gates must have a center latch in place of a chain fastener .
A pin from the latch must fit in a socket embedded in concrete .
J .
Use degree industrial hinges. . Use hinges that will not twist turn or allow sagging of the gate. . Verify gates are capable of being opened and closed easily by one person. . Pintles for gates on wood posts must be  inches in diameter or larger . .

B. Galvanized gauge hog rings .

PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Clear and grade a minimum area to permit proper fence installation . .
INSTALLATION A .
Install endbraced posts in existing cross fences when intersected by the new rightofway fence .
B. Brace corner post in two directions .
C. Brace end and gate posts in one direction .
D. Compact backfill material around post to the density of the surrounding ground E. Cut wood posts to the designated height and slant top at an approximate degree angle .
F. Use  inch diameter x inch long galvanized steel dowels to connect wood braces to the adjacent posts .
G. Tension brace wires until installation is rigid .
H. Rail end caps and set screw bolt or butt weld metal braces to the metal posts .
I .
Support each timber brace with two No .
gauge galvanized iron wires fastened to the wood posts .
J .
Remove sags from fence fabric without causing tension crimps to fail .
Implementation RightofWay Fence and Gate Page of January K. Install grounds according to industry standard anywhere electric transmission distribution or secondary lines cross a wood post fence .
Refer to National Electrical Safety Code Section .
L. Install fence fabric and barbed wire on the side of the post away from the roadway . .
Attach each strand of barbed wire to the post .
M. Install fences according to FG Series Standard Drawings .

END OF SECTION Implementation Wildlife Escape Ramps of January SECTION WILDLIFE ESCAPE RAMPS PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A .
Standard Combination and Corner Wildlife Escape Ramps. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Embankment Borrow and Backfill B .
Section RightofWay Fence and Gate C. Section Hydraulic Erosion Control Products D. Section Topsoil E. Section Seed Turf Seed and Turf Sod Section F. Section Timber and Timber Treatment .
REFERENCES A. American WoodPreservers Association AWPA Book of Standards .
DEFINITIONS A .
Combination Wildlife Escape Ramp Three earthen ramps two opposite each other and perpendicular to the rightofway fence plus one between them parallel perpendicular to the rightofway fence creating a three sided corral for animals to jump into to escape from the rightofway .
Refer to FG Series Standard Drawings .
B .
Corner Wildlife Escape Ramp An earthen ramp placed in the corner of the rightofway fence to allow wild animals to escape from the rightof way .
Refer to FG Series Standard Drawings .
C. Standard Wildlife Escape Ramp An earthen ramp perpendicular to the rightofway fence to allow wild animals to escape from the rightofway .
Refer to FG Series Standard Drawings .
Implementation Wildlife Escape Ramps of January .

PREPARATION A .
Site .
Complete grading requirements before installation of guardrail guardrail end treatment and crash cushions .
a .
Obtain approval of site grading approach and recovery areas and layout before system installation .
Implementation WBeam Guardrail Page of January .
Protect work area when removing guardrail barriers guardrail end treatment or crash cushions until the barriers guardrail end treatment or crash cushion are reconstructed or the hazard is mitigated. . POSTS AND BLOCKS A .
Drill required holes in posts and blocks according to BA Series Standard Drawings before installation. . Field drilling post is acceptable when installing the bottom rail .
a .
Coat field drilled steel post with a fieldapplied cold zinc material .
B .
Drive post if satisfactory results are obtained without damaging the post. . Do not drive posts through asphalt . .
Refer to BA D Series Standard Drawings .
C. Excavate postholes when not driven . .
Compact approved backfill material into bottom of hole if hole is over excavated . .
Compact backfill material around post to the satisfaction of the engineer .
a .
Refer to Section . . RAIL ELEMENTS A .
Drill or punch required holes according to BA Series Standard Drawings before installation. . Field drilled holes in rail element are permitted on a limited basis when required .
a .
Drill no more than three holes on three consecutive posts .
b .
Coat all field drilled rail elements with a fieldapplied cold zinc material .
B .
Shop bend curved sections as required in BA Series Standard Drawings. . DELINEATION A .
Install delineation according to BA and GW Standard Drawings .
Implementation WBeam Guardrail Page of January .
RAISING EXISTING WBEAM GUARDRAIL A .
Raise Wbeam guardrail to maintain the minimum rail height according to BA Series Standard Drawings. . Only Wbeam guardrail with two or threehole post system is eligible to be raised .
a .
Raise the two or threehole post systems rail element only if the rail element is not currently set in the highest hole. . Wbeam guardrail with singlehole post system can not be raised .
Do not lift posts in order to raise rail .
B .
Remove existing rail element and blocks .
C. Complete shoulder grading as required by BA Series Standard Drawings .
D. Reinstall rail elements and blocks on existing two or threehole post system using the next hole up on the two or threehole system to meet the height requirements according to BA Series Standard Drawings. . Do not drill new holes in posts .

STEEL POSTS A .
Supply and galvanize posts as specified .
Refer to ASTM A and AASHTO M . B .
Use flanged channelshaped steel posts that weight lbft .
C. Make all cuts before galvanizing posts .
Refer to GW Series Standard Drawings . .
FLEXIBLE POSTS A .
Free of burns discoloration contamination and other defects .
B .
Remains flexible at temperatures from degrees F to degrees F. C. Capable of being driven into an earth shoulder with or without a pilot hole .
D. Tensile strength of psi .
Refer to ASTM D . . QUALITY CONTROL FLEXIBLE POST TESTING A .
Meet Cold Bend Test .
Subject two posts to a temperature of degrees F degrees F for at least four hours . .
Immediately bend each post four times through a degree angle around a inch mandrel. . Each post must return to its original straight configuration within a degree angle within five minutes at the end of the four bends. . Any cracking or significant loss of rigidity are grounds for failure .
B .
Meet Hot Bend Test .
Subject two posts to a temperature of degrees F degrees F for at least four hours . .
Satisfy all bending and physical requirements specified in the Cold Bend Test .
C. Meet Impact Resistance Test .
Subject post to impacts by a typical sedan as follows a .
Three hits degree angle at degrees F. b .
Three hits degree angle at degrees F. c. Ten hits degree angle at mph .
d. Five hits degree angle at mph .
Implementation Delineators Page of January .
Acceptable Results a .
Installed post remain intact securely anchored and within degrees of vertical orientation .
b .
Installed post shows minimal signs of cracking or loss of rigidity .
c. Installed post retains at least percent of its reflective sheeting .
d. Impact vehicle suffers little or no damage during the impact test .
D. Exposure .
Expose the specimens for hours in a carbon arctype apparatus according to ASTM G Method . .
Acceptable results a .
Exposure does not result in delamination distress or discoloration .
b. Sheeting is not removable from the specimens without damage .
c. Post is resistant to ultraviolet light ozone hydrocarbons and other weathering. . SHEETING A .
Refer to Section . .
PAINT A .
Refer to Section .
PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION A .
Posts Visibly free of bends or twists both before and after installation .

Implementation Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments Page of January PART PRODUCTS .
CRASH CUSHION AND BARRIER END TREATMENTS A .
Select from the approved products list within the UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments . .
Refer to the UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments for specific uses and requirements for each approved system type .
Refer to httpwww.udot.utah.govgostandardsreferences . .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings for crash cushion or end treatment grading and marker requirements .
B .
Crash Cushion Types .
Type A. a .
Supply system with an adequate width as shown .
b .
Include additional fender panels posts and hardware to gain the required width for hazard protection greater than the manufactured width of a system .
c. Supply system for the required speed according to UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments .
d. Galvanize steel parts according to manufacturers requirements .
e. Supply transition element for the approach of opposing traffic when system is installed with bidirectional traffic and the back of system is within the maximum required clear zone .
Two transition elements required when system is installed with Wbeam median barrier .
f. Supply crash cushion markers .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings . .
Type B Protects fixed hazards up to ft wide and within ft of traveled way with less than ft of longitudinal space in front of the hazard .
a .
Supply system with an adequate width as shown .
b .
Supply systems for the required speed according to UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments .
c. Galvanize steel parts according to manufacturers requirements .
d. Supply transition element for the approach of opposing traffic when system is installed with bidirectional traffic and the system is within the maximum required clear zone .
Two transition elements required when system is installed with Wbeam median barrier .
e. Supply crash cushion markers .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings .
Implementation Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments Page of January .
Type C Protects the approach ends of median Wbeam guardrail when the longitudinal space in front of the hazard is greater than ft. a .
Galvanize steel parts according to manufacturers requirements .
b .
Supply doublesided Wbeam transition element when system is installed in conjunction with concrete barrier or bridge parapet .
Refer to BA Series Standard Drawings .
c. Supply crash cushion markers .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings . .
Type D. a .
Supply system with an adequate width as shown .
b .
Supply system for the required speed according to UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments edition .
c. Galvanize steel parts according to manufacturers requirements .
d. Supply transition element for the approach of opposing traffic when system is installed with bidirectional traffic and the back of system is within the maximum required clear zone .
Two transition elements required when system is installed with Wbeam median barrier .
e. Include fender panels posts and hardware to gain the required width for hazard protection greater than the manufactured width of a system .
f. Supply crash cushion markers .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings . .
Type E Sand Barrel Arrays a .
Design sand barrel array using Energite III Module Systems design manual .
Design sand barrel array to meet roadway design speed .
b. Certify sand barrels and components meet NCHRP for nonredirective gating crash cushions .
c. Construct sand barrels using a frangible polyethylene material that will shatter upon impact .
Use yellow sand barrels .
Permanently apply manufactured date month and year to each piece of the barrel system .
Use one or two piece barrel construction .
Interface cones with the barrel to prevent sand leakage but allow for drainage of excess water for sand barrel systems that use barrel and cone configuration .
Provide lids for each sand barrel .
Fasten lid securely to barrel .
Implementation Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments Page of January d. Provide sand barrels that hold the required amounts of sand according to requirements of the typical sand barrel array .
lb lb lb lb and lb .
Mark each barrel in a manner that the amount of sand required for the nominal weight is visible for systems that are designed using barrels for multiple sand weight requirements .
e. Fill modules with dry sand containing no more than percent moisture .
f. Supply crash cushion markers and construct pad .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings .
C. End Treatment Types .
Type F a .
Galvanize steel parts according to manufacturers requirements .
b .
Supply crash cushion markers .
Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings . .
Type G a .

PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION A .
Prepare site to finished grade before installing crash cushion or barrier end treatment. . Construct approach areas and recovery areas to meet CC Series Standard Drawings and system requirements before system installation. . Construct concrete pad according to system requirements when applicable .
a .
Crash Cushion Types A B and D require concrete pad constructed to manufacturers requirements when installed in a permanent application .
b .
End Treatment Type F QuadTrend requires a concrete pad and concrete anchor system in all applications .
Refer to manufacturers requirements .
c. End Treatment Type F BEATSSCC can be mounted on a concrete pad with surface mounted posts .
Refer to manufacturers concrete pad and mounting requirements .
Implementation Crash Cushions and Barrier End Treatments Page of January d. Crash Cushion Type C and End Treatment Types F G and H. Create block out hole by forming saw cutting or other similar method required when installing ground mounted system into asphalt or concrete .
Refer to BA D Series Standard Drawings .
e. Use manufacturers specification for concrete pad construction .
f. Refer to CC Series Standard Drawings for Type E sand barrel detail for pad requirements . .
Obtain approval of site grading approach and recovery areas and layout before system installation . .
Compact backfill material around posts and foundation tubes with mechanical effort to match the density of the surrounding soil .
B .
Install crash cushion and barrier end treatments according to .
CC Series Standard Drawings and UDOT Guidelines for Crash Cushion and Barrier End Treatments. . Manufacturers specifications and recommendations. . Use manufacturer certified installer to perform the installation .
C. Repair or replace permanent systems damaged before final acceptance within hours of notification of damage . .
Exceptions include .
a Damage is caused by an errant vehicle other than a vehicle operated by the Contractor or a subcontractor .
b Damage occurs after traffic has been established in the final lane configuration with shoulders as established in the project plans. . Payment will be made using a force account basis for the cost of repair or replacement of the damaged system when the Engineer determines the conditions described under the exception in this Section Article .
paragraph Ca apply .

Implementation Concrete Barrier Page of January D. Constant Slope Barrier Placed by Extrusion or Slip Form .
Provide an offset guideline for the extrusion or slip form machine to maintain the predetermined grade. . Feed concrete to the extrusion or slip form machine at a uniform rate . .

a .

b .

PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Site Considerations .
Complete grading to final grade requirements according to the plan before installing cable barrier post foundations terminals transitions Wbeam components and anchor systems .
Implementation High Tension Cable Barrier Page of January .
Apply a bareground treatment ft on each side of the cable system using bare ground herbicide .
a .
Apply after cable barrier foundations have been installed and the excess material has been removed or graded into surrounding area .
b .
Follow productlabeling requirements for selected product .
c. Apply herbicide at a rate of lbacre .
d. Have a license issued by the Utah Department of Agriculture for RightofWay application . .
CONCRETE FOUNDATIONS REQUIREMENTS A .
Line Posts .
Castinplace post foundation a .
Do not over excavate hole .
b .
Install manufactures required reinforcing steel .
c. Install post sleeve no greater than  inch above finished grade of foundation .
d. Fill the excavated hole with concrete .
Dome concrete down from top of post sleeve to flush with finished grade .
Refer to BA Series Standard Drawings .
Do not use a tubular concrete form for foundation casting .
Post sleeve will be within  inch alignment to the post on either side .
a Sleeve alignment can be adjusted to meet placement requirements on a horizontal curve .
b Meet manufacturers requirements if supplied system uses offset posts .
Install foundation in such a manner that the post will stand vertically and be no greater than  inch from plumb .
e. Allow concrete to cure a minimum of seven days and achieve psi before installing cable .
B. Castinplace nonNCHRP Cable Barrier Anchor deadman anchor .
Install according to manufacturers specification .
a. Excavate hole and form a castinplace anchor .
Install reinforcing steel according to cable manufacturers requirements .
Install hardware according to cable manufacturers requirements for cable attachment .
Install so the top of the anchor block will be at the same grade and elevation as the three consecutive posts foundations approaching the anchor block .
Implementation High Tension Cable Barrier Page of January b .
Place concrete and allow to cure a minimum of seven days or achieve psi before connecting and tensioning cable .
c. Backfill with excavated material .
Compact material around the castinplace anchor block to a minimum of percent of maximum laboratory density .
Refer to Section .
Dispose of excess material by removal or grade into surrounding area .
Install so that anchor block will not move greater than inches toward the opposite cable anchor or terminal during tensioning or after tensioning has been completed .
Remove and replace with a larger block or secure so that no additional decrease of cable tension occurs if anchor block moves greater than inches . .
Install anchor line posts with sleeves and hardware for cable attachment as required for anchor system according to manufacturers specification .
a .
Install foundations with post sleeves for anchor posts according to manufacturers requirements .
Follow the same installation procedure use the same concrete material and allow the same curing time as required in this Section Article .

Implementation Precast RetainingNoise Walls Page of January .
Use a form release agent that meets the following a .
A manufacturers recommended liquidrelease agent that will not bond with stain or adversely affect precast concrete surfaces and will not impair subsequent surface or joint treatments of precast concrete .
b .
A nonpetroleum release agent meeting all EPA requirements .
c. A release agent that is not detrimental to concrete strength or durability and that does not impart color tint or texture to the finished product .
E. Lifting Devices .
Use the number type and size necessary to lift the largest precast panel used on the project and tilt it from a horizontal position to a vertical position. . Use a galvanized flushtype that does not project beyond the edge of the panels. . Design for the shear factor of safety .
for lifting from a flat position and a tension factor of safety for lifting from a vertical position. . Design for shear so that the panels can be lifted from either side . .

a .

Cast the panels to dimensional tolerances according to Precast Concrete Institute PCI or National Precast Concrete Association NPCA and as shown .
a .
Cast in metal forms .
b .
Do not use coloring additives .
c. Achieve uniformity of appearance color texture and pattern .
d. Produce a concrete panel with smooth solid surfaces free of voids and air pockets .
Implementation Precast RetainingNoise Walls Page of January .
Permanently mark each panel with the casting date and the panel identification number supplied by Engineer on the panel end near the top . .
Provide the surface texture architectural treatment on both sides of noise panels as shown .
Provide the surface texture architectural treatment as shown on the exposed side of retaining panels .
Remove all residue from panel surfaces .
a .
Use a concrete formliner to achieve the specified concrete texture .
b .
Provide panel faces that are free of joint marks grain and other obvious defects .
Provide corners including false joints that are uniform straight and sharp . .
Apply water repellent according to Section before shipping .
a .
Water repellent may be applied at the project site after installation when authorized by the Engineer . .
Replace panels that a .
Do not match in contrast .
b .
Are not permanently marked .
c. Show discoloration from release agents. . Use a single fullheight noise panel between posts for all noise walls .
Use a single noise panel and a single retaining panel between posts for retainingnoise walls .
a .
The noise and retaining panels may be cast as a single panel when there is less than ft of soil provided that the portion of the panel retaining soil meets all retaining panel requirements .
D. Curing .
Cure according to Section . . QUALITY CONTROL A. Precast Posts and Panels .
Document all test results .
The quality control file will contain at least the following information a .
Element identification b .
Date and time of casting c. Concrete cylinder test results d. Quantity of the used concrete and the batch printout e. Formstripping date and repairs if applicable f. Location or number of blockouts and lifting inserts g. Temperature and moisture of curing period h. Lifting device details requirements and inserts i .

DELIVERY HANDLING AND STORAGE A .
Store units with adequate dunnage and bracing . .
Protect units to prevent contact with soil and staining . .
Prevent cracking distortion warping and other physical damage .
B .
Place stored units so identification marks are clearly visible and units can be inspected .
C. Place nonstaining resilient spacers of even thickness between each unit .
D. Support units during shipment on nonstaining shock absorbing material. . POST HOLES A .
Place edge of post holes no closer than ft from underground utilities . .
CONCRETE POSTS A .
Set true to line and grade .
Replace posts more than  inch out of plumb in ft of exposed length .
B .
Replace posts that do not adequately support or accept insertion of the precast panels. . PRECAST CONCRETE PANELS A .
Refer to SW Series Standard Drawings .
B .
Set elevations in the field for the Engineers observation .
Stake elevations to the bottom of the bottom panel .
Align as shown .
C. Apply construction adhesive to wood shims and drive tightly into place .
Locate as shown. . Cut off shim flush with post face .

b .

b .

b .

END OF SECTION Implementation Retroreflective Sheeting Page of January SECTION RETROREFLECTIVE SHEETING PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A. Retroreflective sheeting materials for traffic signs and traffic control devices. . RELATED SECTIONS Not Used .
REFERENCES A. ASTM B Aluminum and AluminumAlloy Sheet and Plate B. ASTM D Retroreflective Sheeting for Traffic Control C. Code of Federal Regulations CFR D. Construction of Roads and Bridges on Federal Highway Projects FP .
DEFINITIONS A. Retroreflective Sheeting .
Sheeting The retroreflective or nonreflective material that comprises the background legend word messages and symbols and border. . Sheeting Components The matched component products required for the manufacture of highway signs consist of the sheeting cutout letters and borders adhesives inks and overlay films .
Failure of the sheeting inks or overlay films provided sold or recommended for use constitute a failure of the entire sign and replacement under manufacturers warranty replacement obligations .
All components and warranties will be compatible with substrates used by the Department including Aluminum ASTM B H or T. .
Permanent Signs Include sign installations that are in their final configuration and that are expected to have a multiyear life .
Examples include freeway guide signs regulatory signs warning signs barrier markers crash cushion markers and delineation .
Implementation Retroreflective Sheeting Page of January .
Work Zone Standard Signs MUTCD and Department standard application signs including but not limited to Road Work Ahead Work Zone Speed Limit Flagger Symbols Business Access and Regulatory signing within the work zone. . Work Zone Project Specific Signs Signs that have legends specific to the project and that can not be reused on a future project .
Examples include Alder Street closed from st to nd Avenue use Birch Street or project notification signs .
These are typically used for only one construction season . .
Flexible Work Zone Devices Include such devices as roll up signs cones tall cones and flags with retroreflective sheeting. . Work Zone Channelization Devices Include such devices as drums vertical panels barricades tubular markers and pavement marking tabs. . SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers Product Data and Specifications .
PART PRODUCTS .
MATERIALS A. Retroreflective Sheeting .
Meet Standard Specifications for Construction of Roads and Bridges on Federal Highway Projects FP . .
Conform to CFR Subpart F for Standard Highway Colors for Ordinary and Fluorescent Sheeting. . Meet ASTM D Standard Specification for Retroreflective Sheeting for Traffic Control .
B. Nonreflective Sheeting As specified and according to the recommendation of the retroreflective sheeting manufacturer .
C. Use matched component cutout legends symbols and borders .
D. Use only acrylic EC film to achieve color .
Do not use vinyl EC film to achieve color . .

INSTALLATION A .
Permanent sign and sheeting identification .
Affix to each sign a inch high twodigit number representing the fabrication year to the front lower left corner of each sign .
Use numbers of contrasting color to sheeting color .
Represent the year as and so forth. . Affix to each sign a inch x inch impermeable nonfading weatherresistant selfadhesive label .
Attach label where it will not obscure sheeting .
The label contains the month and year of manufacture Contractors name and type of sheeting .

DEFINITIONS A .
Traffic Sign Components .
Panel Assembly of substrate and attached sheeting .
Several panels may be necessary to complete one sign .
Panel types are a .
Type A Retroreflective sheeting on sheet aluminum PW Retroreflective sheeting on plywoodbacked sheet aluminum b. Legend Nonreflective legend and border Retroreflective legend and border .
Panel Overlay Attaching new panels to all or part of an existing panel. . Panel Replacement Removing the existing panel and attaching a new panel to the frame. . Sheeting Components All components and warranties will be compatible with substrate used by the Department Aluminum ASTM B H or T. . B .
Provide countdown pedestrian signal assembly with a gloss black colored polycarbonate housing and clear flat LED signal module .
C. LED pedestrian countdown module will not require special tools for installation and will fit into a inch x inch traffic signal housing . .
The module will be rated for use in the ambient operation temperature range of degrees F to degrees F and will be completely sealed against dust and moisture intrusion . .
The message will consist of a double overlay message combining the graphic symbols of a hand and walking man and two seven segment digits . .
The hand and man symbols will be no less than inches high . .
The countdown digits will be no less than inches high .
D. Terminal block will consist of dual wiring screw terminal and quick disconnect features for the neutral walk and dont walk phase .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January E. Use  inch wide by .
inch thick AISI type stainless steel pole mount bands. . Clamshell will be a twopart mounting assembly with stainless steel hinge pins on the polemounted half . .
The two halves will be secured together with a stainless steel flat head socket bolt requiring a inch Allen wrench . .
The assembly will be interchangeable left to right mount. . PEDESTRIAN PUSH BUTTON ASSEMBLY A .
Refer to SL Series Standard Drawings .
B. Pedestrian Push Button with LED Indicator .
Pedestrian button with standard bolt circle. . ADA compliant assembly with a inch diameter stainless steel actuator . .
Assembly with solid state electronic Piezo switch with no moving plunger or moving electrical contacts. . Enclose supporting circuitry within the button with wiring to the push button terminated on two screw terminals . .
Rain tight gasket to seal between the button assembly and the frame. . Button that gives indications to the user that a call has been made in both of the following forms a. Audible beep when button is pushed .
b .
Momentary LED light as the button is pushed or LED light that stays on for to seconds if the button is pushed and held closed or an LED light that stays on until the pedestrian signal phase is activated . .
Minimum year unlimited warranty .
C. Pedestrian Push Button Frame .
Provide cast aluminum frame powder coated black capable of supporting push button and a inch x inch sign with the following characteristics a. Frame attaches to the pole using two ANSI  x  inch hex head or Phillips brass bolts attached behind the sign .
b. Frame is additionally supported using adjustable staves .
c. Sign attaches above the button using ANSI stainless steel Allen head screws .
d. Cable guide extends through a  inch diameter mounting hole in the support pole to channel wiring to the button . .
Provide push button frame standoff brackets to mount two frames perpendicular on one pedestrian signal pole .
a .
A single piece solid aluminum or stainless steel bracket designed for various pole diameters .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January b .
No additional holes required for mounting .

PART EXECUTION .
QUALIFIED PERSONNEL A .
All electrical work must be supervised by a Master or Journeyman electrician .
All traffic signal work must be supervised on site or completed by IMSA level II certified personnel or Department approved equivalent . .
Provide at least one level II IMSA certified personnel on site .
With crews of five or more provide at least two level II IMSA certified personnel. . Failure to demonstrate compliance will result in a stop work order until current certifications can be met .
a .
Payment of items related to this section may be withheld for any work not meeting this requirement .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January .
The Department may declare the Contractor to be in default and terminate the contract if certifications can not be met within calendar days of issuance of a stop order .
a .
The prime Contractor is responsible for all incurred cost of the work performed by other forces .
B .
Contractors are not allowed to turn on a traffic signal. . Only personnel approved by the Department are permitted to turn on traffic signals . .
PREPARATION A .
Coordinate Department Furnished Materials .
Receive materials at the Departments Central Warehouse South West Salt Lake City UT .
Contact the warehouse by calling to schedule a pickup at least hours in advance . .
Receive drop shipment materials at the prearranged location. . Powder Coated Materials a .
Deliver Department furnished materials for powder coating from the Departments Central Warehouse to the powder coating facility .
b .
Deliver Department furnished materials from the powder coating facility to the project site .
c. Paint to match hardware attached to powder coated items such as signal pole caps bolts and hand hole covers .
d. Powder coat base plate adapters to match signal poles .
B .
Notify the Engineer and local traffic enforcement agencies at least working days before any operational change or shutdown of a traffic signal system .
C. Contact local power utility at least days before the connection date .
Verify the exact location voltage procedure and materials required by the local power utility . .
EXISTING FACILITIES A .
Maintain and work around existing traffic signal equipment until the new or modified traffic signal system has been installed and is operational when existing traffic signal installations are modified or completely rebuilt. . Use temporary signal head covers on signal heads and back plates that are not in operation. . Do not disconnect or remove an existing signal system until the replacement system is fully functioning .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January .
Replace an existing signal damaged during construction within hours .
B .
Obtain approval before removal of operating detection equipment . .
Notify Engineer at least hours before removal . .
Engineer may enforce liquidated damages if system is taken out of service without approval .
C. Remove and replace the entire concrete slab to the nearest joints if a portion of a slab is broken or damaged during construction .
D. A uniformed police officer must be onsite during a signal change over. . UTILITY CONFLICTS AND OBSTRUCTIONS A .
Modify proposed equipment locations to avoid conflict with underground utilities or other obstructions as required . .
Obtain approval from the Engineer before modifying locations .
B .
Coordinate with the Engineer to fieldlocate new facilities such as cabinet foundations camera poles detector poles and junction boxes .
C. Field locate equipment with the Engineer .
Avoid areas with poor drainage or high potential impact from thrown snow. . Place for maximum accessibility and safety for maintenance personnel and vehicles including a bucket truck . .
Satisfy clear zone requirements as defined in the AASHTO Roadside Design Guide .
Verify right of way limits are not exceeded . .
Satisfy requirements of applicable UDOT Standard Drawings. . EXCAVATION A .
Move the excavated material to a location that will minimize obstructions to pedestrian or vehicular traffic and will not interfere with surface drainage .
B .
Protect pedestrian and vehicular traffic from excavation .
C. Remove and properly dispose of surplus excavated material within hours .
D. Do not backfill conduit trenches until inspected by the Engineer .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January .
TEMPORARY SIGNALS A .
Maintain at least two signal heads for the primary movement at a signalized intersection on all approaches .
B .
Temporary equipment must meet current specifications unless approved by the Engineer . .
TEMPORARY POWER A .
Generators used to provide power to a traffic signal must be equipped with an inverter. . FACILITIES TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE A .
Existing conduits remain in place .
B .
Remove conductors taken out of service. . Cut conductors wires and cables at the end of the conduit if they can not be removed due to conduit damage . .
REMOVE AND SALVAGE EXISTING EQUIPMENT A .
Existing traffic signal equipment remains the property of the Department .
B. Verify that the Salvage Existing Equipment Checklist has been placed in the signal cabinet by the Department signal crew before construction .
C. Replace in kind equipment damaged during the removal or transport process .
Equipment will be returned within hours of removal to the region signal office .
D. Remove foundations to a depth of at least inches below the existing surface .
E. Remove and properly dispose of abandoned junction boxes .
F. Backfill holes with local material compact to the density of the surrounding area and cap with surrounding material. . Cap with concrete at least inch thick and finish to match surrounding grade if located in pavement. . CONSTRUCT POLE FOUNDATION A .
Refer to SL Series Standard Drawings .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January B .
Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire .
Refer to Section C. Do not weld reinforcing steel anchor bolts or conduit. . Use tie wire to secure conduit. . Use template to align and secure drop in anchors .
D. Do not mount steel on foundations until they have been placed for at least days or attained percent of the specified day compressive strength based upon field cured cylinders .
E. Place and hold anchor bolts in proper alignment position and height before and during concrete placing and vibrating .
F. Install anchor bolts according to the AASHTO Standard Specifications for Structural Supports for Highway Signs Luminaires and Traffic Signals Article .. . Retighten all nuts after the structure is fully loaded . .
CABINET BASE AND CABINET INSTALLATION A .
Refer to SL Series Standard Drawings. . SIGNAL POLE AND MAST ARM PLACEMENT A .
Install signal pole to be plumb after mast arm is attached. . Rake pole to level mast arm. . Do not rake the signal pole to increase signal head clearance .
B .
Tighten anchor bolt nuts on signal poles to snug tight plus  turn .
C. Tighten anchor bolt nuts as shown on SL Series Standard Drawings for poles with breakaway slip base systems .
D. Field assemble multisection mast arm slip joints to achieve a snug fit . .
Apply antiseize compound and provide overlap not less than  times inside diameter of end section. . DIRECTIONAL BORING AND TRENCHING FOR CONDUIT A. Directional Boring .
Use directional boring for conduit installation on roadway crossings unless otherwise approved .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January B. Trenching Paved Surface .
Do not trench through paved surface without approval from the Engineer . .
Maximum trench width inches. . Use flowable fill to bottom of pavement or to within inches of the roadway surface when pavement is less than inches thick . .
Apply tack coat evenly before final backfill when surface is asphalt . .
Match the composition density and elevation inch of the existing pavement section .
C. Trenching Unpaved Surface .
Use backfill that matches the composition density and elevation of the existing surface . .
Install conduits that pass under finished curbs and gutters sidewalks concrete flatwork textured or decorative surfaces by jacking drilling or pushing .
D. Minimum Conduit Cover .
Refer to SL Series Standard Drawings . .
INSTALL CONDUIT A .
Place all conduits in the same trench before surfacing .
B .
Use PVC or HDPE conduit underground as shown .
C. Seal uncapped conduit ends inside junction box with at least inches of duct seal .
D. Do not use a torch for bending or shaping PVC conduit. . Use equipment specifically designed to heat PVC conduit to shape required curves or radii .
E. Do not exceed degrees of conduit sweeps between junction boxes . .
INSTALL JUNCTION BOX A .
Refer to SL Series Standard Drawings .
B .
Provide at least inch spacing between adjacent junction boxes .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January .
INSTALL WIRING A. Conductors .
Clean and dry the inside of the conduit before installing conductors and cables . .
Install grounding conductor in circuit conduits with V or higher voltage. . Use approved lubricants when pulling conductors and cables in conduit . .
Pull conductors and cables with pull tape . .
Tape the ends of unused conductors and label them as spares. . Land wires according to SL Series Standard Drawings .
B .
Bonding Conductor Ground .
Size bonding wire according to NEC article minimum AWG solid insulated .
a .
Run continuously and bond to each metal signal pole or luminaire pole . .
Bond the grounding system conductor to the ground rod in each junction box except in circuits with less than V. . A concrete encased electrode may be used according to NEC in signal pole foundations as an alternative to a ground rod in case of excessive rocky soil conditions if approved by the Engineer .
a .
Do not place the concrete until Department conducts a pre pour inspection of the electrode .
C. Arrange the wiring neatly within enclosures such as cabinets junction boxes and fixtures . .
Provide at least ft of slack cable for all cables at every junction box that cable passes through . .
Provide at least ft of slack cable at the nearest junction box for cables connecting to pedestrian signal poles .
D. Terminate terminal connections with a mechanical spade connector .
E. Provide a separate conductor cable for signal heads that control a dedicated turn phase .
F. NEC requires no more than percent of conduit be filled with cables .
In cases where more cable is required conduit size or quantity may be increased for that specific crossing .
Implementation Traffic Signal Page of January G. Mark cabinet cables with colored vinyl electrical tape as specified in Table .

B .

C. Initiate other nonemergency repairs within hours of notice . .

DEFINITIONS A. Snug Tight The tightness that is attained with a few impacts of an impact wrench or the full effort of an ironworker using an ordinary spud wrench to bring the plies into firm contact. . SUBMITTALS A .

FABRICATION A. Fabricate according to UDOT Steel and Concrete Construction Manual and AWS D .. .
Refer to Section for shop inspection requirements .
B .
The fabricator must be an AISC Bridge Component QMS CPT Certification .
C. Welding .
Onetime repair by welding of deficient weld is allowed without written authorization from the Engineer. . Longitudinal seam welds a .
Use fullpenetration groove welds for post and mast arm sections .
b .
For full span type structures locate the seam weld for the mast arm in the lower quadrant of the mast arm compression side under dead load .
c. For cantilever type structures locate the seam weld for the mast arm in the upper quadrant of the mast arm compression side under dead load .
d. For posts locate the seam weld on the same side as the mast arm compression side under dead load .
Implementation Overhead SignVMS Structure Page of January D. Perform Charpy VNotch tests for all main load carrying tension members with a  inch steel thickness or greater .
Test results must meet requirements for Zone .
Refer to ASTM A . .
This includes post mast arm base plate splice plates sign brackets and HSS tube sections .
E. Drill or punch bolt holes and slots to finished size. . Do not use flame cutting on bolt holes. . Slotted holes can be thermally cut by plasma laser or oxygen acetylene methods .
Grind hardened thermally cut edge to a maximum surface roughness of microinch and the conical taper of the hole must be maintained within tolerance .
F. Provide hand holes for the overhead pipe frame as shown .
G. Locate inserts at the bottom of the mast arm .
Weld  inch diameter insert in each hole .
Thread inserts before galvanizing and provide galvanized or brass plugs .
H. Use ultrasonic testing on the post to base plate welds shop splice welds and field splice welds in post and mast arm . .
Acceptance criteria according to AWS D. Table .
connections in tension .
I. Verify fit up of the structure by assembling the structure in the shop .
J .
Paint base plates posts mast arms splice plates and associated hardware when shown . .
Paint splice plates and base pates after installation of bolt assemblies .
a. Primer coat of paint can be applied to all areas before installation .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Verify the roadway crosssection information sign dimensions foundation location and clearances shown before fabrication .
B .
Field verify the post height and length of mast arm based on the asbuilt foundation field survey .
Implementation Overhead SignVMS Structure Page of January .
ERECTION A .
Do not weld cut or drill in the field .
B .
Meet vertical clearance requirements during construction .
C. Temporarily support anchor and brace posts and mast arms during erection to produce the proper alignment and camber in the completed structure .
D. Establish proper elevation and orientation of signs VMS panels posts and mast arms .
E. Rake post as necessary during sign erection using leveling nuts to level the sign panels . .
Create a snug tight condition by wrench tightening both top and bottom anchor bolt nuts against the base plate until full contact is made at final position . .
Tighten top nuts onesixth turn past snug tight and retighten nuts below the base plate to maintain full contact with the base plate . .
Fill out Anchor Bolt Certification form in the presence of the Inspector during bolt installation .
F. Install high strength bolts according to Section High Strength Bolt Installation unless noted otherwise . .
Install to snug tight when shown . .
Fill out Bolted Field Splice Certification and Bolted Sign Frame Connection Certification in the presence of the Inspector while the bolts are being placed .
a .
Provide necessary equipment and access to allow Inspector access to the connection .
G. Fill the void between the base plate and top of foundation with nonshrink grout after completing the sign erection .
H. Cover signs that require temporary covering with an opaque nonpaper material . .
Secure cover at the rear of the sign so that the sign is not damaged and the covering remains secure during inclement weather . .
Maintain covering until removed .
I .
Do not allow traffic under a partially erected signVMS structure .
Implementation Overhead SignVMS Structure Page of January J .
Use two coats of a zincrich paint to touch up minor damage to galvanization that occurs during transportation and erection of galvanized members. . Feather back damaged areas to form a smooth transition before applying the zincrich paint according to ASTM A . K. Touch up minor paint damage to painted members that occurs during transportation and erection according to Section . .
LIMITATIONS A .
Do not open traffic under the following conditions .
Information contained on a removed sign is not being provided by a new or temporary sign .
Information on the new sign conflicts with an existing sign .
New sign conflicts with the current striping .
New sign obstructs an old sign that contains required information END OF SECTION Bolted Field Splice Certification Anchor Bolts Certification and Bolted Sign Frame Connection Certification forms follow Implementation Overhead SignVMS Structure Page of January Bolted Field Splice Certification Consecutively number splices looking ahead on station and increasing from left to right .

DRILLING EQUIPMENT A .
Capable of .
Drilling holes to the required diameter location alignment and depth in the type of materials present at the shaft locations . .
Installing and removing casing. . FREE DRAINING GRANULAR BACKFILL A .
Refer to Section .
PART EXECUTION .
DRILLING A .
Drilling Holes .
Drill straight vertical holes to the depth shown or as directed by the Engineer . .
Drill holes within inches of plan position . .
Remove all loose material from the bottom of the drilled holes before placing the shaft. . Do not use water or slurry for drilling operations .
B. Casing .
Furnish and place casing when required to prevent the drilled hole from caving and any time groundwater is encountered . .
Remove casing during or after the backfill is placed .
C. Uncased Holes .
Drill uncased dry noncaving holes in a continuous operation .
D. Obtain Engineers approval to place shaft under water. . SHAFT INSTALLATION A .
Place and compact free draining granular backfill in the bottom of the drilled hole to the proper elevation before placing the shaft .
B .
Place free draining granular backfill up to the top of the shaft . .
Compact by hand using a maximum of inch lifts .

DEFINITIONS A .
Hydraulic Erosion Control Products HECP Biodegradable manufactured thermally processed natural or reinforced interlocking fibers and premixed with a tackifier. . Mixed with water and hydraulically applied as a slurry on recently constructed areas. . SUBMITTALS A .

WATER A .
Free of dirt silt and other detrimental matter. . TACKIFIER A .
General .
Free from growth or germination inhibiting factors. . Nonflammable .
Nontoxic to aquatic organisms. . Functional for a minimum of days .
B. Guarbased tackifier .
Derived from ground endosperm of guar seeds Cyamopsis tetragonolobus and treated with dispersant agents . .
Apply at a rate of lbs per acre .
C. Psylliumbased tackifier .
Manufactured from the finely ground muciloid coating of Plantago ovata or Plantago ispaghula seeds. . Will hydrate when mixed with water to form a slurry and produces a firm resilient and rewettable membrane on the soil surface after application . .
Apply at a rate of lb per acre .
D. Starchbased tackifier .
Typically derived from corn or potatoes in a nonionic coldwater soluble pregelatinized granular form . .
Apply at a rate of lbacre .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Complete required grading topsoil placement and seeding in designated areas before applying HECP .
B .
Apply HECP within hours after seeding .
C. Provide sufficient time for HECP to cure according to manufacturers recommendation before precipitations falls .
Implementation Hydraulic Erosion Control Products Page of January .
HECP APPLICATION A .
Use HECP components prepacked by the manufacturer. . Do not field mix materials unless using a HECP Type product that does not include a premixed tackifier into manufacturer package .
B .
Mix water and HECP according to the manufacturers recommendation .
C. Apply HECP at the rates in Table unless otherwise specified .
Table HECP Application Rates HECP Type Minimum Rates lbs per acre Type Type Type D. Apply a uniform layer of HECP slurry to targeted areas from both the top and bottom of the slope to meet manufacturers recommendation for installed thickness and ground coverage . .
Remove overspray before the HECP slurry dries .

SOURCE QUALITY CONTROL CONTRACTOR FURNISHED MATERIAL A .
Obtaining Soil Samples .
Obtain soil samples while the Engineer is present .
Provide no less than  lb per soil sample . .
Obtain samples from a thin slice of soil cut from the side of a freshly dug hole or by using a soil auger or sampling tube . .
Mix the several small samples taken from various places around the source together to produce a composite sample. . More than one composite sample may be required if the topsoil horizon changes significantly across the source. . Store samples in a clean container at room temperature and out of direct sunlight. . Label the location and date on each sample container . .
Provide additional soil samples for verification if requested by the Engineer .

GENERAL REQUIREMENTS A .

B .

paragraph D. C. Provide a suitable topsoil surface just before seeding on the remaining top soiled areas not covered under this article paragraph B .
Suitable topsoil surface is .
Noncompacted and finished according to this Section Article .. . Weed free . .
Finish grade uniform surface with smooth transitions between grade changes and disturbed areas .
D. Do not strip or handle wet topsoil .
E. Establish finish grade at inch below the top of all walks curbs mow strips and other hard surfaces for areas receiving seed or turf seed and  inch for areas receiving turf sod . .
STRIP AND STOCKPILE TOPSOIL A .
Strip the topsoil .
Only from areas shown or determined by Engineer. . To a depth determined by the Engineer .
B .
Remove and dispose of any roots larger than inches in diameter or inches in length .
C. Stockpile stripped topsoil .
At locations acceptable to the Engineer . .
So that placement or activity around the stockpile does not damage or impact any existing trees shrubs or environmentally sensitive areas .
Obtain appropriate clearances if such impacts are unavoidable .
D. Grade to minimize erosion on and around the stockpiles .
Implementation Topsoil Page of January .
SPREAD STOCKPILED AND CONTRACTORFURNISHED TOPSOIL A .
Clear area to receive topsoil of all trash debris weeds and rock inches or larger and dispose of objectionable material in an approved manner .
B .
Place and spread the stockpiled topsoil over the prepared slopes to the plan depths .
Use inches if no depth is indicated in the plans .
C. Disc or harrow the placed topsoil along the contour on slopes and flatter or cattrack the slopes to create continuous cleat tracks that run parallel with the contours .
D. Cattrack slopes steeper than to create continuous cleat tracks that run parallel with the contours .

B. Seeding Window .

A late winter exception to the seeding window may be obtained from the Engineer if suitable weather and soil conditions exist .

PART PRODUCTS .
SEED AND TURF SEED A .
Meet the Utah Seed Law Utah Code Title Chapter .
B .
Supply seed on a pure live seed PLS basis .
C. Obtain seed from lots that have been tested by a state certified seed testing laboratory such as Association of Seed Analyst AOSA or Society of Commercial Seed Technologists SCST . .
Seed germination test older than months for grass seed and months for shrub or tree seed are not acceptable. . Based on the amount or type of seed required on a project the Department may require additional testing by the Department of Agriculture .
D. Do not use wet moldy or otherwise damaged seed .
E. Seed Substitutions .
Contact the major seed brokers in the state to verify that the seed is unavailable before requesting a seed substitution . .
Obtain approval for a seed substitution . .
TURF SOD A .
Healthy and wellrooted nursery grown Kentucky Blue Grass sod comprised of a minimum of three varieties and free of weeds .
Implementation Seed Turf Seed And Turf Sod Page of January B .
Machine cut in straight uniform strips or rolls cut at a depth between  inch and inch . .
FERTILIZER turf sod and turf seed areas only A .
Uniform in composition dry and free flowing . .
Turf seed or turf sod Elemental nitrogen in granular form .
Phosphorus and potassium are optional and may be applied with nitrogen in granules .
Use a slow release form of a minimum percent nitrogen such as sulfur coated urea or urea formaldehyde . .
Apply elemental nitrogen with a concentration ranging from percent if hydroseeding method is used .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Complete all final grading irrigation work trench settling topsoil placement and surface preparation before seed or sod application .
B .
Prepare general seedbed for all seeded and sodded areas. . Verify that a suitable topsoil surface has been prepared according to Section before seeding. . Do not work topsoil or seed when the soil is saturated or frozen .
C. Prepare Turf Seedbed .
Review finish grade to confirm that topsoil is inch below the top of all walks curbs mow strips and other hard surfaces . .
Apply fertilizer at the rate of lb yd and mix thoroughly into upper inches of topsoil. . Do not apply fertilizer and seed at the same time in the same machine .
D. Prepare Turf Sod Surface .
Review finish grade to confirm that topsoil is  inch blow the top of all walks curbs mow strips and other hard surfaces . .
Apply fertilizer at the rate of lb yd and mix thoroughly into upper inches of topsoil. . Level and roll prepared areas using a gal waterfilled hand roller containing to gal of water. . Lightly rake and dampen with water the top  to  inches of soil just before laying the sod .
Implementation Seed Turf Seed And Turf Sod Page of January .
SEEDING GENERAL A .
Notify the Engineer seven working days before seeding .
B .
Apply seed at the rate indicated in the Seed Schedule as shown .
Note that drill seed and broadcast seed are applied at different rates . .
DRILL SEEDING METHOD A .
Use the drill method of seeding on accessible slopes and flatter .
B .
Use a drill equipped with the following .
Depth band .
Seed box agitator .
Seed metering device .
Furrow opener .
Packer wheels or drag chains C. Use the drill manufacturers directions in the presence of the Engineer .
Calibrate the drill to apply seed at the rate indicated in the seeding schedule .
D. Space drill rows a minimum of inches and a maximum of inches .
E. Fill the seed boxes no more than half full when drilling on a slope .
F. Set depth bands to drill seeds to a  inch depth .
G. Drill along the contour .
H. Maintain the drill at the calibrated setting throughout the seeding operation .
I .
Allow the furrows that are created by the drill to remain. . BROADCAST SEEDING METHOD A .
Use the broadcast method of seeding under the following conditions .
Slopes steeper than . .
Slopes and flatter where the area to be seeded is inaccessible to drill . .
The area to be seeded is not large enough to justify using a drill. . Rocky surface conditions will damage a drill .
Implementation Seed Turf Seed And Turf Sod Page of January B .
Obtain approval of the broadcast method by demonstrating the procedure on a yd area .
C. Evenly broadcast seed using either .
A cyclone seeder or other approved mechanical seeder. . A hydroseeder .
a Apply seed water and lb of cellulose fiber mulch tracer per acre .
D. Do not seed during windy weather or when soil is saturated .
E. Incorporate the seed into the soil by one of three methods .
Cattracking by running the dozer up and down the slope creating continuous cleat tracks that run parallel with the contours. . Hand raking the seed in  inch deep and along the contours of the slope. . Slope chaining by pulling the chain along the contour until the seed is covered .
F. Obtain approval from the Engineer that the seed has been adequately incorporated into the soil before applying wood fiber mulch erosion control blanket flexible growth medium flexible channel liner or other topdressing . .
TURF SEEDING A .
Apply turf seed after seedbed preparation .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph C. B .
Roll seeded areas using a hand roller half filled with water .
C. Lightly water and program the irrigation system to maintain a moist seedbed .
D. Rope off newly seeded areas along walkways using bright plastic ribbon tape attached to stakes . .
TURF SOD PLACEMENT A .
Prepare sod bed and place sod with all edges and joints tightly butted. . Do not stretch or overlap sod. . Keep length seams in a straight line .
B .
Lay turf sod with staggered joints and trim off excess material along the edges .
Implementation Seed Turf Seed And Turf Sod Page of January C. Roll sod immediately after placing using a hand roller half filled with water. . Reroll if depressions still remain . .
Thoroughly water with a fine spray to a depth sufficient that the underside of the new sod and soil immediately below the sod are thoroughly wet .

SCHEDULE A .
Install poles and cuttings in the fall after October and before the ground becomes frozen or in the spring after the ground thaws and before April .
PART PRODUCTS .
POLES AND CUTTINGS A .
Collect poles and cuttings from live native stands of the species listed from October to February .
B .
Obtain poles and cuttings from live trees and shrubs that will be destroyed due to highway construction from areas adjacent to the project or from locations that are ecologically matched in climate and elevation .
C. Obtain necessary permits from appropriate regulatory agency or permission from landowner before collecting poles and cuttings outside the rightofway .
D. Prune branches using current standards from the International Society of Arboriculture when collecting poles and cuttings from trees or shrubs that will remain .
Implementation Pole PlantingsWillow Cuttings Page of January E. Remove no more than  of the branches from any tree or shrub when obtaining poles and cuttings from vegetation that will remain within the rightofway .
F. Supply poles and cuttings that meet the following size constraints .
Pole Cut branches at a degree angle ft long and to inches in diameter from one to threeyearold growth. . Willow Cutting Cut stems at a degree angle ft long and  to  inch in diameter from one to twoyearold growth .
PART EXECUTION .
STORE A .
Store dormant poles and cuttings acquired but not planted in the fall until the ground thaws .
B .
Store in plastic bags at temperatures between degrees F to degrees F or outside in snowfilled plastic bags .
C. Do not allow the poles or cuttings to dry out or break bud while being stored . .
INSTALL A .
Stake poles and cuttings at plan locations for approval or as directed .
B .
Create a hole deep enough to accommodate percent of the length of the pole or cutting using an auger or water stinger .
C. Remove inch from the basal end of the pole or cutting just before planting .
D. Place one pole or one cutting in the hole basal end first .
E. Backfill and compact around the pole or cutting to eliminate air pockets .
F. Water the pole or cutting and add more backfill if settling occurs .

DELIVERY STORAGE AND HANDLING A .

B .

C. Notify the Engineer at least calendar days before delivering the plants to the site .
D. Deliver plant materials to the work site in covered vehicles just before placement .
E. Maintain delivered plants in a healthy condition . .

Install irrigated plants using the following schedule Elevation Planting Season Below ft March December to ft April October Above ft May July No planting in July or August .
B .

PART PRODUCTS .
PLANTS A .
Supply healthy plants of the species and size specified true to form free from disfiguring knots sunscald frost cracks bark abrasions and all forms of infestation and disease .
B .
Provide legible labels attached to all plants flats bundles or other containers indicating botanical genus species and size .
Implementation Trees Shrubs and Groundcovers Page of January C. Supply trees with straight central leaders capable of standing upright without the support of stakes or guys .
D. Supply containerized plants with root systems fully established in the container .
E. Do not use balled and burlapped plants if the ball of earth surrounding roots has been cracked or broken or if the burlap is not secure .
F. Use bareroot plant material only with approval .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Verify that the area prepared to receive plants is graded properly according to the plan all work is completed in the area and that topsoil has been placed .
Refer to Section .
B .
Install the irrigation system and have it fully operational before installing plants .
C. Stake or delineate plant locations for approval before installation . .
INSTALLATION A .
General .
Install plants using the plan details. . Water the plants within one hour of installation to saturate the rootball to a minimum of inches below and around the plant hole .
a .
Add more backfill if settling occurs .
B. Containerized Plants .
Excavate plant holes to twice the diameter and the same depth of the rootball . .
Carefully remove the plant from its container scarify the sides and bottom of the rootball if needed and place it in the prepared hole. . Place excavated soil in inch lifts around the rootball and eliminate voids by tamping the soil between each lift .
C. Balled and Burlapped Plants .
Excavate plant holes to twice the diameter and the same depth of the rootball. . Gently place the plant in the prepared hole with burlap securely intact .
Implementation Trees Shrubs and Groundcovers Page of January .
Do not mishandle or break root balls . .
Carefully remove any wire baskets and the top half of the burlap without disturbing the root ball .
D. Tubeling Plants .
Auger a hole the same size as the tube. . Gently place watered tubeling in the prepared plant pit immediately following excavation of the hole so that the roots are not tangled compacted or curled up at the ends. . Compress the soil at the base of the tubeling to eliminate voids between the rootball and existing soil. . CLEAN AND MAINTAIN A .
Remove foreign materials from site such as containers burlap and twine collected during installation .
B .
Remove any tags labels or other items attached to the plant material after final plant inspection .
C. Water and maintain the plants in a healthy condition until the final plant inspection .

PART PRODUCTS .
DISINFECTANT A. Chlorine based Implementation Tree Pruning Page of January PART EXECUTION .
TREE PRUNING A .
Conform to ANSI Z . and Current Standards for Pruning International Society of Arboriculture ISA .
B .
Remove tree branches extending over the roadway to provide a clear height of ft above the paved surface and ft above sidewalks .
C. Spray pruning equipment with disinfectant after coming in contact with diseased plant material .
D. Use the Natural Target or Drop Crotch pruning method when removing limbs .
E. Do not top pollard stub or dehorn any tree .
F. Make all pruning cuts sufficiently close to the trunk or parent limbs without cutting into or removing the branch collar or the branch bark ridge .
G. Prune trees to make them shapely symmetrical and typical of the natural form of the species being pruned .
H. Do not remove branches that will deform the appearance of the tree . .
BRANCH DISPOSAL A. Shred removed branches into wood chips inches or smaller .
B .
Remove all wood chips larger than inches .
C. Broadcast shredded branches as determined by the Engineer over and around the site where trees are being pruned or removed and where placement will not be detrimental to vegetation growth .

Implementation Rotomilling Page of January PART EXECUTION .
PROCEDURE A .
The Engineer .
Measures and records rotomilling depths taking two random measurements every ft of each pass of the milling machine. . May require an adjustment to the depth of the milling operation within tolerances to remove unacceptable material or to improve ride .
B. Rotomill existing bituminous pavement surface to the width and depth shown not to exceed an additional  inch of plan depth measured from original surface to the top of the ridge .
C. Load the reclaimed material from milling operation into a truck in one operation .
Milled material is the property of the Contractor unless specified otherwise. . CLEAN AND REPAIR A .
Remove and clean all millings from the surface daily .
Control dust created by the cutting action .
Clean rotomilled surface after milling operation and before opening to traffic .
B Verify all milled surfaces are sturdy and sound . .
Remove any material that is loose or not well bonded .
C. Dispose of the milled material END OF SECTION Implementation Profile Rotomilling Page of January SECTION PROFILE ROTOMILLING PART GENERAL .

Procedure for grinding existing concrete pavements. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Pavement Smoothness .
REFERENCES Not Used .
DEFINITIONS Not Used .
SUBMITTALS A. Profilograph information as required for smoothness testing .
Refer to Section .
PART PRODUCTS .
EQUIPMENT A .
Provide and operate equipment utilizing diamond blades mounted on a self propelled machine designed for grinding and texturing pavement .
B .
Do not use equipment that causes damage to the transverse or longitudinal joints .
C. Use vacuuming equipment to remove residue and excess water .
PART EXECUTION .
GRIND A .
Grind until the surface of both sides of the transverse joints and cracks are in the same plane and meet the required smoothness .
B .
Provide a uniform finished texture .
Implementation Grinding Pavement of January C. Perform grinding in a longitudinal direction .
Begin and end grinding at lines normal to the pavement centerline .
D. Do not cause damage to the underlying surface of the pavement .
E. Provide resultant surface in a parallel corrugated type texture consisting of grooves between .
and .
inches wide .
Create a distance between the grooves of between .
and .
inches .
Make peaks of the ridges approximately inch higher than the bottom of the grooves .
Maintain cross slope drainage .
F. Provide uniform transverse slope of the pavement with no depressions or misalignment of slope greater than  inch in ft when tested with a ft straightedge .
G. Do not grind structures .
H. All residue from the grinding process becomes property and responsibility of the Contractor. . SMOOTHNESS TESTS A .
Refer to Section .

EQUIPMENT A .
Provide and operate equipment utilizing diamond blades mounted on a selfpropelled machine designed for grinding and texturing pavement .
B .
Do not use equipment that causes damage to the transverse or longitudinal joints .
C. Use vacuuming equipment to remove residue and excess water .
PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL REQUIREMENTS A .
Provide a uniform finished texture .
B .
Limit transverse and longitudinal deviations to less than  inch from the lower edge of a foot straightedge after grinding for all locations .
Implementation Bridge Concrete Grinding Page of January C. Perform grinding in a longitudinal direction . .
Begin and end grinding at lines normal to the bridge centerline .
D. Protect expansion joints during grinding operations .
E. Create a surface in a parallel corduroytype texture consisting of grooves between and  inches wide .
Use a distance between the grooves of between and  inches. . Limit height of ridges to inch .
F. Maintain cross slope drainage .
G. Tailings from the grinding process become the property and responsibility of the Contractor. . GRINDING PRECAST DECKS AND APPROACH SLABS A .
Grind surfaces of concrete bridge decks and approach slabs until both sides of joints are in the same plane and the entire surface including the sleeper slab to roadway interface meets the requirement of this Section .B . .
Cure shear stud blockout locations for hours before grinding. . Limit grinding to a depth of no more than  inch. . GRINDING EXISTING DECK SURFACES A .
Grind surfaces as shown .
B. Verify concrete cover to reinforcing steel by ferroscanning or an equivalent method before grinding . .
Notify the Engineer if concrete cover is less than inch or that shown. . Do not damage existing rebar .

DEFINITIONS A .
Cold Weather Protection Period The required time during which the concrete is maintained at or above a specific temperature to prevent freezing of the concrete and to ensure the necessary strength development for structural safety. . SUBMITTALS A .
Mix design for all A and AA concrete classes to be used for approval . .
The Department approves concrete mix designs based on trial batch test results or on Department project history . .

The proposed mix design .
b .
Target slump value .
c. Trial batch test results .
d. Test results verifying that coarse and fine aggregates meet this Section Article .
paragraph B. e. Test results for the proposed mix design for potential reactivity of coarse and fine aggregates according to UDOT Quality Management Plan ReadyMix Concrete .
f. Test results demonstrating the ability of the combinations of cementitious materials and aggregates to control the reactivity when using potentially reactive aggregates in a mix design .
g. Written plan for admixtures .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph D. Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January h. Wellgraded combined aggregate gradation for the mix design when used .

ACCEPTANCE A .

Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January B .
The Department may accept the item at a reduced price when concrete is below specified strength and does not have a separate strength pay factor . .
The pay factor will be applied to the quantity of the pay item that is represented by the strength tests that fall below a specified strength. . Department will calculate the pay factor using Table based on day compressive strength .

The Department applies a . pay factor if a reject lot is allowed to remain inplace .

MIX DESIGN A .
Design mixes to meet the requirements of this Section and project specific criteria .
B .
The Contractor assumes responsibility for the compatibility of admixtures with the mix design and their potential effects on concrete properties .
C. Design the cementitious system to mitigate potential alkaliaggregate reactivity. . Use at least percent pozzolan by weight of the total cementitious system .
D. Obtain approval from the Engineer for the project specific application of an approved mix design. . TRIAL BATCHES A .
Use the same components in the trial batches that will be used in the project. . Accelerators and siteadded airentrainment can be incorporated in the trial batch but are not required .
B .
Use Department certified TTQP Concrete and Concrete Strength Testing personnel to perform trial batches and strength tests .
C. The Department or its certified representative may witness the trial batch .
D. Mix concrete trial batches according to the UDOT Materials Manual of Instruction Guidelines for Portland Cement Concrete Mix Design Trail Batches .
E. Use a Department qualified laboratory to verify trial batch compressive and flexural strength testing . .
AGGREGATE STOCKPILES A. Construct stockpile platforms so that subgrades are prevented from intruding into aggregates .
B .
Build stockpiles at least two days before use .
C. Provide an operator and frontend loader to help the Engineer take aggregate samples .
Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January D. Provide separate stockpiles for coarse and fine aggregates .
E. Construct stockpiles to minimize segregation of aggregates F. Allow washed aggregates to drain to uniform moisture content before use hours minimum. . BATCH MATERIALS A. Batch Tolerances .
