PART EXECUTION .
LIMITATIONS A .
Timing Deliver place and consolidate concrete as follows unless otherwise specified .
Within minutes of batching when the air temperature is below degrees F. .
Within minutes of batching when the air temperature is between and degrees F. .
Within minutes of batching when the air temperature is above degrees F. B .
Concrete Temperature Place concrete when the concrete temperature is between and degrees F unless otherwise specified .
C. Pumping and Conveying Equipment .
Do not use equipment or a combination of equipment and the configuration of that equipment that causes a loss of entrained air content that exceeds  of the range of air content allowed by specification . .
Contractor is responsible to verify and monitor air loss . .
Replace reconfigure or repair equipment that does not meet the requirements of this Section Article .
paragraph C Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January D. Cold Weather Comply with the following when placing finishing curing and protecting concrete exposed to cold weather during the protection period .
Cold weather applies when the temperature is forecast to fall below degrees F during the protection period . .
Provide necessary cold weather protection for placing finishing curing and protecting inplace concrete such as covers insulation and heat .
a .
Follow the authorized Cold Weather Concreting Plan when placing castinplace concrete .
b .
Follow the prequalified suppliers approved Quality Control Plan when fabricating precast concrete members . .
Concrete materials a .
Do not use chemical antifreeze additives in the concrete .
This does not apply to normal accelerators .
Refer to AASHTO M . b .
Remove and replace concrete damaged by frost action at no additional cost to the Department .
c. Do not use material containing frost or lumps . .
Determine the concrete compressive strength by one of the following methods a .
Field cured cylinders cured and protected the same as the concrete being protected .
b .
Maturity method .
Refer to AASHTO T . .
Maintain the temperature of the concrete at or above degrees F during and after placement until the end of the protection period .
a .
Measure the specified concrete temperature at the concrete surface .
Use surface thermometers insulated from the surrounding air . .
Placing concrete a .
Do not place concrete during adverse weather including rain snow and high winds without adequate protection approved by the Engineer .
b .
Do not proceed with the placement of concrete if the temperature of all contact surfaces including reinforcement is less than degrees F or greater than degrees F. c. Cease placement operations when the ambient temperature is degrees F and decreasing unless adequate precautions are taken according to the approved Cold Weather Concreting Plan. . Protection of inplace concrete a .
Maintain the concrete above degrees F during placement and until the end of the protection period .
The protection period is the time required for the concrete to reach a compressive strength of at least psi .
Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January Extend the duration of the protection period at least hr beyond the termination of the cure before exposing the concrete to freezing temperatures when curing by the water method .
Refer to Section .
b .
Comply with the following when heating is required .
Adequately vent combustiontype heaters that produce carbon monoxide .
Position heaters and ducts so the hot dry air does not cause areas of the concrete surface to overheat or dry .
Keep concrete surfaces moist to avoid excessive loss of moisture from the concrete when applying external heat . .
Termination of protection a .
Limit the drop in temperature of concrete surfaces to degrees F during any hour period when removing cold weather protection until the surface temperature of the concrete reaches that of the ambient air temperature .
E. Hot Weather Comply with the following when placing finishing curing and protecting concrete exposed to hot weather during the protection period . .
Hot weather limitations apply at any time of the year when a combination of high ambient temperature high concrete temperature low relative humidity and high wind speed have the potential to impair the quality of freshly mixed or hardened concrete by accelerating the rate of moisture loss and the rate of cement hydration or otherwise causes detrimental results. . Monitor site conditions including air temperature relative humidity and wind speed to assess the need for evaporation control measures .
a .
Begin monitoring no later than hour before beginning concrete placing operations .
b .
Continue to monitor site conditions at intervals of minutes or less until required curing procedures are applied . .
Provide necessary hot weather protection .
a .
Follow the approved Hot Weather Concreting Plan when placing castinplace concrete .
b .
Follow the prequalified suppliers approved Quality Control Plan when fabricating precast concrete members .
Implementation Portland Cement Concrete Page of January c. Initiate evaporation control measures when concrete and air temperatures relative humidity of the air and wind speed have the capacity to evaporate free water from the fresh concrete surface at a rate equal to or greater than .
lbfthr .
Determine the evaporation rate of surface moisture using the NRMCA Nomograph in Appendix B of ACI .. .
Cool all surfaces that will come in contact with the concrete to below degrees F . CYLINDER STORAGE DEVICE A .
Provide and maintain cylinder storage device . .
Maintain cylinders at a temperature range of degrees F to degrees F for the initial hour curing period. . Do not move the cylinders during this period. . Equip the storage device with an automatic hour temperature recorder that continuously records on a timetemperature chart with an accuracy of degree F. . Have the storage device available at the point of placement at least hours before placement. . Stop placement of concrete if the storage device is not provided or can not accommodate the required number of test cylinders .
Cylinder strength results may not be disputed if storage devices are not provided. . Use water containing hydrated lime if water is to be in contact with cylinders . .
The Engineer may require a hour test run to determine the storage device capability to maintain and record temperature .

UDOT Quality Management Plans Implementation SelfConsolidating Concrete SCC Page of January .
DEFINITIONS A. SelfConsolidating Concrete SCC A highly flowable nonsegregating concrete mix that spreads into place and is able to flow and fill all corners of the formwork even in the presence of congested reinforcement by means of its own mass with no mechanical vibration .

DEFINITIONS A .
Structural Lightweight Concrete A lightweight portland cement concrete mix used to reduce the dead load of the structure with all of the attributes and performance equal to normal weight structural concrete and with a lower unit weight. . SUBMITTALS A .
Refer to Section except as modified in this Section . .
Include in the concrete mix design submittal in addition to the requirements in Section a .
The weight and absolute volume for each component .

The unit weight of the fresh concrete mix for the purposes of acceptance .
c. Test reports showing that the equilibrium density of the concrete mix meets the requirements of this Section Article .
Paragraph B. .

END OF SECTION Implementation Concrete Bridge Deck Removal Page of January SECTION CONCRETE BRIDGE DECK REMOVAL PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A .
Concrete bridge deck removal in preparation for replacing the entire bridge deck. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Structural Concrete Repair .
REFERENCES A. AASHTOAWS D. Bridge Welding Code B. AASHTO LFRD Bridge Design Specifications .
DEFINITIONS Not Used .
SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Bridge Deck Removal Plan for review including at least the following a .
The proposed method of deck removal .
b. Precautions that will be used to protect portions of the structure to remain .
c. Written sequence of the specific steps for demolition .
Include steps to remove the bridge deck in a safe and controlled manner .
d. Work area plan .
Depict items such as utilities overhead and below the work area drainage inlet structures and protective measures .
e. Details of deck removal equipment and locations of use .
Include details of equipment used to lift large portions of the deck such as cranes excavators lifting slings sling hooks and jacks .
a Include crane locations operation radii and lifting calculations .
Implementation Concrete Bridge Deck Removal Page of January f. Methods for preventing damage and containing debris to protect adjacent travelways railroad facilities waterways property utilities and areas of the environment specified for protection .
Include details and locations of protection and containment such as debris shields .
g. Supporting engineering calculations .
Demonstrate the satisfactory stability and strength of the bridge under all anticipated loads and removal methods .
a Account for the loss of composite action as the bridge deck is being removed .
b Consider the AASHTO LRFD dynamic load allowance .
Demonstrate adequate strength for debris shields and containment .
h. Procedures for repairing girder damage such as cuts nicks gouges dents and spalls .
Refer to this Section Article .. i. Weld repair procedures meeting the requirements of AASHTOAWS D ..
Include weld testing and grinding requirements .
j .
Methods of debris disposal from the deck removal including final disposal site .
k. Schedule Comply with all construction timeframes specified .
l. The seal of a Professional Engineer PE or Professional Structural Engineer SE licensed in the State of Utah on drawings and calculations .
PART PRODUCTS .
EQUIPMENT A .
Saw Cutting Equipment .
Use saws capable of cutting through concrete and reinforcing steel to the specified depth .
B .
Machine Mounted Hydraulic or Pneumatic Equipment .
May be used to remove sidewalks curbs barriers and railings that do not rest directly over girders or diaphragms. . May be used in those areas of the bridge deck between the girders .
a .
Do not use directly over or within ft of any portion of the girders or diaphragms .
Implementation Concrete Bridge Deck Removal Page of January C. Jackhammers .
Use jackhammers to remove portions of concrete decks sidewalks curbs barriers and railings that rest directly on top of girders or diaphragms. . Limit the capacity of jackhammers within inches of the existing girders or diaphragms .
a .
Use lb or smaller jackhammers .
b .
Reduce the capacity of jackhammers if damage occurs to the girders or diaphragms .
D. Hand Held Cutting Tools .
Use cutting torches to cut existing reinforcing steel and shear connectors that are required to be removed. . Use handheld grinding equipment to remove portions of shear connectors .
E. Other Equipment .
Do not use unless authorized in the Bridge Deck Removal Plan .
PART EXECUTION .
DECK REMOVAL A .
Follow the authorized Bridge Deck Removal Plan .
B .
Provide the necessary equipment and protective shields to prevent damaging items below and adjacent to the bridge . .
This includes the collection of water used during deck removal. . Use debris shields and containment without cracks and openings through which material may pass .
C. Inspection . .
Provide equipment that will facilitate inspection . .
Notify the Department Steel Inspector calendar before the first stages of bridge deck removal . .
Notify the Engineer of any damage to girders .
D. Saw Cutting. . Limit the depth of longitudinal and transverse saw cuts above the girder top flange to just below the bottom mat of reinforcing steel but not closer than inches to the flange splice plate or bolts .
a .
Saw cuts no closer than inch are permitted when bottom mat of reinforcing steel is closer than inches to the top flange splice plate or bolts .
Coordinate the saw cuts that are closer than inches to the flange splice plates or bolts with the Engineer .
Implementation Concrete Bridge Deck Removal Page of January .
Continuously monitor the extension of the saw blade from under the deck during the cutting operation to prevent cutting into the girder top flanges . .
Maintain radio or visual contact between the monitoring personnel and the cutting crew. . Mark deck surface above steel girder splice locations to avoid cutting concealed splice plates and bolts .
E. Remove the concrete over the girder flange with jackhammers . .
Provide alternate methods of concrete removal in the Bridge Deck Removal Plan . .
Modify the removal process if damage occurs to the top flange diaphragms splice plates or bolts .
F. Remove shear studs on steel girders as shown . .
Remove sufficient length to avoid conflict with new deck reinforcing steel and shear studs .
a. Remnants up to  inch may be left in place if there is no conflict .
b .
Do not damage flange if grinding smooth to top flange .
G. Protect stirrups in concrete girders in place. . Repair damaged stirrups as authorized by Engineer .
H. Clean top surfaces of girders . .
Remove concrete rust scale or other extraneous material from steel girders . .
Remove fractured and loose concrete from concrete girders. . REPAIR DAMAGED STRUCTURE MEMBERS A .
Repair damaged girders and diaphragms according to the authorized Bridge Deck Removal Plan .
Use the following to develop the repair procedures .
Identify positive and negative moment regions. . Steel girder bridges a .
Repair bends and dents larger than  inch according to the authorized Bridge Deck Removal Plan .
Smaller bends and dents need not be repaired .
Implementation Concrete Bridge Deck Removal Page of January b .
Repair cuts nicks and gouges less than or equal to inch deep for negative moment regions and less than or equal to inch deep for positive moment regions by grinding unless the damaged area reduces the total flange cross section by more than percent .
Notify Engineer if damage is deeper than inch for negative moment regions and deeper than inch for positive moment regions or total flange cross section has been reduced by more than percent .
c. Repair cuts nicks and gouges greater than inch deep for negative moment regions and greater than inch deep for positive moment regions according to the method described in the Bridge Deck Removal Plan .
d. Repair damaged webs transverse vertical stiffeners and connection plates . .
Concrete Girder Bridges a .
Repair spalls  inch or greater using an authorized patching material Spalls less than  inch in the top flange need not be repaired provided that the area is to be filled with concrete or grout in the completed bridge deck .
b .
Repair cracks in the top flange using epoxy injection crack repair methods according to Section .
c. Repair saw cuts that are deeper than  inch by chipping out the area and patching with an approved patching material .
Smaller saw cuts need not be repaired . .
Develop special repair procedures for situations not defined in the authorized Bridge Deck Removal Plan and obtain authorization before starting the repair procedure .

THEADED BARS A .

B .
Use deformed rebar according to ASTM A Grade .
C. Cut plate heads for Theaded bars from flats of hotrolled steel according to ASTM A . .

B .

Provide epoxy coated galvanized plastic coated or plastic bar supports and tie wire for reinforcing steel other than stainless steel that meet the following requirements .
Meet the requirements of Table . .
Remove contaminants that affect the adhesion of the coating to the wire. . Use an electrostatic spray method fluidized bed or flocking to apply an epoxy coating .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January .
Apply plastic coating by spraying dipping or using as a powder. . Galvanized coating thickness is according to AASHTO M . .
Maintain the thickness of epoxy or plastic coatings of at least mils with no maximum. . Use patching material according to the manufacturers recommendation to repair damaged coating .
a .
Use patching material that is compatible with the coating and that is inert in concrete .
b .
Do not repair hanger marks on the coated bar supports that result from the coating application process .
Hanger marks are not considered damaged coating. . Use gauge coated tie wire .

GROUTED SPLICE COUPLER A .
Use grouted splice couplers to join precast elements as shown . .
Provide couplers that use cementitious grout placed inside a steel casting .
Grout is part of the proprietary system and is provided by the coupler manufacturer. . Use threaded connections at the Contractors option for the portions of the coupler that are placed within the precast element if the strength of the coupler meets or exceeds the requirements of this Section .
B .
Use one of the following grouted splice coupler manufacturers according to the requirements of this Section .

E. Use the same coating system as used for the reinforcing steel. . Use grouted splice couplers that join the reinforcing steel without removal of the epoxy coating on the spliced bar when using epoxy coated reinforcing steel . .
CONTINUOUS RESISTANCE BUTT WELDED HOOPS A. Weld only reinforcing steel conforming to ASTM A as shown. . Use butt welded splices for continuous hoops .
B .
Refer to AWS D. Structural Welding Code Reinforcing Steel .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January C. Perform welding only by an AWS certified welder .
D. Change welding procedures to reflect chemical composition of the steel. . Welders must have correct mill test report chemical analysis from the heat in which the steel was made .
E. Use only a welded splice capable of transferring the minimum ultimate tensile strength of the reinforcing bar from one bar to the other .
F. Apply coating after all welding has been completed . .

PART EXECUTION .
DELIVERY STORAGE AND HANDLING A .
Protect the bars and the coating during handling and storage. . Use systems with padded contact areas when handling epoxy coated bars. . Pad all bundling bands for epoxy coated bars . .
Lift all bundles with strongback multiple supports or a platform bridge. . Do not drop or drag bars .
B .
Repair damaged coating. . Epoxy Coated a .
Meet requirements of ASTM A Appendix A. for repair material .
b .
Follow manufacturer recommendations for repairs .
c. Do not use bars with total damaged surface area of epoxy coating greater than percent in any ft section .
d. Do not use bars with percent or greater damage to total surface area during all stages of work. . Galvanized a .
Use Inorganic Zinc Rich Paint with to percent zinc by weight or greater than percent by weight metallic zinc in dry film for repair material .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January b .
Follow manufacturer recommendations for repairs .
c. Reject bars with total damaged surface area of coating greater than percent in any ft section .
d. Reject any bars with percent or greater damage to total surface area during all stages of work .
C. Store bars above the ground surface on wooden or padded supports. . Place timbers between bundles when stacking is necessary. . Space the supports close enough to prevent sags in the bundles .
D. Cover epoxy coated reinforcing steel with an opaque covering upon delivery to the project site . .
Protect epoxy coated reinforcing steel that has been partially embedded in concrete or placed in formwork .
a .
Cover with an opaque covering before days exposure to sunlight. . Place the opaque coverings to provide air circulation and prevent condensation on the reinforcing steel .
E. Ship handle and store stainless reinforcing steel so it does not come in contact with carbon steel. . Cover stainless reinforcing steel with tarps during outdoor storage . .
Separate bundles of stainless reinforcing steel from other types of reinforcing steel with wooden spacers. . Store stainless reinforcing steel on wooden supports off the ground or floor. . PLACEMENT A .
Maintain a clean surface keeping all reinforcement free from loose mill scale loose or thick rust dirt paint oil or grease .
B .
Field bend bars according to the authorized field bending procedures .
C. Place all reinforcement in designated position and securely hold in position while placing and vibrating concrete . .

Tie bundled bars together at not more than ft centers .
E. Maintain the required distance from the forms and between layers of reinforcement with prefabricated chairs ties hangers or other devices .
F. Use precast concrete block bar supports only when the concrete is placed in contact with the soil and then only as the support for the bottom mat of bars .
G. Do not tack weld reinforcing bars in place .
H. Overlap at least one panel of welded wire reinforcement sheets to each other and fasten at the ends and edges .
I .
Support reinforcing steel for concrete T beams pier caps approach slabs and deck slabs on metal chairs or bar supports according to this Section Article ..
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January J .
Space chairs for supporting the top steel and bolsters for supporting the bottom steel not more than ft on center of the bar in each direction .
K. Tie deck steel to beams or forms at regular intervals of not more than ft on center along the beams to prevent steel movement during concrete placement .
L. Support reinforcing steel for slabs on grade on metal chairs attached to a sand plate or use precast concrete block supports according to this Section Article .. M. Do not place concrete until the Engineer has verified the reinforcement placement and fastening .
N. Place stainless steel reinforcement so that it does not come in contact with carbon steel. . Do not tie stainless steel to uncoated or coated carbon steel reinforcement galvanized attachments or galvanized conduits .
a .
Maintain at least inch clearance between the metals using nylon or polyethylene spacers when stainless steel reinforcing or dowels must be near coated or uncoated reinforcing or galvanized metals .
Bind using nylon cable ties .
Maintain at least inch clearance unless insufficient space exists .
a Either bar may be sleeved with a inch minimum thick insulator material such as polyethylene nylon or rubber tube extending at least inch in either direction past the point of closest contact between the two dissimilar bars .
b Sleeves are not allowed for bars that run parallel to each other. . FIELD CUTTING A .
Saw or shear coated bars that are specified to be cut in the field .
Do not flame cut .
B .
Repair the coating at the sawed or sheared end using the specified patching or repair material. . SPLICING A. Furnish all reinforcing steel in the lengths shown .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January B .
Do not splice bars except where shown .
C. Stagger splices as far as possible .
D. Place and tie lapped splices in the bars .
Maintain the minimum distance to the surface of the concrete shown .
E. Do not allow lap splices in vertical column reinforcing bars unless shown .
F. Do not lap splice No .
and No .
bars. . Use mechanical splice couplers .

Do not field bend reinforcing steel unless shown .
B .
Follow the authorized field bending procedures .
C. Use methods that do not damage coatings .
D. Do not heat the bars during the bending operations .

Do not field straighten or rebend fabricated bent bars . .
INSTALLATION OF DOWELLED ANCHORS A .
Use dowelled anchors according to the following .
Drill brush and clean all holes and install all doweled anchors according to manufacturers published recommendations applicable specifications and as shown. . Do not install dowelled anchors until the holes are verified by the Engineer . .
Install dowelled anchors .
Test dowelled anchors to percent of the dowelled anchor yield strength when shown and as follows a .
Allow anchor adhesives to cure hours before testing .
b .
Tension test according to ASTM E . Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January .
CONNECTION PROCEDURE USING GROUTED SPLICE COUPLERS A .
Use personnel familiar with installation and grouting of splice couplers and that have completed at least two successful projects in the last two years . .
Train new personnel within three months of installation by a manufacturers technical representative as an acceptable substitution for the experience .
B Remove and clean all debris from the joints before grout application .
C. Keep bonding surfaces free from laitance dirt dust paint grease oil or any contaminants other than water .
D. Embed rebar anchor dowels to the minimum coupler embedment required by the manufacturer .
E. Saturate Surface Dry SSD all joint surfaces before connecting the elements .
F. Use shims to verify that the reinforcing extensions are within the manufacturers recommended tolerance .
G. Maintain a minimum grout and sleeve temperature of degrees F. Monitor the temperature of the covered grouted slice couplers until the temporary bracing is removed .
H. Conform to the manufacturers instructions for grout mixing water to grout ratio mixing time and shelf life .
I .
Mix structural grout and coupler grout just before use according to the manufacturers instructions .
J .
Follow the manufacturers recommendations for coupler installation and grouting .
K. Monitor the grouting operation to verify that all sleeves have been filled .
L. Verify that all sleeves are protected from any vibration shock or other excessive movement until temporary bracing is removed .
M. Conform to the following when installing couplers above a horizontal joint .
Determine the thickness of shims to provide the specified elevation within tolerance . .
Follow nonshrink grout manufacturers recommendations for mixing joint surface preparation and application .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January .
Place nonshrink grout on the interface between the two elements being joined before setting the element .
a .
Crown the thickness of the grout toward the center of the joint so that the grout can be displaced outward as the element is lowered onto the joint .
b .
Prevent the grout from entering the coupler above elements by using grout dams or seals. . Set the element in place .
a .
Engage all couplers in the joint .
b .
Allow the grout to seep out of the joint. . Trowel off excess grout to form a neat joint once the element is set plumbed and aligned .
a .
Pack grout into any voids around the joint perimeter . .
Flush out the coupler with clean potable water . .
Mix the special coupler grout according to the manufacturers recommendations for methods and proportions of mix and water. . Make four sets of three inch cube specimens for testing .
a .
Cure the specimens according to AASHTO T . b .
Test one set of cubes for compressive strength to determine when to release bracing .
Refer to this Section Article .
paragraph Ba .
c. Test one set of cubes at days for acceptance .
d. Store extra sets for longer term testing if necessary .
e. Use a Department qualified laboratory to take the samples and perform the tests. . Pump the coupler grout into the coupler that is cast into the element .
a .
Start from the lower port .
b .
Pump until the grout is flowing freely from the upper port .
c. Cap the upper port first and then remove the nozzle to cap the lower port . .
Cure the joint according to the grout manufacturers recommendations .
N. Conform to the following when installing couplers below a horizontal joint .
Determine shim thickness to provide the specified elevation within tolerance. . Before setting the element a .
Mix the coupler grout paying strict attention to the manufacturers recommendations for methods and proportions of mix and water .
b .
Clean debris from the interior using compressed air .
Remove any rain water using a vacuum that can remove water from the confined space in the coupler .
c. Place the coupler grout into the coupler by pouring or pumping .
Implementation Reinforcing Steel and Welded Wire Page of January d. Place grout on the interface between the two elements being joined .
Crown the thickness of the grout toward the center of the joint so that the grout can be displaced outward as the element is lowered onto the joint. . Trowel off excess grout to form a neat joint once the element is set plumbed and aligned .
a .
Pack grout into any voids around the joint perimeter .
O .
Conform to the following when installing couplers in vertical joints horizontal barcoupler connection .
Establish a method to provide the specified elevations alignment and spacing within tolerance. . Use washers or seals to prevent mixing the joint grout and the coupler grout . .
Apply epoxy adhesive to the interface between the two elements being joined. . Set the element in place .
a .
Engage all couplers in the joint . .
Flush out the couplers with clean potable water once the element is set plumbed and aligned . .
Mix the coupler grout paying strict attention to the manufacturers recommendations for methods and proportions of mix and water. . Pump the coupler grout into the coupler that is cast into the element .
a .
Start from the port closest to the joint .
b .
Pump until the grout is flowing freely from the other port .
c. Cap the port farthest from the joint first and then remove the nozzle to cap the other port. . Form the edges of the joint and place grout into the joint . .
Cure the joint according to the grout manufacturers recommendations. . FIELD QUALITY CONTROL A .
Inspect coated bars for damage to the coating after the bars are in place and immediately before concrete placement .

Provide adequate stability against overturning .

Provide adequate stability against overturning and adequate load capacity .
The leg spread measured between points of support on the minor axis must not exceed the minimum and maximum percentages of the nominal height as shown .

DEFINITIONS A. Inlet and outlet pipes The terms inlet pipes and outlet pipes are synonymous with vents drains injection ejection or inletoutlet ports .
Inlet and outlet pipes are devices connected to the PT system used for the injection of materials into or the ejection of materials from inside the ducts .
B. Jacking force The force applied to the tendon before anchorage and the occurrence of losses including the anchor set loss .
C. Permanent force The force remaining in the prestressing steel after all losses including long term creep and shrinkage of concrete elastic shortening of concrete relaxation of steel losses in prestressing steel due to sequence of stressing friction unintended wobble of ducts anchor set friction in anchorages and all other losses particular to the method or system of prestressing have taken place or have been provided for .
D. Torpedo A rigid object sized to fit through undamaged posttensioning ducts .
Used to prove that installed ducts have not been blocked or damaged during the concrete pour. . SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Detailed drawings of the PT system for review .
Include at least the following a. Anchorage and bearing details including local zone and grillage reinforcement b. Duct placement including individual tendon center of gravity CG locations and combined tendon CG location at anchorages low points and high points Not required for segmental bridges or precast deck panels Distribute the prestressing force in castinplace post tensioned bridge girders with approximately equal quantity in each girder and place the force symmetrically about the centerline of the structure c. Method and spacing of duct supports d. Duct ties and stirrup ties e. Inlet and outlet pipe locations f. Expected friction coefficient wobble coefficient and anchor set g. Jacking forces jacking ends initial stresses and sequence Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January h. Permanent grout cap detail i .
Material data sheets for tendons ducts and permanent grout cap j .
Calculated elongations and tolerances k. Bar couplers when shown l. High point outlet inspection details m. Anchorage inspection details .
Include supporting engineering calculations .
a .
Design the posttensioning system according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications b .

Provide detailed congestion drawings integrating PT system and concrete reinforcing at locations where duct or anchorage passes through grids of reinforcing steel such as at anchorage zones diaphragms bents and other highly congested areas .
a .
Indicate additions or rearrangement of reinforcing steel and revisions to concrete dimensions from that shown .

D. Prestressing Steel .
Accompany each lot of prestressing steel with a mill certificate and a test report including the following a .
Chemical composition not required for strand b. Crosssectional area c. Yield and ultimate strengths d. Elongation at rupture e. Modulus of elasticity f. Stress strain curve for the actual prestressing steel intended for use .
Supply a certificate of conformance stating the manufacturers minimum guaranteed ultimate tensile strengths and actual ultimate strengths with each reel or heat of prestressing steel wires bars or strands .

Provide three ft long samples of each size from each reel for strand .
Provide three ft long samples from each heat or reel for wire or bars .

Be certified as a PTI Level Bonded PT Field Specialist .
Attend the preconstruction meeting Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January .
Be present at all times during installation of PT system components to a .
Inspect and approve installation of hardware including ducts b .
Provide instructions to the Contractor regarding concrete placement around the ducts endanchorage assemblies and other appurtenances .
Provide close observation and control of a. Duct pressure field test b. Stressing and anchoring of tendons c. Postgrout inspections and repairs d. Record keeping certification of stressing results and approval of elongations .
Be present for grouting operations .
Review and sign a. Duct pressure field tests records b. Elongation records c. Stressing operation records .
More than one representative is required when multiple PT operations are occurring simultaneously .
B. Grouting operation supervisor must .
Be certified as either an ASBI Certified Grouting Technician or a PTI Level Bonded PT Field Specialist .
Attend the preconstruction meeting .
Provide close observation and control of grouting operations including a. Mixing and placing b .
Field trial tests c. Field mockup tests d. Production tests .
Review and sign a. Grouting Procedures b .
Safety Procedures c. Grouting operation reports PART PRODUCTS .
GENERAL A .

B .

PRESTRESSING STEEL A .
Materials .
Strand a. Uncoated Grade lowrelaxation wire strand conforming to AASHTO M . Bar a. Uncoated deformed Type II conforming to AASHTO M . Wire a. Uncoated lowrelaxation conforming to AASHTO M B .
Attach tags for strand from each manufactured reel bars of each size from each mill heat wire from each coil anchorage assemblies PT system components and bar couplers to be shipped to the site . .
Assign the individual lot number and tag in such a manner that each lot can be accurately identified at the job site . .
Unidentified prestressing steel anchorage assemblies or bar couplers received at the site will be rejected if there is a loss of positive identification of these items at any time .
C. Use bar couplers only at the locations shown. . Use mechanical couplers that develop at least percent of the actual ultimate strength of the bar tested in an unbonded state without exceeding anticipated set. . Use couplers for bars that do not reduce the elongation at rupture below the anticipated elongation of an uncoupled bar .
D. Protect prestressing steel against physical damage and rust or other results of corrosion at all times from manufacture to grouting or encasing in concrete. . Do not use prestressing steel that has sustained physical damage . .
Remove and discard lengths of strand containing broken wire. . Use wire that is bright and uniformly colored having no foreign matter or pitting on its surface. . Package prestressing steel in containers or shipping forms to protect the steel against physical damage and corrosion during shipping and storage .
a .
Use a corrosion inhibitor which prevents rust or other results of corrosion placed in the package or form Use a corrosion inhibitor either placed in the package form or applied directly to the steel that has no deleterious effect on the steel grout concrete or bond strength of steel to grout .
Use inhibitor carrier type packaging material that conforms to the provisions of Federal Specification MILPRF .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January b .
Immediately rejuvenate or replace the corrosion inhibitor if its useful life expires. . Use shipping package or form that is clearly marked with a statement that the package contains highstrength prestressing steel care to be used in handling the type kind and amount of corrosion inhibitor used including the date when placed safety orders and instructions for use .
a .
Immediately replace damaged packaging or forms or restore to original condition. . POSTTENSIONING ANCHORAGES A .
Use anchoring devices that develop at least percent of the actual ultimate tensile strength of the prestressing steel tested in an unbonded state without exceeding the anticipated set. . DUCTS A .
General .
Use corrugated galvanized metal ducts corrugated plastic ducts rigid steel pipe ducts or smooth plastic ducts .
a .
Use ducts that are mortar tight and capable of withstanding concrete pressures without deforming or permitting the entrance of cement paste during the placing of concrete .
b .
Use ducts that can be accurately bent and placed at the locations shown . .
Minimum internal dimensions for a. Multistrand tendons crosssectional area  times the crosssectional area of the prestressing steel b. Prestressing bars diameter  inches larger than bar outside diameter measured across deformations c. Prestressing bars with couplers diameter  inches larger than largest dimension of the largest enclosed element Enclose bar couplers and coupler components in housings long enough to permit the necessary movements .
Use ducts that have properties compatible with the assumed design values shown. . Use ducts that can be bent as shown without crimping or flattening and have sufficient strength to maintain their correct alignment during placing of concrete. . Use duct splices at joints between precast segments that are capable of positively preventing the entrance of cement paste and water from concrete .
a .
Use duct splices that do not cause electrolytic action or deteriorate .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January .
Provide reference marks on rigid ducts to facilitate orientation during placement . .
Provide hold down ties to the forms when the buoyancy of the ducts in the fluid concrete would lift the reinforcing steel .
B .
Metal Ducts .
Fabricate corrugated semirigid ducts from ASTM A galvanized sheet steel coating designation G. a .
Use a minimum wall thickness of gauge for semirigid ducts less than or equal to .
inches in diameter gauge for semirigid ducts greater than .
inches in diameter gauge when bar tendons are preassembled with semirigid ducts b. Fabricate with either welded or interlocked seams .
Galvanize welded seams. . Fabricate rigid steel pipe ducts from galvanized ASTM A Grade B schedule steel pipe .
a .
Use pipe with smooth inner walls capable of being curved to the proper configuration without crimping or flattening . .
Provide joints between sections of ducts that have positive metallic connections which do not result in angle changes at the joints .
C. Plastic Ducts .
Refer to Section .. of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications for the fabrication and testing requirements of corrugated plastic ducts .
a .
Use seamless fabrication methods to manufacture corrugated plastic duct. . Use rigid smooth black polyethylene ducts manufactured from percent virgin polyethylene resin meeting the requirements of ASTM D with a minimum cell class of C where the tendon is not embedded in concrete .
a .
Use a resin containing antioxidants with a minimum oxidation induction time OIT according to ASTM D of not less than minutes .
b .
Manufacture smooth duct with a dimensional ratio DR of .
as established by either ASTM D or ASTM F as appropriate for the manufacturing process used .
c. Use duct meeting the minimum pressure rating of psi .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January D. Exceptions .
Use plastic ducts that are leak tight vapor tight and impermeable where special corrosion protection is required such as in bridge decks external tendons and bridge elements subjected to corrosive environments. . Use plastic ducts where stray electrical currents may cause corrosion damage to tendon materials. . Do not use plastic ducts when the radius of curvature of the tendon is less than ft. E. Splices Joints Couplings Connections and Inlet and Outlet Pipes .
Use stainless steel nylon or polyolefin materials .
a .
Stainless steel products other than bolts conform to ASTM A Type .
ASTM F Type for bolts b. Nylon products use one of the following cell classes according to ASTM D SPA weather resistant SPA heat stabilized SPA ultimate strength not less than psi with UV stabilizers added c. Polyolefin products conform to the following Contains antioxidants with a minimum induction time of minutes according to ASTM D Remolded finished polyolefin material has a stress crack resistance minimum failure time of hours at an applied stress of psi using ASTM F . Make splices joints couplings and connection to duct and anchorage with devices or methods mechanical couplers plastic sleeves heatshrink sleeves producing a smooth interior alignment with no lips or kinks .
a .
Provide connections and fittings that are airtight and watertight .
b .
Tape sealed connections or repairs are not permitted c. Heatshrink sleeves requirements refer to PTI M. Section d. Provide connections that are external to the concrete with a minimum pressure rating of psi . .
Plastic components including fasteners must be free of water soluble chlorides and not react with the concrete or enhance corrosion of the prestressing steel .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January .
Use inlet and outlet pipes that are  inch minimum inside diameter for strand tendons or  inch for single bar tendons .
a .
Use inlet and outlet pipes that are fitted with positive mechanical shutoff valves or plugs .
Design and test inlets outlets valves and plugs to resist a minimum pressure of psi .
b .
Extend pipes a sufficient distance out of the concrete member to allow for proper closing of the valves .

Use a commercial prepackaged antibleed posttensioning grout conforming to the requirements for a Class C grout as defined by PTI M .. . Furnish grout capable of meeting the vertical rise requirements for the project tendons . .

a .
Use grout within months of manufacture. . Use water that is potable clean and free of injurious quantities of substances known to be harmful to Portland cement or prestressing steel. . EPOXY GROUT A .

PERMANENT GROUT CAP A .
Use permanent grout caps made of one of the following .
Fiber reinforced polymers using nylon Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene ABS or polyester resins a .
Use one of the following cell classes for products made from nylon SPA weather resistant SPA SPA ultimate strength not less than psi with ultraviolet stabilizer added according to ASTM D . ASTM A Type L stainless steel B .
Use caps rated for a minimum pressure of psi .
C. Seal caps against the anchor bearing plate with neoprene Oring seals and ASTM F Type stainless steel bolts .
D. Provide an inlet port at the top of the cap or front of cap as appropriate. . EPOXY COMPOUND A .
Comply with ASTM C Type IV .
PART EXECUTION .
ANCHORAGE INSTALLATION A .
Arrange the anchorage so that the prestressing force in the tendon can be verified before removal of the stressing equipment .
B .
Set anchorage devices or blockout templates for anchorages in a plane normal to the axis of the tendons so that anchor plates are normal in all directions of the tendon and bear uniformly on the concrete .
C. Recess the anchoring devices so that the ends of the prestressing steel and parts of anchoring devices including permanent grout caps are embedded at least inches inside the end surface of the element .
D. Locate anchorages within plus or minus  inch of the desired position laterally and plus or minus inch along the tendon . .
Maintain minimum cover requirements .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January E. Verify entrance and exit angles of tendon paths at anchorages and at faces of concrete so they are within plus or minus degrees of desired angle measured in any direction and deviations in the alignment are accomplished with smooth transitions without kinks. . DUCT INSTALLATION A. Securely tie ducts in position inspect and repair before concrete placement is started. . Use supplementary support bars where needed to maintain proper alignment of the duct .
B. Securely fasten internal ducts to avoid displacing or damaging the ducts during concrete placement. . Support polyethylene duct and metal duct for longitudinal PT in the flanges at intervals not to exceed ft. .
Tie polyethylene duct in webs for longitudinal PT to stirrups at intervals not to exceed ft. . Support flat ducts for transverse PT at intervals of not more than inches . .
Tie metal duct for longitudinal PT in webs to stirrups at intervals not to exceed ft. C. Verify final position of PT duct is within the tolerances shown in Table of the AASHTO LRFD Construction Specifications . .
Position the duct as shown and adjust the reinforcement as determined by the Engineer if conflicts exist between the reinforcement and posttensioning duct .
D. Provide inletoutlet ports at the following locations .
Anchorage areas of tendon .
The high points of the duct when there is more than a inch variation in the vertical position of the duct a .
Locate additional outlet ports ft to either side of the high point .
Low points of the duct .
Verify outlet port is free draining .
Major changes in the cross section of the duct such as coupler locations .
Locations as shown E. Verify that ducts anchorage blockouts openings inlets and outlets are kept clean and free of debris fuel oils other contaminants and site trash. . Seal the ends of ducts after installation in the forms. . Leave low point outlets open .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January F. Verify angle changes at duct joints are within plus or minus degrees of desired angle measured in any direction and deviations in the alignment are accomplished with smooth transitions without kinks .
G. Use mandrels as stiffeners in each duct during concrete placement for precast segments . .
Extend mandrel throughout the length of the segment being cast and at least ft into the corresponding duct of the previously cast segment . .
Provide mandrels of sufficient rigidity to maintain the duct geometry with the tolerances shown in this Section. . TENDON INSTALLATION A. Verify that ducts are unobstructed undamaged and free of water and debris after completion of concrete placement and before installing the prestressing steel . .
Prove that the ducts are clear of obstructions or damage by passing a suitably sized torpedo through the ducts .
a .
Size the torpedo  inch smaller than the clear inside dimensions of the duct with rounded ends .
b .
Use a ft long torpedo for straight ducts .
c. Size the torpedo for sharply curved ducts such that when both ends touch the outermost wall the torpedo is at least  inch clear of the inside wall .
d. The member will be rejected if the torpedo will not easily travel completely through the duct .
e. Using a torpedo to verify that ducts are clear is not required for four strand tendons in flat ducts used for transverse PT of segmental boxgirders placed before concrete casting .
Prove PT ducts are free and clear of obstructions or damage by moving the group of strands back and forth in duct for a minimum distance of ft in each direction .
Move strands easily by hand without resorting to excessive effort or mechanical assistance . .
Flush ducts with oilfree and waterfree compressed air or water as required to remove unwanted material from inside of ducts .
a. Ducts subjected to contamination with chlorides water used for flushing ducts may contain slack lime calcium hydroxide or quicklime calcium oxide in the amount of .
lbgal .
Test for presence of chlorides and oils in discharged water before placing tendons .
Continue to flush if chloride levels in flush water outflow exceeded ppm until chloride level in flush water outflow is below ppm .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January b .
Blow all water out of the duct with oilfree compressed air and swab dry after flushing .
B .
Conduct duct pressure field tests before installing the internal or external prestressing steel . .
Install grout caps inlet and outlet port caps and other components necessary to seal ducts. . Pressurize duct to psi using oilfree and waterfree compressed air .
a .
Only one duct per web or girder may be tested at a time . .
Lock off the outside air source. . Record pressure loss for minute .
a .
Locate the leak repair and retest if the pressure loss exceeds .
psi for tendons greater than ft long or .
psi for tendons less than or equal to ft long . .
Include location and method of repair in duct air test records if repairs are required. . Do not load strand until all pressure tests are successful .
C. Strands in an individual tendon may be pushed or pulled through the duct individually or may be pulled through the duct as a unit . .
Protect the strand which is being advanced into the duct from contact with abrasive materials such as steel or concrete and contaminants such as grease oil and dirt at all times .
a .
Round off ends of strands and wires that are pushed or fit advancing end with smooth protective cap .
b .
Use pulling lines with a capacity of at least .
times the dead weight of the tendons when used for essentially horizontal tendon installation .
c. Do not use pushing wheels made from metal .
d. Do not intentionally rotate strands or wires during installation .
e. Use a special steel wire sock or other device attached to advancing end if a tendon is pulled through the duct .
f. Do not install permanent tendons before completion of testing as required by this Section. . STRESSING TENDONS A .
General .
Do not apply PT forces until the concrete has attained the required compressive strength as shown .
a .
Do not apply PT forces to castinplace concrete structures other than segmentally constructed bridges until days after the last concrete has been placed in the member .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January b .
Make test cylinders for determining strength of the same concrete and cured under the same conditions as the member . .
Stress all strands in each tendon simultaneously with a multistrand jack except for those in flat ducts with not more than four strands. . Furnish equipment for tensioning the tendons from the manufacturer of the PT system. . Sequence the stressing of posttension castinplace bridge such that no more than one tendon is stressed per web before stressing a tendon in another web .
a .
Do not apply an eccentric force about the centerline of the structure that exceeds of the total posttensioning force at any time during the prestressing. . Keep stressing operation records that include the following for each tendon installed a .
Project Pin Name and number b .
Contractor and subcontractor c. Tendon location size and type d. Date tendon was first installed in ducts e. Coil and reel number for strands or wires and heat number for bars and wire f. Assumed and actual crosssectional area g. Assumed and actual modulus of elasticity h. Date stressed i. Jack and gauge numbers per end of tendon j .
Required jacking force k. Gauge pressures l. Elongations theoretical and actual m. Anchor sets theoretical and actual n. Stressing sequence for example tendons before and after this tendon o. Stressing mode one end or two ends or simultaneous p. Witnesses to stressing operation Contractor manufacturers representative and Inspector q .
Date grouted days from stressing to grouting grouting pressure applied and injection end r. Other relevant information B. Stressing Jacks .
Use hydraulic jacks to stress tendons that are capable of providing and sustaining the necessary forces .
Equip each jack with either a .
A pressure gauge with an accurately reading dial at least inches in diameter .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January b .
A load cell with indicator by means of which the prestressing force in the tendon may be determined .
Do not use the lower percent of the Manufacturers rated capacity when determining the jacking stress. . Use a jacking system that provides an independent means of measuring the tendon elongation .
C. Tensioning Operations .
Tension prestressing steel so that the force of the prestressing steel will not be less than the value shown on the authorized shop drawings .
a .
Do not exceed percent of the guaranteed ultimate tensile strength of the prestressing steel during the stressing of the tendons .
Replace tendons stressed past percent of the guaranteed ultimate tensile strength .
b. Anchor the prestressing steel at initial stresses that will result in the long term retention of permanent forces of not less than those shown on the approved shop drawings .
c. Do not allow the initial stress at the anchorage to exceed percent of guaranteed ultimate tensile strength after anchor set . .
Remove and replace strand due to wire failure or slipping during stressing if any of the following conditions are met a .
Member cross section has a final effective PT force less than percent of the design total PT force based on the recorded jacking force or liftoff force whichever is smaller .
b. PT force across a mating joint is less than percent of PT force required by the contract drawings for that mating joint for that stage of construction .
This requirement applies to segmental construction or similar construction that has members post tensioned together across a common joint face at any stage of construction .
c. Any single tendon has more than a percent reduction in crosssectional area or posttensioning steel due to wire failure . .
Follow stressing sequence shown in authorized shop drawings .
D. Elongations .
Conduct the tensioning process such that tension being applied and the elongation of the posttensioning steel can be measured at all times. . Keep a permanent record of gauge pressures and tendon elongations for each tendon. . Measure elongations to the nearest inch .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January .
Preload tendons to percent of their final jacking force before beginning elongation readings to eliminate takeup in the tensioning system. . Mark each strand before final stressing to permit measurement of elongation and to verify that all anchor wedges set properly . .
The measured elongation must agree within percent of the theoretical elongation for the posttensioned elements to verify the required tendon force or the entire operation must be checked and the source of the error determined and remedied to the satisfaction of the Department before proceeding with the work .
a .
Do not overstress the tendon to achieve the theoretical elongation .
b .
Acceptance may be achieved by force verification liftoff tests demonstrating that the measured force is within minus percent and plus percent of the required force as shown if the measured elongations fall outside of the acceptable tolerance. . Do not cut off the stressing tails of the tendons until the elongations have been approved by the PT system manufacturers representative .
Within hours of approval a .
Cut prestressing steel using an abrasive saw or plasma torch to within  inch to  inch from anchorage .
Flame cutting of PT steel is not permitted .
b .
Clean rust and other debris from metal surfaces which will be covered by the grout cap c. Place grout cap including a seal over the wedge place until the tendon is grouted .
E. Protection of Steel After Installation .
Minor rust which may form on the surface of the prestressing steel within calendar days after protective packaging has been opened will not be cause for rejection. . Prestressing steel installed tensioned and grouted within calendar days will not require the use of corrosion inhibitor in the duct following installation of the prestressing steel .
a .
Blow a vapor phase corrosion inhibitor powder conforming to MILPRF into ducts containing prestressing steel if prestressing steel is anticipated to be removed from protective packaging for days or more before grouting. . Do not exceed calendar days between removal of prestressing steel from protective packaging and grouting operations .
a .
Failure to begin grouting operations will result in stoppage of work .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January .
GROUTING A .
General .
Begin grouting operations to fill the void space between the duct and the tendons as soon as possible after all the prestressing steel has been tensioned anchored and approved by the PT system manufacturers representative . .
Flush the inside of the duct with water under pressure to remove all traces of the corrosion inhibitor used to protect the prestressing steel if a vapor phase corrosion inhibitor has been blown into ducts before grouting .
a .
Continue flushing operations until the discharge water is free of traces of the corrosion inhibitor .
b .
Blow all water out of the duct with oilfree compressed air and swab dry after flushing . .
Eliminate vibration from all sources under the contractors control within ft of the member being grouted for the duration of the grouting procedure and hours after completion . .
Conduct a joint meeting of the Contractor grouting crew and the Engineer before grouting operations begin .
a .
Discuss the grouting operation plan required testing corrective procedures and other relevant issues at the meeting .
B .
Temperature .
Keep PT grout below degrees F during mixing or pumping .
a .
Cool the mixing water if necessary. . Keep ducts free of water to avoid damage due to freezing in temperatures below degrees F. . Keep accurate temperature records covering maximum and minimum air temperatures and temperatures of the concrete adjacent to the ducts to be grouted when ambient temperature may be expected to fall below degrees F. . Do not use any material in which frost or ice is present and keep the ducts and equipment free of frost and ice . .
Postpone grouting operations if frost is expected within hours of start . .
Maintain a temperature of at least degrees in the grout in the ducts for the duration of the grouting and the longer of hours after completion or until jobcured inch cubes of PT grout reach a minimum compressive strength of psi when low temperatures are expected and grouting can not be postponed .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January C. Equipment .
Use equipment which meets the requirements in Section .. of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications . .
Provide flushing equipment with an independent power source on site capable of developing a pressure of psi and of sufficient capacity to flush out partially grouted ducts as required due to blockage or breakdown of equipment .
a .
Do not exceed the allowable grouting pressures when flushing .
Refer to this Section article .
E. D. Mixing .
Mix PT grout according to the manufacturers recommendations .
a .
Continue mixing grout until a uniform thoroughly blended grout is obtained without excessive temperature increase. . Agitate the grout continuously until it is pumped. . Do not begin grouting operations until the field trial tests specified in PTI M. Section .. have been satisfactorily performed .
a .
Do not add water to increase grout flowability that has been decreased by delayed use of the grout . .
Perform field mockup test specified in PTI M. Section .. when required by the Engineer. . Do not exceed a watercement ratio of .. E. Grouting Operations .
Blow oilfree and waterfree compressed air through the ducts checking all inlet and outlet pipes to verify they are capable of accepting injection of the PT grout immediately before grouting. . Open all inlet and outlet ports before grouting starts . .
Obtain target flow rates as a function of mixer type used and ambient temperatures from the PT grout manufacturer .
a. Verify the grouting rate is slow enough to avoid air entrapment and segregation of the grout and verify complete filling of the duct . .
Maintain a continuous oneway flow of PT grout in a generally uphill direction .
a .
Inject PT grout from near the lowest end of tendons .
b. Grout each tendon in one operation .
c. Flush the grout out of the duct with water immediately when oneway flow of grout can not be maintained or grouting is interrupted . .
Refer to PTI M. Section .. for production test requirements of production grout . .
Perform normal operations at approximately psi. . Do not exceed a pumping pressure at the tendon inlet of a. psi for internal polyethylene ducts b. psi for internal circular steel ducts Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January c. psi for external HDPE pipe d. Close the inlet and inject the PT grout at the next outlet which now becomes an inlet which has just been or is ready to be closed as long as a oneway flow is maintained if the actual grouting pressure exceeds the maximum allowed .
Fit the outlet that is to be used for injection with a positive shutoff .
Do not inject grout into a succeeding outlet from which grout has not yet flowed . .
Waste grout through the first outlet after the inlet pipe until residual water or entrapped air has been removed a .
Cap or otherwise close outlet when the consistency of the ejected grout is the same as the injected grout .
b .
Close following remaining outlets in the same manner except at high points where the outlets a short distance downstream to the high point are closed before the high point outlet .
c. Discharge at least gallons of grout through the final outlet pipe before sealing . .
Provide a standpipe at the upper end of the duct for vertical or nearly vertical tendons .
a .
Design the standpipe to collect and store bleed water and allow it to be removed from the grout .
b .
Locate the standpipe so that the level of the grout can be brought to an elevation so that bleeding will not cause the level of the grout to drop below the highest point of the upper anchorage device .
c. Remove the standpipe after the grout has hardened. . Do not remove or open plugs caps or valves until the PT grout has set .
a .
Remove ends of inletoutlet pipes at least inches below the concrete surface after the grout has set .
b .
Fill the void with epoxy grout within hours of inlet and outlet removal .
c. Remove all miscellaneous material used for sealing grout caps before carrying our further work to protect anchorages .
d. Permanently seal all outlet and inlet openings for external tendons. . Keep grouting operation records that include the following for each duct a .
Names of personnel performing the grouting activity b .
Identification of tendon c. Date grouted d. Number of days from tendon installation to grouting e. Quantities and types of material used Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January f. The maximum pumping pressure at the inlet g. Temperature measurements of air water prepackaged material mixture grout and concrete member in the duct Note if temperatures are within acceptable limits .
h. Summary of tests performed and the results including postgrouting inspection i .
Volume of grout pumped and capacity of duct accounting for reduction for area of prestressing steel Include ratio of actual grout used to anticipated quantity of grout used .
j .
Time from beginning grouting operation to sealing all inlet and outlet pipes k. Discussions of problems encountered during grouting and steps taken to resolve them F. PostGrouting Inspection .
Randomly inspect percent of the inlet and outlet pipes at anchorage and at high points for voids by drilling and inspecting with a borescope .
a .
Inspect ducts between and hours after grouting .
b .
Use drilling equipment that will automatically shut off when steel is encountered to prevent damaging the prestressing steel and anchorages .
c. All anchorages and high points will be inspected if a void exposing prestressing steel is found by random drilling .
d. Fill drilled holes not indicating voids with epoxy compound within hours of completion of inspections .
Use an injection tube to fill drilled hole from the base .
e. Use vacuum grouting to fill voids that expose prestressing steel .
Perform vacuum grouting operations under the direct supervision of a crew foreman who has been trained and has experience in the use of vacuum grouting equipment and procedures. . PROTECTION OF END ANCHORAGE A .
Protect PT strand wire and bar anchorages as soon as practical but not to exceed days after grouting is completed .
B .
Cap inlets and outlets with plastic or stainless steel threaded plugs .
Implementation PostTensioning Concrete Page of January C. Construct anchorage pourbacks with epoxy grout according to manufacturers recommendations . .
Mechanically clean and abrasive blast clean the surface of concrete in anchorage recesses until clean aggregate is exposed .
a Flush surface with water and blow dry. . Do not damage reinforcing steel coatings. . Test substrate at pourback locations using ASTM C and develop a minimum of psi tension .
D. Construct pourbacks using tight fitting forms that can be installed and held in place securely against the previously placed concrete . .
Fill recess with epoxy grout and finish flush .
