or less .
Refer to ASTM C . . FORMS A. Plywood wood metal glass or a combination of these materials .
B .
Use mortartight concrete forms true to the dimensions lines and grades of the structure and of sufficient rigidity to prevent objectional distortion of the formed concrete surface caused by pressure of the concrete and other loads incidental to the construction operations .
C. Discontinue using a form or forming system that produces a concrete surface with excessive undulations until modifications have been made. . Undulations are excessive if they exceed either  inch over feet or of the centertocenter distance between studs joints forms fasteners or wales .
D. Countersink all bolt and rivet holes when using metal forms for exposed surfaces so that a plane smooth surface of the desired contour is obtained .
E. Use lumber that is free of knotholes loose knots cracks splits warps or other defects that affect the strength or appearance of the structure . .
Rough lumber may be used for forming surfaces if visible rough surfaces do not show on the final structure .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January F. Form exposed element surfaces of a concrete structure with the same forming material or with materials that produce a concrete surface that is uniform in texture color and appearance .
G. Do not use stayinplace metal deck forms unless otherwise specified. . MISCELLANEOUS STEEL ITEMS A .
Galvanize all miscellaneous steel items permanently cast into structural concrete elements .
Refer to AASHTO M . . EPOXY ADHESIVE A .
Refer to AASHTO M Type II. . WATERPROOFING MEMBRANE A .
Refer to Section PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Falsework .
Design and construct falsework according to the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Section Temporary Works .
a .
Design falsework so that loads imposed on existing new or partially completed portions of structures due to construction operations do not exceed the load carrying capacity of the structure or portion of the structure .
b. Brace and tie girders to resist forces that would cause rotation or torsion in the girders from the placing of concrete for diaphragms or decks or show girders to be adequate for those effects .
c. Do not weld falsework support brackets or braces to structural steel members or to reinforcing steel. . Footing Construction a .
Build falsework on a solid footing that is safe against undermining protected from softening and capable of supporting imposed loads .
b .
Demonstrate that the soil bearing values do not exceed the supporting capacity of the soil .
Conduct load tests or have soils investigation conducted by a professional engineer licensed in the State of Utah .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January c. Use piling or drilled shafts to support falsework that can not be founded on a solid footing .
d. Space drive and remove piles according to the authorized falsework drawings. . Construction a .
Use materials able to sustain the stresses required by the falsework design .
b .
Use suitable jacks or wedges to set the forms to the grade or camber required and to prevent settling .
c. Produce a finished structure of the specified camber and built to the lines and grades indicated .
B .
Forms .
Clean the inside surfaces of dirt mortar and foreign material before concrete placement. . Use form oil that permits the ready release of the forms and does not discolor the concrete. . Do not place concrete in the forms until a .
All work connected with form construction has been completed .
b .
All embedded materials have been placed .
c. All dirt chips sawdust water and other foreign materials have been removed .
d. Inspection and approval have been obtained. . Do not use stayinplace deck forms unless otherwise specified .
C. Footings Box Culverts and Headwalls .
Excavation and Backfill Refer to Section . .
The Engineer may direct written changes in dimensions or elevations necessary to secure a satisfactory foundation. . Do not dewater by pumping during concrete placement or for hours thereafter unless pumping is outside the enclosure. . Do not use well points to dewater footing .
D. Bridge Decks .
Reinforcing Steel a .
Pass the screed over the area with a screed face device to measure the cover before concrete placement .
b .
Relocate and tie reinforcing steel that projects above the specified level before placing the concrete .
c. Adjust and support reinforcing steel that does not meet the placement tolerances defined in Section before placing the concrete .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Screeds a .
Firmly support screed rails for bridge deck slabs to prevent movement during concrete placement .
b .
Support the machine rails on the bridge beams when using a finishing machine .
c. Do not place the machine rails on the forms unless the form supports have been strengthened to prevent deflection and the Engineer gives authorization .
E. Miscellaneous Construction .
Drainage and Weep Holes a. Construct drainage and weep holes at locations shown or as directed .
b .
Place ports or vents for equalizing hydrostatic pressure below low water .
c. Use noncorrosive materials for weep hole forms .
d. Paint exposed surfaces of metal drains as shown. . Anchor Bolts a. Securely and accurately set anchor bolts in bent caps abutments or pedestals before the concrete is placed .
b .
Use templates to maintain location and plumbness. . PLACE CONCRETE A .
Do not place concrete without authorization from the Engineer .
B .
Do not deviate from the deck placing sequence shown without written authorization from the Engineer .
C. The Engineer may postpone placement operations if the concrete can not be protected during adverse weather .
D. Handling concrete .
Avoid segregation of the ingredients . .
Arrange chutes troughs or pipes used as aids in placing concrete so the concrete does not separate. . Use metal or metallined chutes and troughs .
Do not use aluminum. . Equip chutes with baffle boards or a reversed section at the end of the outlet when placing on steep slopes . .
Extend open troughs and chutes down inside the forms or through holes left in the forms .
Terminate the ends in vertical downspouts . .
Thoroughly flush all chutes troughs and pipes with water before and after each placement .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Do not allow the free fall of concrete to exceed ft for thin walls maximum inch thickness or ft for other types of construction without the use of a tremie or a flexible metal spout. . Use flexible metal spout sections composed of conical sections not more than ft long with the diameter of the outlet and the taper of the various sections so the concrete fills the outlet and retards concrete flow .
E. Placing concrete .
Deposit concrete as close as possible to its final position without allowing it to flow laterally in the form . .
Spread fresh concrete in horizontal layers with thickness not greater than what can be compacted with vibrators. . Do not use vibrators to flow concrete laterally. . Limit placement interruptions to minutes. . Place and vibrate each layer before the preceding layer has taken initial set. . Do not place concrete in flowing water .
F. Consolidating concrete .
Use high frequency internal vibrators to consolidate all concrete for structures except concrete placed under water. . Use enough vibrators to consolidate the fresh concrete to the desired degree within minutes after it is deposited in the forms. . Supply at least two vibrators for structures involving more than yd of concrete. . Do not attach vibrators to or against the forms or the reinforcing steel. . Do not allow vibrators to penetrate layers of concrete that have taken initial set. . Use spades or wedgeshaped tampers to secure a smooth and even texture of the exposed surface. . PLACE CONCRETE UNDER WATER A .
Place and deposit concrete under water as shown .
B. Seal the forms or cofferdams watertight .
C. Do not pump water while placing concrete or disturb the concrete until it has set at least hours or attained at least percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
D. Regulate placing to keep surfaces approximately horizontal at all times .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January E. Place the concrete by beginning at one end of the form and progressing in a zigzag movement from side to side across the length of the form .
F. Place the concrete using a tremie or concrete pumping equipment .
G. Placing concrete with a tremie .
Use an inch to inch diameter steel tube tremie constructed with watertight connections a hopper to receive concrete and a device at the bottom to exclude water from entering the tube. . Use support that permits the discharge end to move over the entire top work surface and permits the tremie to be rapidly lowered to stop or retard flow when necessary . .
Minimize the number of tremie location shifts for continuous placement. . Keep the tremie tube full to the bottom of the hopper during placement. . Slightly raise the tremie when a batch is dumped into the hopper but do not raise it out of the concrete at the bottom until the batch discharges to the bottom of the hopper .
a. Replug the end and refill the tube with concrete if the concrete seal around the tube is lost. . PUMP CONCRETE A .
Use a prequalified concrete pumping contractor .
Refer to UDOT Quality Management Plan Concrete Pumping . .
Replace pump that causes excessive or erratic loss of air entrainment. . Use a pump that produces a continuous stream of concrete without air pockets. . Do not add water to the concrete in the pump hopper .
B .
Do not allow pump vibrations to damage freshly placed concrete .
C. Do not use concrete contaminated by priming or cleaning the pump . .
LIMITATIONS A .
Light the work site so all operations are plainly visible if mixing placing or finishing occurs after daylight hours .
B .
Keep all traffic off concrete bridges and culverts for days after final concrete placement until all concrete is fully cured and until all concrete achieves percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January C. Keep all traffic off bridge deck and approach slab closure pours for at least days after final concrete placement until all concrete is fully cured and until all concrete achieves percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders. . Highearly strength concrete used in bridge deck and approach slab closure pours may be opened to traffic at least days after final concrete placement and after concrete achieves percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders. . CONSTRUCTION JOINTS A .
Make construction joints where shown .
B .
Obtain Engineers authorization when additional construction joints are desired and meet the following requirements .
Place and construct without impairing strength and appearance. . Place in planes perpendicular to the principal lines of stress and at points of minimum shear. . Make monolithic structures by extending the reinforcing across the joint. . Avoid construction joints through paneled wing walls or large surfaces that are to be treated architecturally. . Make a straight line joint across the face of the pour for the full width of the bridge deck. . Leave a rough surface to increase the bond with the concrete placed later. . Form tapered sections with an insert so that the succeeding layer of concrete ends in a section at least inches thick. . Place a bulkhead from the surface to the top mat of steel to establish a straight vertical face .
Shape the concrete below the top steel to a near vertical face in line with the bulkhead . .
Establish a straight vertical face by saw cutting to a minimum depth of inch when a bulkhead can not be placed .
a .
Shape the concrete below the saw cut to a near vertical face .
C. Meet the following before resuming concrete placement .
Retighten forms. . Roughen the surface of hardened concrete without leaving loosened particles or damaged concrete. . Clean off concrete surface of foreign matter and laitance by sandblasting. . Saturate concrete surface with water . .
Apply epoxy adhesive to face of construction joints .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
CONCRETE SURFACE FINISHING CLASSIFICATIONS A .
Ordinary Surface Finish A true and uniform finished surface .
B .
Rubbed Finish A surface smooth in texture and uniform in appearance free of form marks and irregularities .
C. Wire Brush or Scrubbed Finish .
A finished surface with the cement surface film completely removed and the aggregate particles exposed leaving an evenpebbled texture. . An appearance ranging from fine granite to coarse conglomerate depends on the size and grading of the aggregate used .
D. Floated Surface Finish .
Flat work Strike off and use a floated surface finish. . Bridge decks and approach slabs machine finish unless otherwise permitted . .
CONCRETE SURFACE FINISHING A .
Give all formed concrete surfaces at least an ordinary surface finish except as specified otherwise .
B .
Use other types of finishes as required in addition to the ordinary surface finish .
C. Provide a rubbed finish for repaired surfaces that can not meet ordinary surface finish requirements due to irregularities honeycombing excessive surface voids discoloration and other defects . .
CONCRETE SURFACE FINISHING PROCEDURES A .
Ordinary Surface Finish .
Remove all fins and projections after removing forms .
a .
Clean point and true all honeycomb spots broken corners or edges cavities made by form ties and other holes and defects .
b .
Keep all areas to receive mortar saturated with water for at least minutes before mortar placement. . Use a mortar of cement and fine aggregate for pointing not more than one hour old mixed in the proportions used in the grade of concrete being finished . .
Cure the mortar patches and rub to blend with surrounding concrete .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Tool and free all joints of mortar and concrete .
a .
Leave the full length of the joint filler exposed with clean and true edges .
B .
Rubbed Finish .
Wet the concrete surface as soon after form removal as conditions permit paint with grout and rub with a wooden float until the surface is covered with a lather of cement and water .
a .
A thin grout of one part cement one part fine sand may be used in the rubbing .
b .
Let this lather set for at least three days then rub lightly with a fine carborundum stone until smooth. . Use a mechanically operated carborundum stone to finish the surface of hardened concrete at least four days after placing .
a .
Finish in the same manner as ordinary surface finish .
Let the lather set for at least days before lightly rubbing with a fine carborundum stone until smooth. . Commercial grade rubbing mortar may be used if authorized by Engineer .
C. Wire Brush or Scrubbed Finish .
Scrub the surface with stiff wire or fiber brushes using a solution of muriatic acid one part acid four parts water as soon as forms are removed and while the concrete is relatively green. . Wash the entire surface once the scrubbing produces the desired texture .
a .
Use water mixed with percent by volume ammonium hydroxide to remove all traces of the acid .
D. Floated surface finish on flat work other than bridge decks and approach slabs .
Striking Off a .
Carefully rod and strike off the surface with a strike board following the cross sections and grades shown after compaction .
b .
Allow for camber as required .
c. Operate the strike board longitudinally or transversely and move it forward with a combined longitudinal and transverse motion so that neither end is raised from the side forms during the process .
d. Keep a slight excess of concrete in front of the cutting edge at all times . .
Floating a .
Use longitudinal or transverse floating or both to create a uniform surface .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January b. Longitudinal floating is required except in places where it is not feasible. . Longitudinal Floating a .
Work the longitudinal float operated from foot bridges with a sawing motion while holding it parallel to the road centerline .
b .
Pass gradually from one side of the pavement to the other .
Move the float forward  of its length and repeat operation .
c. Substitute machine floating if equivalent results are produced. . Transverse Floating a .
Operate the transverse float across the concrete surface by starting at the edge and slowly moving to the center and back again to the edge .
Move the float forward  of its length and repeat the operation .
b .
Preserve the crown and cross section of the concrete surface. . Straightedging a .
Test the concrete surface for trueness with a straightedge after the longitudinal floating has been completed and the excess water has been removed while the concrete is still plastic .
b. Furnish and use an accurate ft straightedge held parallel to the road centerline in contact with the surface .
c. Check the entire area immediately filling depressions with freshly mixed concrete then strike off consolidate and refinish .
d. Cut down and refinish high areas .
e. Continue the straightedge testing and refloating until the concrete surface is at the required grade and contour .
E. Floated Surface Finish for Bridge Decks and Approach Slabs .
Machine finish exposed surfaces unless otherwise permitted . .
Finish concrete by striking off and floating the surface . .
Allow the Engineer enough time to inspect finishing machines during daylight hours before concrete placement . .
Provide lighting facilities that adequately light the work area when placing and finishing operations are not completed during daylight hours . .
Extend finishing machine rails beyond both ends of the scheduled placement and allow sufficient distance to permit the float to fully clear the concrete .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Use adjustable rails set to provide the finished grade elevations shown installed to prevent springing or deflection under the weight of the finishing equipment and placed to operate without interruption over the entire surface being finished. . Place screed machine parallel to the abutments and bents within degrees. . Support screed rails to prevent movement during placing of the concrete . .
Attach a measuring device to the screed face and pass it over the area. . Place concrete in a uniform heading approximately parallel to the screed machine. . Limit the rate of placing to allow enough time to finish the surface before initial set . .
Continuously place concrete the full length of the structure or superstructure unit unless otherwise shown or authorized . .
Provide sufficient material equipment and manpower to place deck concrete at a rate of at least ydhour. . Strike off the surface to the required elevations with the finishing machine immediately after placing and consolidating the concrete. . Do not add water to the concrete in front of or behind the screed . .
Obtain authorization for the strikeoff method and equipment .
a .
Maintain satisfactory performance .
b .
Use equipment capable of finishing concrete within the surface tolerances specified .
c. Maintain satisfactory consolidation and surface tolerance to prevent shutdown and rejection of the equipment. . Furnish a ft straightedge to check the surface tolerance placed both longitudinally and transversely immediately behind the screed machine and handfinished areas . .
Correct irregularities greater than  inch from the straightedge before additional placement and immediately fill depressions with concrete and refinish. . Cut down and refinish high areas. . Continue straightedge testing and corrective measures until the entire surface is free of observable departures from the straightedge .
F. Final texturing for bridge decks and approach slabs a textured hardened finish .
Use a texture process that produces regular  inch wide transverse grooves spaced randomly from  inch to  inch on centers and  inch deep. . Keep the finished surface free from porous spots and surface irregularities .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Furnish a work bridge that follows the finishing machine to facilitate texturing and application of the curing compound . .
Check the surface smoothness for acceptance after the concrete has hardened . .
Remove irregularities by grinding if the surface deviates more than  inch from a ft straightedge .
Refer to Section .
a .
Depth of grinding must be authorized by the Engineer before any grinding operations begin . .
CONCRETE CURING A .
Refer to Section . . FORM REMOVAL A .
Obtain authorization from the Engineer before removing forms .
B .
Remove struts stays and braces that hold the forms in correct shape and alignment when no longer necessary .
C. Remove all forms from the concrete surfaces. . Do not use a method of form removal likely to cause overstressing of the concrete .
D. Remove supports to permit the concrete to uniformly and gradually take the stresses due to its own weight .
E. Do not remove forms used in ornamental work railings parapets and exposed vertical surfaces for at least twelve hours after placement .
F. Always remove forms before removing shoring from beneath beams and girders to determine the condition of columns .
G. Removing Falsework .
Do not remove falsework supporting the deck of rigid frame structures until the fill has been placed in back of the vertical legs. . Keep falsework and forms in place under slabs beams and girders for days after the day of last concrete placement .
a. Slab forms with a clear space of less than ft may be removed after seven days. . Keep forms and falsework in place in cold weather according to the authorized cold weather concreting plan .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January H. Patch formed surfaces within hours after form removal. . Cut back and remove all projecting wire or metal devices used for holding the forms in place and that pass through the body of the concrete at least inch beneath the surface of the concrete . .
Remove lips of mortar and irregularities caused by form joints . .
Fill small holes depressions and voids with cement mortar mixed in the same proportions as that used in the body of the work . .
Obtain a solid uniform surface by chipping away coarse or broken material to patch larger holes or honeycombs .
a .
Cut away feathered edges to form faces perpendicular to the surface .
b .
Apply epoxy adhesive to patch area according to manufacturers recommendations .
c. Fill the cavity with stiff mortar composed of one part portland cement to two parts sand thoroughly tamped into place .
d. Preshrink the mortar by mixing it approximately minutes .
Vary the time according to manufacturers recommendations temperature humidity and other local conditions .
e. Float the surface of this mortar with a wooden float before initial set .
f. Keep the patch wet for five days .
g. Rub patches on exposed surfaces to blend them with surrounding concrete after curing .
h. Add coarse aggregate to the patching material when patching large or deep areas .
i .
Make a dense wellbonded and properly cured patch .
I .
Areas with extensive honeycombing will be rejected .
J .
Apply the following requirements after fully removing all the closure joint forms if inserts are placed along the bottom edges of the precast concrete deck panels to form the closure pour joints .
Cut off castinplace anchors at least inch below the face of slab and repair according to this Section Article .
paragraph H. .
Fill all voids with drypack mortar flush with the bottom of slab . .
Fill voids created by the removal of reusable concrete anchors with drypack mortar flush with the bottom of slab. . Drypack mortar will be composed of one part portland cement to two parts sand .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
SUPERSTRUCTURE A. Deck Do not place parapet forms or parapet for at least seven days after deck placement and until the deck has attained the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders or leave all falsework in place and design it to carry all additional loads that are part of the parapet placement process. . Do not allow the installation of the parapet and parapet forms to interrupt the curing of the deck and approach slabs when installed before curing is complete .
B. Slab Span Place concrete in one continuous operation .
C. CastInPlace TBeams .
Place concrete in one or two continuous operations first to the top of the girder stems and second to completion unless otherwise shown . .
Obtain a bond between the stem and slab that is positive and mechanical and secured by means of shear keys or roughened surface in the top of the girder stem .
D. Do not place the approach slab until the sleeper slab concrete has been in place at least seven days or has attained percent of the specified day compressive strength based on field cured cylinders. . SUBSTRUCTURE A .
Concrete in Columns and Bent Stems .
Allow footing concrete to set until it has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders before placing column forms when column is being placed on a footing. . Place concrete in one continuous operation . .
Allow concrete to set at least two days and until it has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders before placing caps. . Do not place concrete in the superstructure until the columns have been stripped and authorized .
B. Substructure Concrete .
Do not place the superstructure load on the bents or abutments until they have been in place at least seven days and attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January C. Do not backfill abutments wingwalls and retaining walls until all concrete has been in place at least days and has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders. . Do not interfere with curing . .
BOX CULVERTS A .
Allow base slab and footing to attain percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based upon field cured cylinders before constructing the remainder of the culvert .
B. Construct side walls and top slab monolithically unless the wall height exceeds ft. . Keep the construction joints vertical and at right angles to the axis of the culvert .
C. Construct shear keys in the top of the side walls for anchoring the top slab when side walls and top slab are not placed monolithically .
D. Construct wingwalls monolithically .
E. Do not backfill until the concrete has been in place at least days and has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
F. Apply a waterproofing membrane to the top slab and side walls of all concrete box culverts for the full length of the structures. . HEADWALLS A .
Allow apron and pipe collar to attain percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders before the remainder of the headwall is constructed .
B. Construct wingwalls monolithically .
C. Do not backfill headwalls and wingwalls until all concrete has been in place at least days and has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders . .
CONCRETE SLOPE PROTECTION A .
Preparing Subgrade .
Prepare the area to be paved by smoothing and shaping the berms and slopes and excavating for the cutoff walls .
Implementation Structural Concrete Page of January .
Fill and compact subgrade Refer to Section .
a. Furnish extra material to properly finish the slopes when required .
b .
Compact all soft and yielding material resulting in a firm and substantial subgrade of uniform density . .
Thoroughly spray the area with water before placing the concrete . .
Obtain the Engineers authorization for all surfaces before placing concrete .
B .
Placing Concrete .
Do not place concrete upon spongy frozen or unstable surfaces . .
Provide concrete of a consistency that it can be placed on the slopes without deformation . .
Complete all horizontal grooves and vertical joints as shown . .
Complete the entire slope protection in one placement if possible or terminate the placement with a construction joint located in the horizontal grooves or vertical joints . .
Finish concrete using a Floated Surface Finish according to this Section Article .. C. Seal Joints and Closures Refer to . .
RETAINING WALLS A .
Allow footing concrete to set until it has attained percent of its specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders before placing wall forms .
B .
Do not backfill walls until all concrete has been in place at least days and has attained percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders. . MISCELLANEOUS CONSTRUCTION A .
Bearing Areas .
Finish bridge seat bearing areas high and rub or grind to grade level within an allowable tolerance of inch and within a tolerance of  inch of the elevation shown. . Do not grout under bearing plates. . CLEANUP A .
Remove falsework and falsework piling to ft below the finished ground line rubbish and temporary building materials before final inspection .

PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Debris Containment .
Prevent debris from falling into streams and onto pedestrian areas traffic areas and railroad tracks .
Implementation Bridge Deck Joint Closure Page of January .
REMOVE CONCRETE A .
Concrete Saw Cuts .
Saw cut concrete surface inch deep along perimeter of concrete removal area .
B .
Use jackhammer method to remove existing concrete . .
Removal of Concrete Slab Use pound class handoperated jack hammers or smaller .
a .
Use pound class handoperated jack hammer or smaller when removing concrete within inches of girders and diaphragms that are to remain . .
Operate jack hammers at an angle greater than degrees as measured from the deck surface .
C. Remove existing joint armor steel and existing joint materials .
D. Protect existing electrical conduit from damage where encountered .
E. Remove loose or fractured concrete .
F. Clean existing concrete and steel surfaces . .
REINFORCING STEEL A .
Existing Reinforcing Steel .
Thoroughly clean reinforcing steel that will remain in place of corrosion and adhering materials by sandblasting . .
Remove and replace any reinforcing steel with percent or greater section loss .
a .
Cut and remove deteriorated existing reinforcing steel bars .
b .
Match the size of the new reinforcing steel bar to the existing bar .
c. Provide lap lengths as shown .
B .
New Reinforcing Steel and Doweled Anchors .
Place reinforcing steel after sandblasting operations are complete .
Implementation Bridge Deck Joint Closure Page of January .
PLACE CONCRETE A .
Use epoxy grout to create a smooth flat uniform surface on concrete girders and diaphragms as shown . .
Cure according to manufacturers installation instructions .
B. Saturate existing concrete surfaces with water before placing concrete .
C. Form place and finish concrete according to Section .
D. Cure concrete according to the requirements for castinplace concrete closure pours in bridge decks and approach slabs in Section .

Cube Specimens E. AASHTO T Length Change of Hardened Hydraulic Cement Mortar and Concrete F. AASHTO T Resistance of Concrete to Rapid Freezing and Thawing Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January G. ASTM A Deformed and Plain LowAllow Steel Bars for Concrete Reinforcement .

DEFINITIONS A .
Working Points Identifiable points of reference between elements to be connected . .
Identified point locations provide a basis for measurement a .
The working point at the top of the foundation allows for an identifiable location for an elevation measurement for example .
B .
Working Lines Reference lines connecting working points . .
Typically oriented along the length of elements to be connected . .
Provide a basis for aligning elements located along the working line . .
Provide a reference for the verification of length between working points. . SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Detailed shop drawings of fabricated materials for review .
a .
Include the following Locations and details of lifting inserts hardware and devices .
Type and amount of additional reinforcing required for lifting .
Minimum compressive strength required before handling the precast elements .
Details of vertical adjusting hardware .
b .
Include supporting engineering calculations .
Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January .
Erection Drawings for precast concrete members for review .
a .
Include the following A work area plan depicting items such as utilities overhead and below the work area drainage inlet structures and protective measures .
Equipment to be used to lift substructure elements including cranes excavators lifting slings sling hooks and jacks .
Include crane charts crane locations and operation radii .
Equipment that will be used for the assembly of the substructure .
Methods of providing temporary support of the elements .
Include methods of adjusting and securing the element after placement .
Procedures for controlling both horizontal and vertical tolerance limits .
Include details of alignment jigs including bilevel templates for reinforcing anchor dowels .
Methods for placement of flowable bedding concrete for spread footings .
Add grout ports in the footings to facilitate the bedding process if required .
Method sequence and equipment for forming grout voids and installing the structural nonshrink grout .
Methods of forming closure pours including the use of backer rods .
Do not assume that the backer rods will restrain the pressure from the grout in vertical grout joints .
Provide additional forming to retain the backer rod .
Methods for curing grout and closure pour concrete .

Materials .

C. Structural NonShrink Grout .
Use structural nonshrink grout for joints between precast elements as shown .
a .
Use gray cementitious grout containing no calcium chloride or admixture containing calcium chloride or other ingredient in sufficient quantity to cause corrosion to steel reinforcement .
Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January b .
Use quicksetting rapid strength gain nonshrink and high bond strength grout .
c. Meet the requirements of AASHTO T with the exception that the Contractor supplied cube molds will remain intact with a top firmly attached throughout the curing period .
d. Refer to Table for structural nonshrink grout requirements .

The use of castinplace concrete will not be considered for substitution .

PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL PROCEDURE FOR INSTALLATION OF ELEMENTS A .
Follow the authorized erection drawings . .
Resubmit the drawings for review if changes are warranted due to varying site conditions .
B .
Dry fit adjacent precast elements in the shop .
C. Establish working points working lines and benchmark elevations before placing elements .
D. Check the condition of the receiving bonding surface before connecting elements remove items such as dust rust and debris according to the recommendations of the grouted splice coupler manufacturer .
E. Place elements in the sequence and according to the methods outlined in the erection drawings . .
Adjust the height of each element with leveling devices or shims .
F. Mix structural nonshrink grout just before its use according to the manufacturers instruction . .
FOUNDATIONS A .
Set foundation in the proper horizontal and vertical location . .
Check for proper alignment within tolerances as described .
B .
Adjust vertical leveling devices before full release of the element from the crane to facilitate the vertical adjustment process . .
Check for proper grade within tolerances as described .
C. Check the spacing of dowels or grouted splice couplers between adjacent foundations that are to support common elements in future stages of construction. . Use bilevel templates and jigs . .
Adjust the location of the foundation if required .
Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January D. Place bedding concrete through the ports for spread footings . . Start from the center of the footing and proceed toward the outside edges. . Verify that bedding concrete is filling the entire void between the footing and the subgrade .
E. Place concrete in voids around pile tops as shown for foundations supported on drilled shafts or piles . .
Allow this concrete to flow partially under the pile cap . .
The entire underside of the cap need not be filled with concrete .
F. Do not remove temporary supports or proceed with the installation of elements above the foundation until the compressive test result of the cylinders for bedding concrete or pile connection concrete has reached the specified minimum values . .
BENT COLUMNS A .
Survey the elevation of the element directly below the column . .
Provide shims to bring the bottom of the column to the required elevation .
B .
Measure the elevation of the top of the shim stack and the top of the projecting dowels. . Verify that the elevations and dowel extensions are within tolerances as described .
C. Check the dowel spacing or grouted splice couplers between adjacent columns that will support common elements in future stages of construction. . Use bilevel templates and jigs . .
Adjust the location of the foundation if required .
a .
Maintain vertical alignment of columns within tolerances as described .
D. Set the column in the proper horizontal location . .
Check for proper horizontal and vertical alignment within tolerances as described . .
Adjust the shims and reset the column if the column is not within tolerance .
E. Install the grouted splice couplers according to Section once the connection geometry is established and checked .
F. Install temporary bracing if required in the erection drawings .
Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January G. Allow the grout in the grouted splice coupler to cure until the grouted splice coupler can resist percent of the specified minimum yield strength of the bar before removing temporary bracing and proceeding with installation of components above the bent column . .
The required grout strength is based on the certified test report .
Refer to Section . . Verify the strength of the grout by testing cube samples .
Refer to this Section Article .B . .
BENT CAPS A .
Survey the elevation of the column directly below the cap. . Use shims to bring the bottom of the cap to the required elevation. . Measure the elevation at the top of the shim stack and the top of the projecting dowels. . Verify that the elevations and dowel extensions are within tolerances as described .
B .
Set the cap in the proper horizontal and vertical location . .
Check for proper horizontal and vertical alignment within tolerances as described . .
Remove and adjust the shims and reset the cap if the cap is not within tolerance .
C. Install the grouted splice couplers according to Section once the connection geometry is established and checked .
D. Install temporary bracing if required in the erection drawings .
E. Allow the grout in the coupler to cure until the grouted splice coupler can resist percent of the specified minimum yield strength of the bar before removing temporary bracing and proceeding with installation of components above the pier cap . .
The required grout strength is based on the certified test report .
Refer to Section . . Verify the strength of the grout by testing cube samples .
Refer to this Section Article .B. . WALL PANELS A .
Wall panels include .
Cantilever Abutment Stems .
Wingwall stems .
Integral abutment pile cap stems .
Abutment backwalls and cheekwalls Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January B .
Wall panels supported on precast concrete elements foundation or stem. . Survey the elevation of the base directly below the panel .
a .
Provide shims to bring the bottom of the panel to the required elevation .
b .
Measure the elevation of the top of the shim stack and the top of the projecting dowels .
c. Verify that the elevations and dowel extensions are within tolerances as described. . Set the panel in the proper horizontal and vertical location .
a .
Check for proper horizontal and vertical alignment within tolerances as described .
b .
Remove and adjust the shims and reset the panel if the panel is not within tolerance . .
Install the grouted splice couplers according to Section once the connection geometry is established and checked . .
Install temporary bracing if required in the erection drawings . .
Allow the grout in the coupler to cure until the grouted splice coupler can resist percent of the specified minimum yield strength of the bar before removing temporary bracing and proceeding with installation of components above the panel .
a .
The required grout strength is based on the certified test report .
Refer to Section .
b. Verify the strength of the grout by testing cube samples .
Refer to this Section Article .B. . Place concrete inside the blockouts and cure if the panels contain corrugated pipe blockouts. . Place structural nonshrink grout in joints between precast abutment and backwall segments after leveling jacks and temporary supports are removed .
a .
Do not apply additional dead loads or live loads to the precast backwall segments until the structural nonshrink grout has reached a strength of psi based on manufacturers recommendations .
C. Wall panels supported on piles or drilled shafts integral abutments. . Set the panel in the proper horizontal and vertical location .
a .
Check for proper alignment within tolerances as described . .
Adjust the leveling devices before full release from the crane if vertical leveling devices are used .
a .
This will reduce the amount of torque required to turn the bolts in the leveling devices .
b .
Check for proper grade within tolerances as described . .
Check the spacing of dowels or grouted splice couplers between adjacent panels that will support common elements in future stages of construction .
a .
The use of bilevel templates and jigs is recommended .
Implementation Precast Substructure Elements Page of January b .
Adjust the location of the panel if required. . Place concrete around pile tops as shown .
a .
Allow concrete to flow partially under the panel .
b .
The entire underside of the panel need not be filled with concrete. . Do not remove temporary supports or proceed with the installation of elements above the panel until the compressive test result of the cylinders for the pile connection concrete has reached the specified minimum values. . Place structural nonshrink grout in joints between precast abutment and backwall segments after leveling jacks and temporary supports are removed. . Do not apply additional dead loads or live loads to the precast abutment segments until the structural nonshrink grout has reached a strength of psi based on manufacturers recommendations. . PRECAST BEAM SEATS A .
Set beam seat in the proper horizontal location . .
Check for proper alignment within tolerances as described .
B .
Adjust vertical leveling devices . .
Check for proper grade within tolerances as described .
C. Install temporary bracing if required in the erection drawings .
D. Pour or pump structural nonshrink grout through the blockouts in the seat. . Start from the center of the seat and proceed toward the outside edges. . Verify that grout is filling the entire void between the seat and the substructure element below .
E. Grind beam seat to achieve the seat elevation tolerance as described if required . .
Grind to a maximum depth of  inch .

PART EXECUTION .
INSTALL WELDED SHEAR STUDS ON NEW AND EXISTING STEEL GIRDERS AND ON NEW PRECAST CONCRETE GIRDERS A .
Install welded shear studs at the locations shown .
B. Weld shear studs to steel girders or plates embedded in precast concrete girders according to AASHTOAWS D .. .
Adjust studs as necessary to provide clearance for bolts in existing bolted splices. . Use method and equipment recommended by the manufacturer of the studs. . Field weld studs using automatic end welding. . Use equipment with adequate capacity for the size of stud welded . .
INSTALL ADHESIVE DOWELED ANCHORS IN EXISTING CONCRETE OR PRECAST CONCRETE GIRDERS A .
Field drill holes in the top flange of existing concrete and precast concrete girders . .
Locate girder reinforcing steel before drilling holes. . Avoid drilling through reinforcing steel .
B .
Install anchors according to manufacturers recommendations .
Refer to Section .
Implementation FullDepth Precast Concrete Deck Panels Page of January .
PLACE PRECAST CONCRETE DECK PANELS A .
Fully brace concrete girders or steel girders before placing panels .
B .
Place the precast concrete deck panels as shown . .
The use of castinplace concrete is not an acceptable alternative for precast panels .
C. Check the grade of the deck panels after deck panels are placed and adjusted to provide the elevations shown . .
Check the grade before posttensioning of the deck panels if applicable .
D. Provide vertical adjustment in the sequence defined in the erection plan to bring panels to the elevations shown . .
Adjust vertical adjusting hardware to within percent of each other to provide proper distribution of panel weight to the supporting girders .
E. Prevent shifting of the precast concrete deck panels during the joining of the deck panels after the proper grade is achieved. . LONGITUDINAL POSTTENSIONING A .
Cure precast panels days before tensioning postinstalled cables or rods unless otherwise noted .
B .
Clean and remove debris from blockouts .
C. Grout shear key between panels .
D. Do not begin stressing operations until the concrete reaches the strength and age designated on the plans . .
Stress strands within hours of transverse joint grouting .
E. Do not posttension until the shear key grout has attained a compressive strength of psi based on manufacturers data .
F. Install strands as shown .
G. Fully tension strand and grout ducts according to Section . .
Complete posttensioning before grouting girder camber strips and shear stud grout pockets .
Implementation FullDepth Precast Concrete Deck Panels Page of January .
INSTALLATION OF HEADED T BARS AND ANCHORS A .
Install according to Section . .
PREPARATION AND INSTALLATION OF STRUCTURAL NONSHRINK GROUT A .
Clean and remove debris from the camber strips and blockouts before placing the structural nonshrink grout .
B .
Keep bonding surfaces free from laitance dirt dust paint grease oil rust or contaminant other than water .
C. Form the girder camber strips as shown after installing shear studs at the locations shown .
D. Pretest grout material installation under field conditions in a grout pocket and camber strip mockup to determine grout flowability and whether subsequent cracking will occur .
Include in the mockup at least two shear stud pockets and a camber strip that is the same configuration as the actual bridge . .
The Engineer may determine modifications to the grouting process . .
Proceed with grouting process as modified by the Engineer .
E. Saturate surface dry SSD surfaces receiving structural nonshrink grout .
F. Mix and place structural nonshrink grout following manufacturers recommendations for preparation and installation . .
Mix structural nonshrink grout just before use according to the manufacturers instructions .
G. Grout the girder camber strips using structural nonshrink grout. . Place structural nonshrink grout in the girder camber strips in a continuous operation within a panel .
H. Grout the shear stud blockouts using structural nonshrink grout . .
Structural nonshrink grout in the shear stud blockouts can be placed as part of the placement of the structural nonshrink grout in the girder camber strips .
I .
Do not allow voids in the grout for the girder camber strips and shear stud blockouts .
Implementation FullDepth Precast Concrete Deck Panels Page of January J .
Do not apply superimposed dead loads or live loads to the precast concrete deck panels until the structural nonshrink grout in the shear stud blockouts and the girder camber strips has reached a strength of psi based on manufacturers published data .
K. Fill surface voids with nonshrink grout including lifting device blockouts and grout ports .
L. Texture top surface of grouted blockouts and voids according to Section for bridge decks .
M. Cure structural nonshrink grout according to manufacturers recommendation .
N. Finish grout flush or a maximum of  inch above adjacent panels . .
Correct blockout and void profiles in excess of  inch higher than the adjacent panel through surface grinding . .
Remove and replace blockouts and voids for profiles finished below top of adjacent panels. . DECK GRINDING A .
Profile grind the deck and approach slabs according to Section after panels are in place grouting and closure pours are complete and the specified minimum day compressive strength is achieved .

DEFINITIONS A .
Approach Slab A structural slab that is designed to span from the rear face of the abutment to the sleeper slab .
The purpose of approach slabs is to span over potential settlement of the bridge abutment backfill .
The soil under the slab is not intended to support the slab .
Support is provided by the bridge abutment and the sleeper slab .
B. Sleeper Slab A structural slab that is designed as a transition from the approach slab to the approach roadway pavement .
The sleeper slab bears directly on the subgrade and supports the end of the approach slab .
The expansion joint between the sleeper slab and the approach slab is used to accommodate the thermal movement of the bridge. . SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Shop drawings of fabricated materials for review .
a .
Include the following Locations and details of lifting inserts hardware or devices .
Type and amount of additional reinforcing required for lifting .
Locations and details of vertical adjusting hardware .
Minimum compressive strength required before handling the precast elements .
Implementation Precast Approach Slabs Page of January b .
Provide the seal of a Professional Engineer PE or Professional Structural Engineer SE licensed in the State of Utah .
c. Include supporting engineering calculations .
B .

The warranty period starts on the date of Substantial Completion .

D. Structural NonShrink Grout .
Use structural nonshrink grout for bedding under the approach slab at the sleeper slab support as shown .
a .
Use gray nonshrink grout concrete containing no calcium chloride or admixture containing calcium chloride or other ingredient in sufficient quantity to cause corrosion to steel reinforcement .
b .
Use quicksetting rapid strength gain nonshrink and high bond strength grout .
c. Use a grout that is flowable .
d. Meet the requirements of AASHTO T with the exception that the Contractor supplied cube molds will remain intact with a top firmly attached throughout the curing period .
e. Refer to Table for structural nonshrink grout requirements .

Length Change No expansion after days T Certified test results from an AASHTO accredited testing laboratory will suffice for acceptance .

PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION OF SLEEPER SLABS AND APPROACH SLABS A .
General .
Establish working points working lines and benchmark elevations before placing elements . .
Check the condition of the receiving bonding surface before connecting elements and remove items such as dust rust and debris to provide the satisfactory bonding required .
B. Sleeper Slabs .
Place sleeper slab elements as shown .
a .
Adjust the height of each element with leveling devices or shims . .
Lift sleeper slab segments using lifting devices as shown in the shop drawings. . Set sleeper slab in the proper horizontal location .
a .
Check for proper alignment and grade within shown tolerances . .
Adjust sleeper slabs before full release from the crane to facilitate the vertical adjustment process .
a .
Check for proper grade within shown tolerances. . Pour or pump bedding concrete through the ports .
a .
Start from the center of the sleeper slab and proceed toward the outside edges .
Implementation Precast Approach Slabs Page of January b. Verify that bedding concrete is filling the entire void between the sleeper slab and the subgrade. . Do not remove the installation bolts or proceed with the installation of the approach slab until the compressive test result of the cylinders for bedding concrete has reached the specified minimum values . .
Install bond breaker materials in two layers as shown .
a. Seal the edges and joints to prevent concrete or mortar from penetrating the interface between the two sheets .
Duct tape is acceptable for this purpose .
C. Approach Slabs .
Lift approach slab using lifting devices as shown in the shop drawings. . Set approach slab in the proper horizontal location .
a .
Check for proper alignment and grade within shown tolerances. . Survey the top elevation of the approach slab . .
Adjust vertical leveling devices before full release of the approach slab from the crane .
This will reduce the amount of torque required to turn the bolts in the leveling devices .
a .
Check for proper grade within shown tolerances . .
Prevent shifting of the precast approach slab panels during installation. . Clean and remove debris from the areas that will be grouted before placing the approach slab. . Keep bonding surfaces free from laitance dirt dust paint grease oil rust and other contaminants .
D. Place Grout .
Mix structural nonshrink grout just before use according to the manufacturers instructions. . Pretest grout material installation under field conditions in a similar void mockup before construction of the approach slab to determine grout flowability .
Include in the mockup at least two fill ports that are of the same configuration as the actual bridge .
a .
The Engineer may determine modifications to the grouting process .
b .
Proceed with grouting process as modified by the Engineer. . Saturate Surface Dry SSD surfaces receiving structural non shrink grout. . Place product following the manufacturers recommendations for installation. . Texture top surface of grouted blockouts according to Section for approach slabs .
Implementation Precast Approach Slabs Page of January .
Do not apply superimposed dead loads or live loads to the precast approach slabs until the structural nonshrink grout has reached a strength of at least psi or manufacturers recommendations . .
Cure structural nonshrink grout according to manufacturers recommendations .
E. Place Foam .
Pump high density polyurethane foam under the end of the approach slab as shown .
a .
Start from the center of the approach slab and proceed toward the outside edges or start from one end and proceed continuously to the other end .
b .
Check that high density polyurethane foam is filling the entire void between the approach slab and the sleeper slab .
F. Joint Extrusions .
Set prefabricated joint extrusions as shown. . GRINDING A .
Profile grind the approach slab according to Section after panels are in place grouting is complete closure pours are complete and the specified minimum day compressive strength is achieved .

INSTALLATION A .

DEFINITIONS A. Polymer Overlay System A thin bonded polymer overlay applied as a wearing surface consisting of a twopart polymer resin broadcasted with aggregate to refusal before it cures .
B. Installer The entity preparing the surface and installing and finishing the polymer overlay system .
C. Provider The manufacturer furnishing the polymer overlay system. . SUBMITTALS A .
Provider Qualifications for review at least calendar days before ordering material . .
Include at least the following a .
Company name .
b .
Name and phone number of the Providers Technical Support Representative .
c. List of projects using the submitted products with at least two years of satisfactory performance under similar environmental conditions as the project in which it is to be applied .
Refer to this Section Article .
B .
List the following for each project Project name Bridge locations state routes and bridge identifiers Scope of work Products used Approximate date of the system opening to traffic .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January B .
Materials .
The following information at least calendar days before ordering material a .
Manufacturers Product Data Sheets and recommended installation instructions .
b .
Material Safety Data Sheets .
c. The Providers certification stating that the provider is the sole provider of the components of the polymer overlay system and that the components are In accordance with this Section .
Fully compatible with one another .
d. The Installers certification with the Providers written concurrence that the polymer overlay system is fully compatible with all deck repair materials. . Certified test report from an independent nationally recognized laboratory stating that the polymer resins in the polymer overlay system components meet the requirements in this Section .
a .
Test results must be from within a three year period of the submittal. . Certified Test Report from an AASHTO accredited testing laboratory confirming the compliance of the aggregate material with the test requirements of this Section .
a .
Test results must be from within a one year period of the submittal .
C. Method for mixing of the polymer resins .
The Providers written concurrence that the selected mixing method is acceptable and compatible with the polymer overlay system. . Mixing ratio of the polymer resins .
D. A warranty letter to the Engineer and the Department Bridge Management Engineer stating that the Contractor guarantees the polymer overlay system against material and installation defects incurred under traffic for a period of years . .
The guarantee period starts on the date of Physical Completion . .
Include in the letter a .
State Project Designation b .
State Project Name c. State Structure Numbers d. Contractor Provider and Installer Name .
Defects performance failures include a. Spalling Broken or missing pieces of polymer overlay system .
b .
Scaling Visible exposed rough surface texture resulting from a loss of aggregate or resin .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January c. Delamination Visible or audible debonding of the polymer overlay system at the bond line interface with the existing bridge receiving surface .
d. Cracking Visible cracks not reflected from a crack in the existing deck .
e. Loss of skid resistance Skid resistance less than as measured according to ASTM E . .
The guarantee covers percent of the polymer overlay system materials and installation costs . .
Removal and replacement of the polymer overlay system for failed sections . .
The Department will notify the Contractor of defects to be repaired during the guarantee period .
a .
Submit detailed plans and procedures of corrective work according to Providers recommendations and obtain the Departments authorization before commencing work .
b .
Perform corrective work within days of notification. . QUALITY CONTROL A .
Technical Support Representative .
Provide a Technical Support Representative from the Provider onsite during surface preparation and application of the polymer overlay system on the first day the polymer overlay system is installed on a structure .
a .
The Technical Support Representative must have a minimum of years of experience with the system and with guiding and assisting installers in the polymer overlay system installation .
b .
The Technical Support Representative will instruct the workers in proper mixing application technique safety precautions traffic opening time and environmental requirements .
c. The Technical Support Representative must be available for consultation but not necessarily present at the job site for the remaining work . .
The Department reserves the right to require the Technical Support Representative to be onsite if at any time the Engineer is concerned with the product installation quality .
B .
Prior Performance .
The selected polymer overlay system must have at least two years of satisfactory performance for noninterstate use and four years of satisfactory performance for interstate use in similar environmental conditions as the project in which it will be applied .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January .
Products without the required years of prior satisfactory performance will only be considered for use with approval .
a .
Do not use for bidding purposes . .
DELIVERY STORAGE AND HANDLING A. Polymer Resin .
Identify the containers as Part A and Part B and plainly mark with a .
Manufacturers name b .
Manufacturers address c. Name of the product d. Mixing proportions and instructions e. Lot and batch numbers f. Date of manufacture g. Quantity .
Transport to and store on the job site in a dry weather protected environment away from moisture and within the maintained temperature range of to degrees F and according to Providers recommended installation instructions .
B .
Broadcast Aggregate .
Store aggregate in a clean dry location protected from rain and other moisture sources . .
Protect the aggregate from contaminants on the job site .
C. Handling Liquid Materials .
Use protective gloves clothing boots and goggles when directly exposed to the material . .
Provide manufacturers safety data sheets to workers and inspectors .

Use a diamond tipped grinder or approved method to remove an existing polymer overlay system from the deck .
B. Metered Mixing .
Use equipment capable of metering mixing and distributing the polymer resin .
a .
Use equipment that features positive displacement volumetric metering pumps controlled by a hydraulic power unit .
b .
Use motionless inline mixing. . Use equipment that is approved by the Provider .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January C. Hand Mixing .
Use equipment that is approved by the Provider .
D. Broadcasting Aggregate .
Use mechanical equipment capable of dispensing the aggregate onto the deck in a uniform manner as required by the Provider .
PART EXECUTION .
POLYMER OVERLAY REMOVAL A .
Remove the existing polymer overlay as shown or as required by the Engineer. . Do not damage concrete deck when removing polymer overlay . .
SURFACE PREPARATION A .
Surface Defects .
Repair deck surface defects before installing the polymer overlay system .
a .
Use a concrete repair material that meets Providers recommendations and is compatible with the polymer overlay system being used .
b .
Use concrete repair materials free of magnesium phosphate .
B. ShotBlasting .
Clean the entire concrete deck surface with steel shot blast to remove oil dirt rubber and other materials that may be detrimental to the polymer overlay bonding and curing according to the Providers recommendations .
a .
Use sandblasting equipment or mechanical grinders only in areas that can not be reached with steel shotblasting .
Sandblast or grind before shotblasting .
Refer to ASTM D . . Produce a surface relief that meets the International Concrete Repair Institute ICRI Surface Preparation CSP .
C. Traffic .
Do not allow traffic on the deck that has been shotblasted. . Only allow the polymer overlay system equipment on cleaned surfaces .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January .
APPLICATION A .
Concrete Surface .
Complete deck repairs and surface preparation before applying the polymer overlay system. . Clean the concrete surface and apply a penetrating crack filler as required by the Provider. . Do not apply the polymer overlay system when it has rained within hours or is expected to rain within hours of application. . Verify the moisture content in the concrete substrate does not exceed .
percent when measured by an electronic meter . .
Apply the polymer overlay system only when the deck and ambient air temperature is a minimum degrees F and rising. . Verify that treated surfaces are dry at the time of second application .
B. Mixing .
Measure and mix the polymer resin components as recommended by the Provider .
a .
Maintain mix ratios according to the Providers recommendations . .
Mix polymer resin immediately before dispensing. . Verify the mix ratio by volumetric sampling at the beginning of the application mid operation and at the end of the application of each layer .
a .
Use containers with graduated markings with not less than gallon capacity .
b .
Remove the static mixer and dispense each component into separate containers .
Dispense at least five gallons of the primary component for ratio comparison .
Uncontaminated samples may be returned to the reservoirs they were originally dispensed from .
c. The Engineer or Technical Support Representative may request additional sampling .
C. First and Second Layers of Overlay .
Evenly distribute the polymer resin on the clean dry deck surface at the rate recommended by the Provider .
a .
Use new notched squeegees inch minimum on the first lift of every application to verify sufficient thickness of the overlay .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January D. Overlay Thickness .
Provide the number of layers and application rates of the liquid in each layer according to the Providers recommendations . .
Provide a total overlay thickness of at least inch .
E. Time Limits for Broadcast Aggregate .
Use the following maximum time allowed after application of liquid before broadcasting the aggregate in Table unless directed otherwise by the Provider .
Table Time Limits Temperature Maximum Time Above F minutes F to F minutes F to F minutes F to F minutes F to F minutes F. Broadcasting Aggregate .
Broadcast the aggregate before the polymer begins to gel .
a .
Cover the surface until no wet spots remain. . Drop the aggregate vertically so the level of the liquid is not disturbed .
G. Remove Excess Aggregate .
Completely remove excess and loose aggregate after the overlay has hardened by vacuum or with compressed air before applying subsequent layers according to the Providers recommendations .
Refer to ASTM D . .
Aggregate may be reused for subsequent lifts if it is removed directly into containers screened to required gradation and stored free of contaminants .
H. Longitudinal Joints in the Overlay .
Stagger and overlap joints between successive layers to inches so that no ridges appear between two adjacent lanes . .
Maintain straight construction joints between adjacent placements and lifts .
I .
Traffic .
Do not allow vehicles on the polymer overlay while it is curing .
Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January .
Allow traffic on the final layer or in between layers after the resin has cured as determined by the Provider and after removal of excess and loose aggregate .
a. Brush blast the surface with shot blast according to the Providers recommendations before applying additional layers when traffic has been allowed on the cured surface between layers .
J .
Work performed contrary to the Technical Support Representatives instructions will be deemed nonconforming . .
LIMITATIONS A .
New Bridge Decks and Approach Slabs .
Cure newly placed concrete for at least calendar days before beginning installation of polymer overlay system .
B. Bridges constructed offline and moved into their final location by self propelled modular transporters SPMT .
Apply the polymer overlay system no sooner than calendar days after setting the bridge in its final location .
C. Prevent material and debris from falling into streams pedestrian areas live traffic or railroad tracks. . POLYMER OVERLAY REPAIR A .
Locate and mark visible polymer overlay repair areas as shown and in the presence of the Engineer. . Sound the polymer overlay around repair area for delamination of the polymer overlay to determine repair limits. . Square off the edges of polymer overlay system repair area six inches beyond the determined limits and parallel to the travel lane . .
Saw cut the perimeter of polymer overlay system repair area with a  inch deep saw cut .
B .
Remove existing polymer overlay within the repair area according to this Section Article .. . Sound the concrete deck in the repair area for delamination of the concrete deck to determine the need for structural pothole patching .
Refer to ASTM D . Implementation Thin Bonded Polymer Overlay Page of January C. Prepare the deck surface within the repair area according to this Section Article .. . Do not substitute sandblasting or mechanical grinding where shot blasting is required .
D. Apply the polymer overlay system within the repair area according to this Section .

DEFINITIONS A. Deflection Change Elevation change of the ends of a span relative to its midspan .
B. Embedded Items Scuppers manholes anchor bolts or fixtures for bearings barriers lightpoles signs utilities similar appurtenances and posttensioning components whether permanent or temporary .
C. Twist Measurement of the upward or downward deflection of one bridge corner relative to the plane defined concurrently by the elevations of the other three bridge corners. . SUBMITTALS A .
Contract Plan Revisions for approval . .
Provide revised plans detailing dimensional structural and other physical changes to the permanent structure necessitated by the construction methods. . Design and detail changes according to the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications and the UDOT Structures Design and Detailing Manual SDDM . .

Summary of revisions and evaluation .
b .

Implementation Move Bridge Page of January c. Documentation of reductions in load carrying capacity .

and the load carrying capacity of the structure is reduced .

will not be accepted .

a Base the CG and weight on actual known component dimensions and known material densities .

a On the controlling axle line .
b On the controlling vertical jack .
Maximum vertical load demands and capacity of the weakest component in the vertical load path .
Show the number of wheels or axles in each hydraulic group and the geometry of the wheels or axle lines in each hydraulic group .
a Use of at least hydraulic groups is required .
Anticipated maximum stroke requirements .
Implementation Move Bridge Page of January Stability limits including but not limited to the maximum longitudinal and transverse grades along the path and the maximum permitted longitudinal and transverse grades based on system properties .

GENERAL REQUIREMENTS A .
Move the bridge to its final location without damage and loss of strength .
B .
Use methods and procedures that provide adequate safety to the general public during .
Construction activities .
Structure move .
Erection C. Use heavy lift equipment and falsework placed over or adjacent to traveled roadways navigational or recreational waterways pedestrian facilities and any existing commercial industrial or other facilities. . Implementation Move Bridge Page of January .
PREPARATION FOR BRIDGE MOVE A .
Safety and Communication .
Review the authorized Safety and Communication Plans with all personnel involved with the bridge move .
a .
Include at least the engineer of record safety supervisor heavy lift engineer contractors engineer resident engineer and Structures Division representative . .
Conduct a safety meeting immediately before the bridge move to address unforeseen variable factors with all personnel involved .
B .
Heavy Lift System such as jacking cribbing raising and lowering .
Follow the authorized Lifting Transporting and Setting Plan for jacking cribbing raising and lowering the bridge .
a. Adhere to the limitations for jacking with regard to corresponding stability conditions for the heavy lift system and falsework . .
Implement Contingency Plan in the event of a major breakdown or equipment malfunction. . BRIDGE LIFTING TRANSPORTING AND SETTING A .
Follow the authorized Lifting Transporting and Setting Plan .
B .
Do not lift or attempt to move the bridge until it has attained a minimum age of days since the last casting operation and has attained the specified day minimum compressive strength unless otherwise authorized .
C. Monitor the bridge during lifting transporting and setting according to the authorized Monitoring Plan . .
Provide a monitoring system capable of the following a .
Measuring the change in bridge camber at initial lift .
b .
Measuring the relative twist between adjacent lines of supports at initial lift and during the move .
c. Measuring the relative change in elevation between adjacent lines of support at initial lift and during the bridge move .
This measurement is not required for bridges moved with two lines of supports .
d. Indicating when bridge measurements exceed warning levels and absolute limit levels. . Take and record measurements at least as follows a .
Before beginning the move Set the move monitoring system .
Implementation Move Bridge Page of January Monitor the bridge through a typical daily temperature cycle using the monitoring system used during the move .
a Record measurements just before dawn of each day and when the bridge reaches the approximate maximum temperature .
b .
Immediately before the initial lift .
Record the initial measurements .
a Initial measurements establish the baseline condition of the bridge .
c. Immediately after the initial lift .
Record measurements and compare the bridge to the baseline condition .
Calculate the deflection change as the difference between the condition just before to just after the initial lifting of the bridge .
Verify that measurements are within tolerance limits .
d. During the bridge move Continuously monitor the bridge .
e. When the bridge is aligned and ready for setting but is not in contact with the final supports .
f. After setting the bridge in its permanent location .
Record a final set of monitoring system measurements .
Verify that measurements are within anticipated and allowable tolerance limits specified for permanent elevations .
D. Limit deflection change twist and other measurements to the limits defined in the authorized Monitoring Plan . .
SETTING TOLERANCES A. Bridge Alignment Location and Clearances .
Comply with the following for the final condition of the span after move a .
Do not exceed inch maximum deviation at each end of span from overall longitudinal alignment of an individual span after setting .
b .
Do not exceed inch maximum deviation from overall transverse location for example for longitudinal position at each line of bearings .
Implementation Move Bridge Page of January c. Limit the maximum alignment deviation in both primary plan directions at each end of the span or spans being set to not more than inch or to that required for the accommodation of manufactured expansion joint components and bearings whichever is less .
d. Keep individual elements or surfaces within inch of location with respect to similar matching surfaces at expansion joints such as plane of web or parapet of adjacent spans bent or abutment features in the absence of other constraints .
B. Bridge Bearings Elevation and Location .
Keep the elevations of the bridge bearings for the prefabricated bridge within plus or minus inch of required elevations unless tighter tolerances are required in the plans and the authorized shop drawings. . Keep the plan location of bridge bearings with respect to the girders within the limits shown and the authorized bearing shop drawings . .
Address elevation and plan location deviations that do not meet the tolerances according to the authorized Lifting Transporting and Setting Plan .
C. Expansion Joints .
Keep the elevations and alignments of surfaces of adjacent spans to accommodate expansion joint devices within plus or minus inch of dimensioned locations unless tighter tolerances are required according to the expansion joint manufacturer or as shown and in authorized expansion joint shop drawings . .
Address deviations that do not meet the tolerances according to the authorized Lifting Transporting and Setting Plan. . BRIDGE ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION A. Visually inspect the bridge and substructure in the presence of the Engineer post move and before opening bridge to traffic. . Identify spalling and cracking that requires repair .
a .
Indicate whether the repair must be completed before opening to traffic or if the repair can be completed at a later date .
B .
Repair spalling .
Refer to Section .
Implementation Move Bridge Page of January C. Repair cracks .

QUALITY CONTROL A .
Technical Support Representative .
Provide a Technical Support Representative from the Provider onsite during surface preparation and application of the HMWM resin treatment on the first day the HMWM resin treatment is used on a structure .
a .
The Technical Support Representative must instruct the workers in proper mixing application technique safety precautions traffic opening time and environmental requirements .
b .
The Technical Support Representative must be available for consultation but not necessarily present at the job site for the remaining work . .
The Engineer may waive the requirement for the Technical Support Representative to be onsite if the Installer can demonstrate that the Installers superintendent for the work has performed at least five satisfactory applications of the HMWM resin treatment on similar bridges in similar environments .
a .
The Technical Support Representative must be available for consultation throughout the duration of the application .
b .
The Department reserves the right to require the Technical Support Representative to be onsite if at any time the Engineer is concerned with the product installation quality. . HANDLING STORAGE AND DELIVERY A .
Ship and store the materials away from one another in a manner that prevents leakage and spillage from one container to contact other containers .
B .
Store materials in original containers according to the Providers requirements and with manufacturers label . .
Include on label manufacture date batch number trade name brand and quantity .
C. Store sufficient quantities of HMWM resin treatment materials according to the Providers requirements .
