PART EXECUTION .
SURFACE PREPARATION A .
Do not begin surface preparation until skid resistance testing has been performed .
B. ShotBlasting .
Clean the concrete surface by automatic shotblasting .
Remove all traces of curing compound laitance grease dirt dust salt oil asphalt paint striping coating or foreign materials .
a .
Use a cleaning unit equipped with a dust collector that recycles the abrasives .
b .
Do not gouge the surface during shotblasting operations .
c. Collect and dispose of the removed concrete surfacing .
d. Clean the surface and cracks with oil free compressed air .
Refer to ASTM D . C. Perform additional surface preparation if recommended by the Technical Support Representative .
D. Cover deck joints plug deck drains and scuppers seal cracks on underside of deck and use other protective measures to protect waterways and bridge components. . E. Do not allow traffic on the deck that has been shotblasted .
Implementation Bridge Deck Methacrylate Resin Treatment Page of January .
INSTALLATION A .
Install according to the requirements in this Section . .
Follow the Providers recommendations that are more stringent than the requirements listed in this Section .
B .
The deck surface must be dry at the time of HMWM resin treatment .
C. Pretreat visible cracks by filling the cracks and keeping them full. . Prefill large cracks wider than inch with sand before applying resin . .
Treat crack by ponding resin over the crack for between and minutes allowing gravity to feed material into the crack. . Repeat ponding procedure until each crack is sealed .
D. Mix the HMWM resin components according to the Providers requirements and apply the resin to the deck within five minutes of completing mixing .
E. Evenly distribute the HMWM resin on the clean dry deck surface at the Providers recommended rate but not greater than ftgal . .
Application rates may vary depending on field conditions .
a. Texture and absorption of the surface will determine final coverage rates .
b .
The Technical Support Representative will assist the Installer in determining application rates . .
Apply the HMWM resin to refusal. . Redistribute excess material using squeegees or brooms .
F. Broadcast silica sand mechanically over the entire treated area of the bridge deck to obtain a visually uniform coverage of at least .
lbyd . .
Apply the sand before the resin gels . .
Remove excess sand if required by the Technical Support Representative . .
Remove all loose sand that has accumulated along the face of the parapets in deck drains and expansion joints at least calendar days after opening the HMWM resin treatment to traffic .
G. Apply the material in the morning and evening hours when the temperatures are lower and the cracks are at their most open point . .
LIMITATIONS A .
Do not use material after the original shelf life date .
Implementation Bridge Deck Methacrylate Resin Treatment Page of January B .
Cure concrete in new bridge decks for at least days after placement before applying the HMWM resin treatment .
C. Do not apply resin within hours after a rain or when more than percent probability of rain is forecast within hours following the application .
D. Conduct the work in a continuous operation with the HMWM resin treatment application immediately following surface preparation .
E. Apply HMWM resin treatment only if the deck surface temperature and the air temperature are between degrees F and degrees F and the weather forecast shows air temperatures will remain within that range for at least twelve hours after the application is complete .
F. Do not permit traffic on the treated surface until the silica sand cover adheres sufficiently to prevent tracking. . FIELD QUALITY CONTROL A .
The Department will measure the skid resistance according to ASTM E before and after the application of the HMWM resin treatment to verify that the HMWM resin treatment meets the requirements in Table . .
Coordinate with the Engineer to schedule the skid resistance testing at least weeks before needing the skid resistance test results .
Table Skid Resistance Test Results Before Application After Application Before Application B. Reapply the HMWM resin and the silica sand if the skid resistance test results after application do not meet the requirements in Table .

Implementation Concrete Curing Page of January PART PRODUCTS .
CURING COMPOUND A .
Refer to this Section Part Tables and .
B .
Limit Volatile Organic Compounds VOC content to grams liter maximum .
PART EXECUTION .
CURING MEASURES A .
Prevent drying of exposed concrete surfaces after placing concrete and until applying the selected curing method. . Keep exposed concrete surfaces moist by fogging if the surfaces begin to dry before the selected curing method can be applied .
B .
Cure newly placed concrete to prevent loss of water by one or more of the following methods according to this Section. . FormsinPlace Method FIPM a .
Cure formed surfaces of concrete by retaining the forms in place without loosening for the specified curing period .
b .
Complete the cure using one of the methods specified for the element when forms are removed before completing the specified curing period. . Water Method WM a .
Keep concrete surfaces continuously wet by ponding spraying or covering with materials that are continuously and thoroughly wet .
Acceptable materials for covering concrete surfaces include cotton mats multiple layers of burlap or other materials that retain water .
Secure the cover materials to prevent wind or other forces from removing them .
Keep the cover materials saturated throughout the curing period .
b .
Do not erode or damage the finish .
c. Prevent excess water from impacting traffic on inservice roadways .
Implementation Concrete Curing Page of January .
Liquid MembraneCuring Compound Method LMCCM a .
Thoroughly seal exposed concrete surfaces with a liquid membranecuring compound immediately after finishing operations are completed for exposed concrete surfaces or immediately after forms are removed and necessary patching is complete when forms are removed before the end of the curing period .
b .
Apply liquid membranecuring compound uniformly at the rates specified in Tables and .
c. Immediately repair damage to the curing compound film during the specified curing period by respraying. . Waterproof Cover Method WCM a .
Exposed concrete surfaces must be wet before installing cover .
b .
Cover exposed concrete surfaces with a material that prevents moisture loss from the concrete .
Do not use materials that have lost their waterproof qualities .
Secure cover to prevent displacement by wind .
c. Use this method only when the covering can be secured adequately to prevent moisture loss .
d. Maintain the air temperature beneath the cover at not less than degrees F. The use of insulated blankets is permitted . .
Steam or RadiantHeat Method SRHM a .
Use only for precast concrete members manufactured in prequalified plants .
b .
Use a complete steam or radiant heat curing system that includes hour temperature control and monitoring devices .
Use temperature recording devices as necessary to verify that temperatures are uniform throughout the enclosure and within the limits specified .
c. Steam Heat Curing System Use a suitable enclosure to contain live steam and minimize moisture and heat losses .
Use lowpressure and saturated steam .
Maintain to percent relative humidity in the curing enclosure .
Do not apply heat directly on the concrete or cause localized high temperatures .
d. Radiant Heat Curing System Apply heat by means of pipes circulating steam hot oil or hot water or by electric heating elements .
Use a suitable enclosure to contain the heat .
Implementation Concrete Curing Page of January Minimize moisture loss by covering exposed concrete surfaces with plastic sheeting .
e. Waiting Period Do not apply the initial application of heat before the initial set of the concrete except to maintain the minimum temperature within the curing enclosure .
Maintain the temperature within the curing enclosure at not less than degrees F. a Live steam or radiant heat may be used to maintain the curing enclosure at the proper minimum temperature .
b Keep the concrete wet during this period .
f. Curing Period Increase the temperature within the concrete during the initial application of heat at an average rate not to exceed degrees F per hour until the curing temperature is reached .
Do not exceed a concrete temperature of degrees F when applying heat .
Maintain the concrete temperature at between degrees F and degrees F. Maintain the curing temperature until the concrete achieves the specified strength for terminating the curing .
Decrease the concrete temperature at a rate not to exceed degrees F per hour until reaching a temperature of not more than degrees F above the air temperature to which the concrete will be exposed when discontinuing heat .
g. Transfer the stressing force to the concrete immediately after discontinuing steam curing or radiant heat curing for prestressed members .
C. Prevent exposed concrete surfaces from drying when transitioning between curing methods .
D. Fogging .
Use fogging when necessary to prevent drying of exposed concrete surfaces. . Use fogging equipment with compressed air misters that atomize the water and produce a very fine mist and not a spray .
a .
Use equipment that allows for adjusting the rate of fogging depending on the conditions that are present .
b .
Maintain misters at least ft above the concrete surface and aimed in a direction not lower than horizontal .
Implementation Concrete Curing Page of January c. Do not use fogging to apply excess water to the concrete surface to aid finishing .
d. Do not affect the watercement ratio of the concrete .
e. Discontinue fogging when a fine coating of water or sheen is visible on the concrete surface. . Do not damage the concrete surface .
E. Follow the hot and cold weather limitations according to Section . . CURING COMPOUND APPLICATION A .
Comply with the following when applying liquid membranecuring compound to structural elements in bridges box culverts headwalls retaining walls concrete drainage structures and concrete slope protection. . Do not use curing compounds on surfaces that require a rubbed finish or on surfaces of construction joints against which new concrete will be cast unless approved .
a .
Completely remove the curing compound before casting new concrete against the surface when curing compound is allowed. . Do not use curing compounds on architectural surfaces that require a concrete coating or penetrating concrete sealer and where removal will diminish the texture .
B .
Preparation .
Verify concrete surfaces are ready for curing .
a .
Complete all patching and surface finishing before applying curing compound . .
Prepare concrete surfaces and apply curing compound according to product manufacturers recommendations .
Refer to Tables and for application rates. . Keep surfaces moist until the curing compound is applied . .
CURE CASTINPLACE CONCRETE A .
Cure all formed surfaces using the FIPM .
B .
Cure exposed surfaces of newly placed castinplace concrete according to the curing methods and curing periods in Table . .
Determine the concrete compressive strength using field cured cylinders cured the same as the concrete member when compressive strength is used to determine the curing period .
The curing period is the specified number of consecutive days when compressive strength is not used to determine the curing period .

Specified curing methods apply to exposed concrete surfaces and any formed surfaces where the forms are removed before the curing period ends .
fc specified day minimum compressive strength .
The curing period for bridge elements that use high early strength concrete may be reduced to the greater of days and the time required to achieve the specified day minimum compressive strength .
Refer to Section for when the use of high early strength concrete is permitted .
Use a curing compound meeting ASTM C when removal is required .
Implementation Concrete Curing Page of January C. Bridge Decks and Approach Slabs .
Cure the exposed surfaces of newly placed concrete bridge decks and approach slabs for the specified curing period by a combination of the liquid membranecuring compound method and the water method . .
Apply membranecuring compound so that no portion of the deck or approach slab is exposed to the atmosphere for more than minutes after the tining or finishing operation .
a .
Use a work bridge that follows immediately after the finishing machine to allow application of the curing compound while the concrete is still plastic. . Cover the entire exposed surface of bridge decks approach slabs curbs and sidewalks as soon as the concrete is sufficiently set to support the materials .
Refer to this Section Article .
for water method requirements .
D. Concrete Barrier .
Broom clean the formed surfaces of the barrier after removing forms . .
Apply curing compound to exposed concrete surfaces immediately after finishing operations are completed . .
CURE PRECAST CONCRETE A .
Cure all formed surfaces using the FIPM .
B .
Cure exposed surfaces of newly placed precast concrete according to the curing methods and curing periods in Table . .
Determine the concrete compressive strength using field cured cylinders cured the same as the concrete member when compressive strength is used to determine the curing period .
The curing period is the specified number of consecutive days when compressive strength is not used to determine the curing period .

Manufacturers product data sheets and recommended installation instructions .
B .

PART PRODUCTS .
PENETRATING CONCRETE SEALERS A .
Choose from the following list .
Silane .
Siloxane .
Silicate .
Siliconate .
Organo Silane Ester .
Styrene Acrylic Copolymer .
Organo Siloxane .
Alkylalkoxy Siloxane .
Alkylalkoxy Silane Implementation Penetrating Concrete Sealer Page of January B .
Meet VOC content of gL or less for Reactive Penetrating Sealer and gL or less for others .
Refer to ASTM D . C. Can be applied to either new or existing surfaces .
D. Dries clear without significant change in surface appearance .
E. Maximum drying time of  hours .
F. Product can be applied in horizontal vertical and overhead surfaces .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Keep surfaces dry and free of release agents laitance dirt dust paint grease oil rust and other contaminants .
B .
Remove any curing compound or other incompatible products from the surface of the concrete before applying penetrating sealer .
C. Use one of the following cleaning methods .
Pressure washing psi min. . Shotblasting .
Sandblasting .
Etching D. Keep concrete surface matrix intact without exposing any large aggregate .
E. Cure concrete for days before sealer application .
F. Obtain approval from the Engineer before applying material .
G. Apply only when the outside air temperature will remain between and degrees F for hours or the manufacturers recommended cure time whichever is longer .
H. Do not apply within hours of a rain event or pressure washing nor if a rain event is forecasted within hours . .
APPLICATION A .
Application Rate .
Apply according to manufacturers recommendations for each of the following surfaces Implementation Penetrating Concrete Sealer Page of January a. Horizontal b. Vertical c. Overhead B .
Apply the penetrating concrete sealer evenly at an application rate recommended by the manufacturer .
C. Do not apply penetrating concrete sealer to portland cement concrete pavement PCCP or other roadway surface .
D. The sealer is considered defective if clouding or chalking occurs after placement .

DEFINITIONS A .
Working Force The force remaining in the prestressing steel after prestressing losses have either taken place or been provided for .
These losses include concrete creep and shrinkage concrete elastic compression steel creep and anchorage take ups .
B .
Working Stress The stress remaining in the prestressing steel after prestressing losses have either taken place or been provided for .
These losses include concrete creep and shrinkage concrete elastic compression steel creep and anchorage take ups. . SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Detailed shop drawings of fabricated materials for review .
a .
Include the following Details and calculations of the method materials and equipment to be used in the prestressing operations including additions or rearrangement of reinforcing steel and revision in concrete dimensions from that shown .
Method and sequence of stressing .
a Specifications and details of the prestressing steel working stresses and other data pertaining to the prestressing operation .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January b Proposed arrangement of the prestressing steel in the members .
c Cutting or release pattern .
Include location and detail of holddown devices and debonded strands .
Location descriptions and details for embedment items including plates inserts sleeves lifting devices and other items used for temporary and permanent attachments. . Erection drawings for precast prestressed concrete members for review .
a. Illustrate the proposed method of erection .
Provide details of the process including but not limited to the following Temporary supports bracing guys deadmen lifting devices connection details and attachments to bridge members .
Details for anticipated phases and conditions during erection .
The erection schedule and sequence crane location crane capacities location of lifting points on the bridge members member weights and other assumed loads during progressive stages of construction .
Minimum number and arrangement of items such as primary members secondary members and connections that must be installed braced and properly connected to provide structural integrity and stability .
Incorporate into the plan the requirements from this Section article .. B .
Material Submittals .
Certifications a .
Certification stating the manufacturers minimum guaranteed ultimate tensile strength for each sample of prestressing steel .
b .
Documentation of AISC Bridge Component QMS CPT Certification for information .
c. The certified calibration chart required by this Section Article .
paragraph B. . Prestressing Steel a .
Three ft long strand samples from each heat or lot that will be used on the project .
b .
Testing may require calendar days after the date of receipt .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January .
ACCEPTANCE A. Girders may be accepted at a reduced price when the average compressive strength based on field cured cylinders is at least percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength. . Price reduction factor is as follows Price Reduction Factor .. c f AVG c f . Where fc specified day minimum compressive strength in psi .
AVG average compressive strength of cylinder breaks in psi. . Department will calculate the amount paid by multiplying the contract unit price for the girder by the price reduction factor . .
The Department will reject girders if the average compressive strength of field cured cylinders is less than percent of the specified day minimum compressive strength .
a .
Core tests are not permitted for compressive strength tests. . HANDLING STORAGE AND DELIVERY A .
Prevent cracking or damaging precast units during handling storage and delivery .
B .
Take appropriate measures to prevent member camber from exceeding the tolerances in this Section Article .
until deck is placed .
C. Store units with adequate dunnage and bracing . .
Secure and protect units from movement . .
Prevent cracking distortion warping contact with soil staining and other physical damage. . Store units with dunnage across full width of each bearing point unless otherwise specified. . Place stored units so identification marks are clearly visible and units can be inspected .
D. Do not ship prestressed concrete members until tests on concrete cylinders manufactured from the same concrete and cured under similar conditions as the girders indicate the concrete has attained an average compressive strength equal to or greater than the specified day minimum compressive strength or for seven days after concrete placement whichever is longer .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January E. Transport precast members in an upright position. . Support the members during transportation in approximately the same points they will be supported when installed .
F. Remove portions of lifting devices protruding above the top of the member when no longer needed .

FABRICATION A .
General .
Use a Department prequalified supplier of precast concrete products according to the UDOT Quality Management Plan PrecastPrestressed Concrete Structures . .
Comply with camber and dimensional tolerances of PCI MNL . . Fabricate structural steel according to Section .
a .
Structural steel for prestressed concrete members requires AISC Bridge Component QMS CPT Certification unless otherwise specified .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January B .
Preparation .
Equipment used to stress tendons must be accurate including jacks pressure gauges and load cells .
a. Furnish a certified calibration chart .
b. Calibrate each jack and its gauge as a unit with the cylinder extension in the final jacking force position. . Calibrate the load cell and provide an indicator to determine the prestressing force in the tendon .
a .
The range of the load cell must be so that the lower percent of the manufacturers rated capacity is not used in determining the jacking stress . .
The prestressing force may be tested by the Engineer . .
Provide sufficient labor equipment and material to install and support testing equipment at the prestressing tendons and to remove the equipment when testing is completed .
C. Prestressing Steel .
Clearly mark the shipping package or form with handling instructions and information about the corrosion inhibitor including date place safety orders and instructions for use . .
Protect against physical damage and corrosion during handling storing and shipping . .
Replace prestressing steel that has damage loose rust pitting or serious corrosion .
a .
Slight rusting is acceptable if it does not cause visible pits. . Do not oil or grease prestressing strand .
D. Pretensioning .
Install and support testing equipment at the prestressing tendons and remove the testing equipment after the testing is completed . .
Tension prestressing steel with hydraulic jacks so that the force in the prestressing steel is not less than the value shown. . Do not allow the initial stress to exceed percent of the specified minimum ultimate tensile strength . .
Maximum temporary tensile stress jacking stress in prestressing steel must not exceed percent of the specified minimum ultimate tensile strength. . Anchor the prestressing steel at stresses initial stress that result in the ultimate retention of working forces not less than those shown . .
The stress loss in pretensioned prestressing steel due to concrete creep and shrinkage steel creep and concrete elastic compression is as shown . .
Check prestressing steel strands in pretensioned members for loss of prestress not more than hours before placing concrete for the members if tensioned individually .
a .
Use methods and equipment acceptable to Engineer .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January .
Retension strands that show a loss of prestress in excess of three percent. . Increase the calculated prestressing steel elongation in pretensioned members to compensate for the loss in stress when it is tensioned at a temperature appreciably lower than the estimated concrete temperature and the prestressing steel at the time of initial set of the concrete .
a .
Do not allow the jacking stress to exceed percent of the specified minimum ultimate tensile strength. . Do not cut or release prestressing steel in pretensioned members until the concrete in the member has attained the minimum compressive strength specified in this Section article .. .
Maintain a minimum lateral eccentricity of prestress when cutting and releasing prestressing steel in pretensioned members .
a .
Follow the cutting and release pattern in the authorized shop drawings. . Cut off pretensioned prestressing steel flush with the end of the member except when otherwise shown .
Clean and paint the exposed strand ends and a inch strip of adjoining concrete with zinc rich paint .
Alternatively cut the strands at least inch back from the girder end fill the recess with grout and finish flush with the girder ends .
a .
Use a wire brush or abrasive blast cleaning to remove dirt and residue not firmly bonded to the metal or concrete surfaces .
b .
Cover the surfaces with a thick application of zinc rich paint .
Thoroughly mix the paint at the time of application and work it into voids in the strands .
c. Apply two applications of zinc rich paint to surfaces that are not covered by concrete or mortar .
E. Place Concrete .
Do not place concrete into forms until the reinforcement and prestressing steel has been inspected and approved by the Engineer. . Clean the inside surface of forms of dirt mortar and foreign material before concrete placement. . Vibrate the concrete internally externally or both .
Do not vibrate SCC. . Avoid displacing reinforcing steel or strands . .
Finish top surfaces of precast girders against which castinplace concrete will be placed to a coarse texture by brooming with a stiff coarse broom .
a .
Clean surfaces of laitance or other foreign material before shipping .
Implementation Prestressed Concrete Page of January F. Cure .
Cure according to Section .
PART EXECUTION .
ERECTION A .
Erect prestressed concrete members according to the authorized erection drawings .
B .
Clean bearing surfaces and surfaces that will be in permanent contact before the members are erected .
C. Use lifting devices in a manner that will not cause bending or torsional forces .
D. Accurately assemble parts as described and according to the contract documents or authorized erection drawings .
Follow matchmarks .
E. Temporarily support anchor and brace erected superstructure members as necessary for stability and to resist wind or other loads until they are permanently secured to the structure. . Support anchor and brace superstructure members as detailed in the authorized erection drawings before allowing traffic under the bridge .
F. Do not open traffic under a partially erected bridge superstructure unless allowed in the erection drawings or authorized by the Engineer and approved by the Professional Engineer responsible for signing and sealing the erection drawings .

END OF SECTION Implementation Approach Slab Jacking Page of January SECTION APPROACH SLAB JACKING PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A. Slab jacking by pumping nonshrink grout or injecting high density polyurethane. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Concrete Slab Jacking B .
Section Structural Concrete Repair .
REFERENCES A. ASTM C Packaged Dry HydraulicCement Grout Nonshrink .
DEFINITIONS Not Used .
SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers product data sheets and recommended installation instructions .
B .
Certificate of compliance for the materials used .
PART PRODUCTS .
EQUIPMENT A .
Equipment capable of supplying a homogeneous product at the appropriate rate .
B .
Certified scales or measuring devices to measure delivered product and to proportion product components .
C. Concrete drill or saw capable of producing circular holes of adequate size for the appropriate application type .
D. Elevation measuring devices with an accuracy of  inch .
Implementation Approach Slab Jacking Page of January E. Concrete saw capable of cutting a joint in roadway slab just adjacent to end of approach slab. . NONSHRINK GROUT A .
Refer to ASTM C . . HIGH DENSITY POLYURETHANE A .
Refer to Section .
PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A .
Establish a final target approach slab profile using an elevation measuring device or string lines .
B .
Clean all adjacent joints before jacking to allow free movement of the slab .
C. Locate structural steel by ferroscanning or other method approved by the Engineer. . Do not damage existing rebar during preparation or installation .
D. Drill a minimum of four evenly spaced holes into each half of the approach slab where required to obtain uniform grout or polyurethane placement . .
Drill vertical holes that are round . .
Drill holes with a maximum diameter of inches .
E. Do not crack approach slab . .
Follow Section to repair approach slab cracks if they develop .
F. Protect integrity of approach slab drains. . Drains in precast approach slabs may require additional preparation and procedures . .
These must be approved by the Engineer before execution .
Implementation Approach Slab Jacking Page of January .
INSTALLATION A .
Pump in a pattern the amount of material required to completely fill the voids underneath the slab. . Raise the approach slab to within plus or minus  inch from the final targeted approach slab profile .
B .
Remove polyurethane material from the drill holes to the full depth of the approach slab at the completion of the pumping operation and clean the full depth of the holes along the circumference with a wire brush. . Dampen the walls of the holes prior to grout placement .
C. Fill the holes with nonshrink grout .
Overfill the holes by  inch .
D. Grind the nonshrink grout used to fill the holes flush with the top of the approach slab .

b .

c. Include supporting engineering calculations . .

EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS A .
Concrete Repair Mortar Mixer .
Use a small mixer to batch out the concrete repair mortar .
B. Epoxy Injection system .
Use at least two pumps having the following characteristics a. Electricpowered and portable b .
Positive displacement c. Positiveratio control of exact proportions of the two components at the nozzle d. Inline metering and mixing .
Automatic pressure control capable of discharging the mixed adhesive at any preset pressure up to psi .
psi and equipped with a manual pressure control override . .
Capable of maintaining the volume ratio of the injection adhesive prescribed by the manufacturer within a tolerance of percent by volume at any discharge pressure up to psi . .
Sensors on both the component reservoirs that automatically stop the machine when only one component is being pumped to the mixing head .

PREPARATION FOR DELAMINATION REPAIR A .
Locate the repair areas. . Sound the items requiring this work and mark the limits of delaminated areas for repair work in the presence of the Engineer .
B .
Concrete removal .
Make  inch deep saw cuts in the sound concrete along the perimeter of the repair area Implementation Structural Concrete Repair Page of January .
Remove damaged shattered and delaminated concrete .
a .
Use lb class jackhammer when allowed .
Do not use pneumatic hammers heavier than lb class for removals in areas directly below the top reinforcing steel .
Use lb class jackhammer or lighter for deck edge repair .
b .
Operate jackhammer at an angle greater than degrees as measured from the element surface .
c. Protect existing reinforcing steel encountered .
d. Replace or repair damaged reinforcing steel . .
Remove loose materials by dry sweeping or clean and dry compressed air with at least psi pressure .
Refer to ASTM D . . Sandblast clean exposed reinforcing steel and concrete surfaces before placing new concrete .
a .
Protect in place sound rebar .
b .
Prevent sandblasting material and debris from falling into waterways pedestrian areas traffic areas or onto railroad tracks. . Clean the repair area by blowing with clean and dry compressed air at psi .
Refer to ASTM D . .
Replace existing reinforcing steel bars with percent or greater section loss .
a .
Cut and remove deteriorated existing reinforcing steel bars .
b .
Match the size of the new reinforcing steel bar to the existing bar .
c. Provide lap lengths as shown. . EPOXY INJECTION A .
General .
Pressure inject cracks to inch in width. . Mark cracks to be pressure injected in the presence of the Engineer .
B .
Preparation .
Sandblast the concrete surfaces clean. . Clean cracks of contaminants using oilfree compressed air according to ASTM D . a .
Remove remaining material by flushing with water under pressure .
Implementation Structural Concrete Repair Page of January .
Space ports at a distance not more than the thickness of the concrete being injected .
a .
Limit port spacing at ends of cracks to not more than half the concrete thickness .
b .
Adjust port spacing based on manufacturers recommendations and to ensure injection adhesive fills the cracks . .
Apply a surface seal over all exterior faces of the crack that can be reached to contain the injection adhesive in the crack .
C. Epoxy Injection .
Inject the crack when it is at its widest if the crack width changes because of daily temperature cycles or other structural loading of the structure .
Proceed from lower to higher ports. . Plug the port being injected and move to a higher port when injection adhesive appears at the next higher port .
D. Final Surface Seal .
Grind flush all ports extending above the concrete surfaces . .
Mask the member in parallel straight line segments between the ends of the crack so the surface seal has a clean and neat appearance when applied . .
Apply the surface seal at the application rate of at least .
galyd .
a .
Cover the entire length of the crack for at least inches on both sides of the crack . .
Apply a second coat at the same application rate as soon as the first coat is dry to the touch .
a .
Do not exceed the following times between coats Table Maximum Time Between Coats Temperature Degrees F Hours Implementation Structural Concrete Repair Page of January .

a .
Rebuild the areas to original shape  inch. . Vibration is required in the forms when the area between forms and existing concrete surface will allow use of vibrators .
B .
Repairs with a thickness less than or equal to three inches .
Use concrete repair mortar . .
Coat the cleaned concrete using the substrate coating. . Place concrete repair mortar in layers not exceeding the manufacturers recommended application thickness per layer .
a .
Rebuild the areas to original shape  inch . .
Follow the manufacturers recommendations for finishing and curing .
C. Repairs with a thickness greater than three inches. . Use concrete . .
Apply an epoxy resin adhesive to the cleaned concrete surface of the repair area before placing the new concrete. . Place form and finish concrete and construct falsework according to Section . .
Cure concrete according to Section .
D. Finished Surfaces Provide the look of one color . .

PREPARATION A .

Fill depressions with Untreated Base Course material grade and compact . .
Firmly compact the subgrade for Type II Placement . .
Thoroughly wet the surface with water before placing the concrete. . PLACE RIGID PLASTIC FOAM A .
Place rigid plastic foam material inch thick against the surface of all structural members before placing the concrete slope protection .
B. Anchor the rigid plastic foam in place with a compatible adhesive .
Implementation Concrete Slope Protection Repair Page of January C. Recess the rigid plastic foam in the joints against structural members so a groove is formed above the rigid plastic foam filler. . PLACE REINFORCING STEEL A .

Implementation Concrete Slope Protection Repair Page of January B .
Place the sealant with caulking guns in joints after placing the backing rod and in the recess above the rigid plastic foam. . Place sealant when the ambient air temperature is at least degrees F and rising. . Start the sealant placement at one side and proceed to the other side on horizontal grooves and from top to bottom on vertical joints. . Tool the sealant using a concave pointing tool with soap solution until the joints and recess are sealed over completely . .
Finish sealant in a neat and clean fashion .
a. Verify there are no irregular surfaces including peaks and valleys .
b .
Remove sealant outside of the joint .

Implementation Structural Pothole Patching Page of January .
QUALITY CONTROL A .
Manufacturers Technical Representative .
Provide a technical representative from the structural pothole patching product manufacturer for training and consultation .
a .
Provide training in surface preparation proper mixing placing and finishing technique safety precautions traffic opening time and environmental requirements .
Train workers who will mix place or finish the structural pothole patching product during production work in a preproduction meeting .
Use a mockup to demonstrate proper mixing placing and finishing technique .
Coordinate training with the Engineer .
b .
The manufacturers technical representative must Be onsite during surface preparation and application of the structural pothole patching product on the initial structure and for the first day the structural pothole patching product is used on the project .
Be available for consultation but not necessarily present at the job site for the remaining work .
Be available to train workers who did not attend the preproduction training before they can perform production work. . Do not use workers for the production work who have not been trained by the manufacturers technical representative . .
The Engineer may waive the requirement for the manufacturers technical representative to be onsite if the Contractor can demonstrate that the superintendent for the work has performed at least five satisfactory applications of the structural pothole patching product on similar bridges in similar environments .
a .
The manufacturers technical representative must be available for consultation throughout the duration of the application . .
The Department reserves the right to require the manufacturers technical representative to be onsite if at any time the Engineer is concerned with the product installation quality .

CONCRETE REMOVAL A .
Use either the jackhammer or hydrodemolition method described below. . Jackhammer Method a .
Saw Cuts Make inch deep saw cuts in the sound concrete along the rectangular perimeter of the repair areas .
Stop saw cuts and notify the Engineer if reinforcing steel is encountered .
Implementation Structural Pothole Patching Page of January Replace reinforcing steel that has been cut during this operation having a cut depth equal to or greater than percent of the diameter of the reinforcing steel .
a Provide lap lengths of the new reinforcing steel with sound existing reinforcing steel at least of bar diameters .. b .
Remove damaged shattered and delaminated concrete .
Use lb class jackhammer .
a Do not use pneumatic hammers heavier than lb class for removals in areas directly below the top reinforcing steel .
c. Operate jackhammer at an angle greater than degrees as measured from the element surface .
d. Remove the concrete to  inch below the bottom of top mat of reinforcing steel if the delamination occurs at the depth of the top mat of reinforcing steel .
e. Protect existing reinforcing steel encountered .
f. Replace or repair damaged reinforcing steel. . Hydrodemolition Method a .
Obtain the most current requirements for hydrodemolition from the Department .
B .
Remove loose materials by dry sweeping or by compressed air with at least psi pressure .
Refer to ASTM D . C. Deck Blow Through .
Immediately stop the equipment and notify the Engineer and make the necessary adjustments to limit the area of complete concrete removal if removal blows completely through the bridge deck . .
Provide appropriate falsework and formwork to support construction loads safely. . Use treated plywood to facilitate stripping .
D. Replace existing reinforcing steel that have percent or greater section loss. . Cut and remove deteriorated existing reinforcing steel . .
Match the size of the new reinforcing steel bar to the existing bar . .
Provide lap lengths of the new reinforcing steel with sound existing reinforcing steel at least of bar diameters .
E. Keep the repair area clean until new concrete has been placed .
Implementation Structural Pothole Patching Page of January .
BONDING CONCRETE A .
Follow manufacturers recommendations when using rapid setting repair mortar. . PATCHING CONCRETE A. Sandblast clean the exposed reinforcing steel and concrete surfaces before placing the structural pothole patch . .
Protect inplace any sound reinforcing steel. . Resandblast reinforcing steel if rust occurs before placement .
B .
Clean the repair area by blowing with clean and dry compressed air at psi .
Refer to ASTM D . C. Pressure wash the repair area . .
Remove standing water while maintaining a saturated surface. . Repeat pressure washing of the repair area before placing the structural pothole patch if the repair surface shows signs of drying out .
D. Repairs using concrete .
Place concrete and strike off level with deck surface .
Refer to Section . .
Finish surface of bridge deck and approach slab according to Section . .
Apply a liquid membranecuring compound and wet cure the repair area for at least days and until the concrete repair has a compressive strength of at least psi .
E. Repairs using rapid setting repair mortar .
Follow the manufacturers requirements for placing finishing and curing if using rapid setting repair mortar. . Use a texture process that produces regular  inch wide transverse grooves spaced randomly from  inch to  inch on centers and  inch deep .
F. Patch failure Remove the patch completely and repair the pothole again if the patch fails to bond to the existing concrete .

DEFINITIONS A .
Main Members Members on a critical load path that carry bridge dead and live loads .
The loss of capacity of main members would have serious consequences on the structural integrity .
B .
Secondary Members Members other than main members not designed to carry primary load. . SUBMITTALS A .
Working Drawings .
Detailed shop drawings of all fabricated materials for review .
a .
The seal of a Professional Engineer PE or Professional Structural Engineer SE is not required. . Erection Drawings for all structural steel members for review .
a .
Fully illustrate the proposed method of erection .
Provide complete details of the process including but not limited to Temporary supports bracing guys deadmen lifting devices connection details and attachments to bridge members .
The schedule and sequence of erection location of cranes crane capacities location of lifting points on the bridge members member weights and any other assumed loads .
Complete details for all anticipated phases and conditions during erection .
Minimum number of items such as main members secondary members and connections that must be installed and properly connected to provide structural integrity and stability .
Implementation Structural Steel Page of January Supporting calculations according to the current edition of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications to demonstrate that factored member capacities are not exceeded and final geometry will be correct .

FABRICATION A. Fabricate according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Section UDOT Steel and Concrete Construction Manual and AASHTOAWS D .. B .
The fabricator must have AISC Certified Bridge Fabricator Advanced Certification ABR if fabricated structural steel will be part of a bridge structure except as follows .
Railings grates grate frames and drain pipes may be fabricated with AISC Bridge Component Certification CPT .
C. Surface preparation of steel .
Painted Steel a .
Refer to Section . . Unpainted Weathering Steel a .
Meet sandblaster qualifications and surface preparation requirements for painted steel according to Section .
b. Construct so that erection marks on the steel are not visible after the structure is completed .
Implementation Structural Steel Page of January c. Commercially blast the following surfaces according to SSPCSP Igirders a Underside of the exterior portion of the top flange of fascia girders and underside of bottom flange of all girders .
b Exterior portion of web of fascia girders .
c Top side and outside edge of the exterior portion of the bottom flange of fascia girders .
d All welded surfaces .
Trusses a Top chord diagonals and top bracing .
b Exposed surfaces of bottom chord floor beams and bottom bracing .
c All welded surfaces .
d. Commercially blast all other surfaces according to at least SSPCSP .
e. Develop even patina at completion of welding repair and after surface has been verified by the Engineer .
PART EXECUTION .
INSTALL HIGH STRENGTH FASTENERS A .
Store the bolts and nuts in the original containers until used . .
Protect from dirt and moisture . .
Remove only as many fasteners from protected storage as can be tightened during a work shift .
a .
Return unused fasteners to protected storage at the end of each work shift. . Clean and relubricate fasteners that accumulate rust or dirt resulting from site conditions .
a .
Use manufacturers recommended lubricant .
B .
Testing .
Test the installed bolt nut and washer assembly before beginning erection and periodically to verify compliance . .
Provide a SkidmoreWilhelm Calibrator or other acceptable bolt tension indicating device for bolt testing at the job site . .
Check the DTI washers in a SkidmoreWilhelm Calibrator using bolts of sufficient length .
a .
Use DTI washers with solid plates when the fastenergrip length is too short to be tested in a SkidmoreWilhelm Calibrator .
Implementation Structural Steel Page of January C. Install fasteners according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Section the bolting procedure in the authorized erection drawings and the following .
Complete the Bolted Field Splice Certification form at the end of this Section as fastener tightening progresses for all girder field splices . .
Complete the Bolted Diaphragm and Cross Frame Member Certification form at the end of this Section. . Use DTI washers to indicate bolt tension .
a .
Follow the manufacturers methods and procedures as modified by the Engineer .
b .
Place DTI washer on the side of the connection that will not be embedded in concrete .
A DTI washer is still required if the entire fastener will be embedded in concrete .
Do not place concrete until the inspector has certified that all fasteners are properly tightened. . Use drift pins to align bolt holes and maintain dimensions and camber of the member. . Insert bolts in open holes with washers and hand tighten . .
Tighten at least percent of the fasteners as required to approximately onehalf final tension to draw all plies of the connection into firm contact .
a .
Do not tighten any fasteners to indicated full tension at this time . .
Remove drift pins and replace with bolts . .
Tighten fasteners progressively from fixed or rigid points to the free edges . .
Fully tighten percent of the fasteners for field splices and diaphragms .
Verify remaining fasteners are snug tight before release of crane or removal of shoring .
a .
Reduce the DTI washer gap to .
inch regardless of which element is turned for tightening . .
Tighten all fasteners to full tension. . Review the DTI washer compression for each fastener after the first connection .
a .
Reevaluate tightening procedure and make corrections as required if over percent of DTI washers tested are fully compressed. . FIELD WELDING A. Weld according to AASHTOAWS D .. B .
Meet the same requirements as shop welds .
Implementation Structural Steel Page of January C. Comply with welding procedures and inspection requirements . .
Refer to UDOT Steel and Concrete Construction Manual .
D. Welding operators must be certified according to the specified AWS Code . .
Refer to UDOT Steel and Concrete Construction Manual . .
PAINTED STRUCTURAL STEEL A .
Paint all structural steel not designated as unpainted weathering steel . .
Refer to Section . . UNPAINTED WEATHERING STEEL A .
Clean girders of debris after deck concrete is placed. . Redevelop patina as needed. . ERECTION A Erector Qualifications .
An AISC certified erector with one of the following certifications is preferred when erecting bolting and welding bridge framing members a .
Certified Steel Erector with Bridge Erection Endorsement requirements criteria b .
Advanced Certified Steel Erector checklist criteria .
B .
Maintain responsibility for girder erection during each stage of construction including the protection of structural steel members the workers and the traveling public .
C. Erect structural steel members according to the authorized erection drawings and in a manner that prevents damage to elements of the structure . .
Follow matchmarks .
D. Temporarily support anchor and brace main members such as girders during erection to produce the proper alignment and camber in the completed structure . .
Install cross frames and diagonal bracing as necessary to provide stability and correct geometry . .
Provide temporary bracing or stiffening devices if necessary during each erection stage. . Support anchor and brace erected superstructure members as detailed in the authorized erection drawings before allowing traffic under the bridge .
Implementation Structural Steel Page of January E. Design temporary supports and falsework according to the current edition of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Section Temporary Works .
F. Provide additional materials that are required to keep both the temporary and final stresses within the allowable limits used in design .
G. Handle materials so that no parts will be bent broken or otherwise damaged. . Do not injure or distort the members when hammering .
H. Remove dirt and debris from bearing surfaces and surfaces that will be in permanent contact before the members are assembled .
I .
Do not open traffic under a partially erected bridge superstructure unless allowed in the authorized erection drawings .

PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION A. Excavation and Preparation .
Refer to Section . . Keep trenches free from water . .
Prepare foundation to provide a firm and uniform bearing throughout the entire length of the structure .
a. Scarify and compact the top inches of the excavated ground surface to at least percent of the maximum laboratory density. . Place bedding according to the authorized fabrication and installation drawings .
B .
Assembly .
Assemble structural plate pipe structures according to the authorized fabrication and installation drawings . .
Provide loosebolt assembly to maintain structure shape during erection unless temporary bracing is required .
a .
Properly align plates to avoid permanent deflection from the design shape before bolt tightening . .
Install temporary bracing to maintain structure shape during erection when required .
a .
Remove temporary bracing when backfilling reaches the top quadrant of the structure. . Do not exceed the manufacturers assembly tolerances before backfilling .
C. Backfill .
Backfill structure according to the authorized fabrication and installation drawings .
Implementation Structural Plate Pipe Page of January .
Check and control the deflection of the structure during the entire backfilling operation .
a .
Do not exceed the manufacturers recommended limits .

Place footings cutoff walls reinforced concrete slope collars thrust blocks and headwalls as shown .
a .
Refer to Section .
b .

inches .

Design prefabricated steel truss bridge and deck according to current editions of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications the AASHTO LRFD Guide Specifications for the Design of Pedestrian Bridges the AASHTO Guide Specifications for LRFD Seismic Bridge Design and the SDDM. . Design and detail the bridge to accommodate a Cold Climate temperature differential . .
Provide at least inch thick concrete deck. . Use shear studs that extend at least to the center of the deck . .
Provide at least inch clear cover to the top mat of reinforcing steel and to shear studs. . Fracture critical requirements are waived except for Charpy Vnotch testing .
a Meet AASHTO M zone Charpy Vnotch fracture critical requirements for main tension members .
B. Verify that the clear span clear width elevations and geometry shown are consistent with the truss bridge to be used at the site .
C. Use two parallel trusses with at least one diagonal in each panel consistent with the layout clear width and span shown . .
The trusses must be main loadcarrying members of the bridge .
Implementation Prefabricated Steel Truss Bridge Page of January .
Orient vertical truss members so they appear perpendicular to the bridge profile grade after the bridge is erected and dead loads are applied. . Use square and rectangular structural tubing for the members of each truss upper and lower chords diagonals end posts and vertical posts .
D. Use structural steel shapes or square and rectangular structural steel tubing for the floor beams and stringers .
E. Provide structural steel thickness of at least  inch .
F. Provide drilled  inch diameter weep holes at the low points of steel tubing members as oriented in the inplace completed structure. . Flame cut holes are prohibited . .
Provide one weep hole at each end in members that are level or flat . .

MANUFACTURE A Fabricate according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Section .. and AASHTO M . . AISC Highway Metal Components Certification CPT is required for fabrication of metal bearing components .
B. Elastomeric bearings with sliding surfaces . .
Recess and bond PTFE to top plate at manufacturers facility .
a .
Recess at least onehalf of PTFE thickness .
b .
Do not bond the PTFE to the stainless steel sliding plate .
c. Make the bonded PTFE surface smooth and free from bubbles .
d. Polish the filled PTFE surfaces. . Weld the stainless steel with  inch continuous fillet welds to the sole plate .
a .
Use a single piece of stainless steel .
b .
Do not allow the weld metal to project beyond the plane of the sliding surface .
c. Use welding procedures compatible with the stainless steel specified .
Refer to AWS D. Structural Welding Code Stainless Steel .
d. Stainless steel sheet must be flat free from wrinkles and in continuous contact with the sole plate after welding .
Implementation Elastomeric Bearings Page of January .
Protect stainless steel and PTFE sliding surfaces during manufacture shipment and erection .
a .
Clean the sliding surfaces immediately before setting the girder in place .
b .
The Department considers the unit damaged when the sliding surfaces are damaged by scratches weld splatter gouges overspray from painting and other defects. . Do not exceed coefficient of friction shown . .

REMOVAL A .
Remove existing joint seal as shown .
B .
Choose a removal method that will not damage the adjacent concrete or steel . .
PREPARATION A .
Provide tooled radius on joint edges as shown . .
Grind existing concrete as necessary to create radius .
B .
Remove loose or spalled concrete and repair to create a smooth uniform surface for the joint system to bond to . .
Refer to Section .
C. Sandblast entire joint. . Meet the requirements of ASTM D . D. Remove sand left by sandblasting from the joint and surrounding traffic surfaces using compressed air .
E. Joint area must be completely dry before installation .
F. Install joint system when the ambient and substrate temperature is above degrees F. .
Comply with manufacturers installation instruction including environmental limitations . .
INSTALLATION A .
Install the top of the pourable joint seal at least inch below the traffic surface. . Set the depth of the backer rod to meet the manufacturers minimum thickness requirements for the pourable joint seal .
B .
Follow the manufacturers installation instructions .

PART EXECUTION .
PREPARATION A. Label containers containing elastomeric binder with the following .
Manufacturers name .
Lot or batch number .
Date of manufacture .
Date of packaging .
The shelf date if any beyond which the binder is not used .
Manufacturers storage and handling recommendations B .
Remove existing expansion joint system and asphalt when shown .
C. Drill drain hole in concrete deck or approach slab as shown. . Use drill capable of coring cleanly through asphalt membrane concrete and steel reinforcing bars .
D. Clean drain hole of all dust and debris and apply penetrating concrete sealer to the walls of the hole .
E. Place drain and separation geotextile .
Place galvanized steel drain assembly and seal using silicone joint sealer as shown. . Place free draining granular backfill as shown .
F. Place plywood directly on clean concrete deck to cover joint .
G. Asphalt Pavement Preparations .
Place the asphalt overlay . .
Saw cut and remove asphalt to the dimensions shown to create blockout .
a .
Set saws to cut the full depth of the wearing surface .
Do not damage the concrete deck sleeper slab approach slab or asphaltic concrete that remains in place .
b .
Do not allow traffic or construction equipment to cross the cut edge .
Implementation Asphaltic Plug Joint Page of January H. Concrete Pavement Preparation .
Form the blockout for the asphalt plug joint according to Section . . Place the concrete overlay as shown .
I .
Remove plywood forms or rigid plastic foam from the blockout .
J .
Thoroughly clean and dry the entire blockout . .
Remove small debris using compressed air. . Sandblast the length of the blockout to clean any remaining debris on the vertical walls and adjacent deck area. . Meet the requirements of ASTM D for compressed air and sandblaster .
K. Remove and repair spalled and defective concrete material within the blockout according to Section . .
INSTALLATION A .
Install joint seal when the weather conditions meet the manufacturers installation instructions .
B .
Apply joint sealer structures and backer rod to the joint. . Place the top of the backer rod at least inch and no more than the width of the existing joint below the bottom of the blockout. . Place a small amount of hot binder onto the joint sealer structures to adequately plug the joint .
C. Coat the blockout with a thin layer of hot binder immediately after cleaning and applying joint sealer structures .
D. Install the traffic bearing plate centered over the gap butt jointed and placed so that the plates lay flat on the bottom of the blockout. . Place so that there are no overlaps in the sections or gaps between the plate and blockout . .
Provide a traffic bearing plate that is at least inches wider than the maximum movement rating for the joint . .
Coat the top of the plate with a thin layer of hot binder after the locating pins are in place .
E. Follow the manufacturers installation recommendations for the proportioning heating temperatures mixing placing and finishing procedures of the aggregate and binder .
Implementation Asphaltic Plug Joint Page of January F. Place matrix in lifts according to the manufacturers recommendations. . Do not exceed a lift height of inches. . Place matrix to finished grade as shown .
G. Seal top surface of asphaltic plug joint as recommended by the manufacturer . .
Extend seal a minimum of inches onto asphalt or concrete surface .

DEFINITIONS A .
Compression Joint Seal A joint seal placed in compression before installation and kept in compression during its life . .
Seals the joint as shown to prevent water from seeping through the joint .
B. Elastomeric Joint Seal preformed open cell vulcanized elastomeric compound using virgin polychloroprene as the only polymer C. Silicone Coating factory applied external facing applied to the foam at a width greater than the maximum joint extension and cured before final compression .
D. Type A open cell precompressed selfexpanding polyurethane foam with factory applied highwaygrade silicone joint seal .
E. Type B preformed open cell vulcanized elastomeric joint seal .
F. Watertight no free dripping water or patches of moisture on any surface under the joint. . SUBMITTALS A .
Manufacturers product data sheet and installation instructions .
B .
Removal Plan for review . .
Include method of removal and preparation of existing surface. . Equipment to be used .
C. Calculated stretch of the joint seal for information .
Refer to this Section .D .
D. Repair procedure for review .
Refer to this Section .C .

PREPARATION A .
Compression Seal Type A .
Concrete a .
Remove loose particles and weak concrete .
b .
Repair spalls chipped edges and uneven surfaces using epoxy grout .
c. Remove contaminants by sandblasting .
Verify no oil or water contamination according to ASTM D . d. Prepare the surface as required by the manufacturer. . Metal a. Sandblast according to ASTM D to rough white metal and solventwipe immediately before applying epoxy adhesive primer .
b .
Prepare the surface as required by the manufacturer. . Verify the joint seal size based on the prepared surface and installation temperature. . Store all materials indoors at room temperature until needed at time of installation .
B .
Compression Seal Type B .
Clean finished concrete joint surfaces by sandblasting .
a. Verify no oil or water in compressed air according to ASTM D . Implementation Compression Joint Seal Page of January b .
Remove unsound materials adhesive and contaminants . .
Provide joint openings that are smooth true and vertical .
a .
Joint opening faces are parallel and the width will not vary by more than inch over ft along the length of the joint .
b .
Repair vertical surface imperfections including saw blade gouges greater than inch with epoxy grout . .
Prepare the surface as required by the manufacturer . .

Remove existing joint system according to the authorized Removal Plan .
B .
Compression Seal Type A .

C. Compression Seal Type B .
Avoid damaging existing concrete . .
Saw cut the vertical joint opening concrete surfaces as required to achieve the appropriate width and depth as shown . .
Prepare joint according to this Section .B . .
Install Compression Joint Seal according to this Section .B. . NEW INSTALLATION A .
Compression Seal Type A .
Install joint seal according to this Section .A .
B .
Compression Seal Type B .
The blockout width for the joint will be within inch for joints less than or equal to  inch and  inch for joints greater than  inch of the width shown .
a .
The blockout width corresponds to the appropriate ambient temperature at the time of concrete placement . .
Saw cut the vertical joint opening in concrete surfaces as required to achieve the appropriate width and depth as shown . .
Prepare joint according to this Section .B . .
Install Compression Joint Seal according to this Section .B. . SEAL INSTALLATION A .
Compression Seal Type A .
Install the joint seal according to manufacturers specifications . .
Apply epoxy adhesive to the substrate .
a .
Prepare the joint again according to this Section .A and manufacturers recommendations if the epoxy cures before placement of seal .
Implementation Compression Joint Seal Page of January .
Install joint seal at least inch below the traffic surface or according to manufacturers installation instructions whichever is larger. . Clean silicone coating at joint edges and apply sealant bands according to the manufacturers installation instructions . .
Coat exposed foam ends with a light coating of silicone .
B .
Compression Seal Type B .
Supply the longest continuous length of compression seal possible .
a .
Field splices will be allowed when required by staging .
b .
Field splice according to manufacturers requirements . .
Install compression joint seal according to the manufacturers installation instructions .
a .
Cut the compression joint seal length to the exact width of the pavement .
b .
Cut upturn and downturn bends according to manufacturers installation instructions .
C. Insert compression joint seal into the joint blockout with tools that will not damage the seal .
D. Install the compression seal without stretching more than percent . .
Calculate stretch by dividing the excess length by the original length .
a .
Stretch greater than percent is unacceptable and requires that the seal be replaced . .
Provide the Engineer the calculated stretch .
E. Install compression joint seal so the top of the seal is inch inch below the traffic surface. . WATERTIGHT INTEGRITY TEST A .
Perform a watertight integrity test on the joint system at least five calendar days after the joint has been installed. . Test full width or staged width of the joint system as shown . .
Perform the watertight integrity test in the presence of the Engineer .
B. Pond at least inch of water over the joint for minutes where Joints are over steel or concrete surfaces that can be inspected .
a .
Inspect the steel and concrete surfaces for any evidence of dripping water or moisture for the initial minutes and for minutes after the ponded water has been released .
Implementation Compression Joint Seal Page of January .
Joints are over steel or concrete surfaces that can not be inspected .
a .
Measure and record the initial depth of the ponded water .
b .
Measure and record the depth of the ponded water after minutes .
c. The test can be stopped if depth of ponded water has not changed inch or more .
d. Continue the test for an additional minutes if depth of water has changed more than inch .
Measure and record the depth of the ponded water .
The test is considered a failure if the water level has changed by an additional inch or more .
C. Locate the places in the joint system where leakage is occurring and take measures necessary to stop the leakage . .
Submit a repair procedure recommended by the manufacturer. . Repair joint system according to the authorized manufacturers recommended repair procedure. . Repeat watertight integrity test .

Final Inplace Tolerances for Expansion Joint .

a. Deviations from the string line of more than  inch are not allowed .
b .
Do not deviate parallel extrusion faces from each other by more than  inch at any location .

D. Provide recommended repair for failed watertight integrity test . .
If joint fails the watertight integrity test after the repair remove leaking seals clean steel extrusion grooves and install new seals if leaking occurs during testing .

PREPARATION A .
Expansion Joint Modification and Joint Closure .
Remove the curing cover materials and dry according to manufacturers recommendations or hours whichever is greater after concrete placed at expansion joint modifications and joint closures has cured .
B .
Concrete Deck .
Sandblast to remove asphalt and all other foreign material from the entire deck approach slabs and sides of the parapet for a height of inches above the concrete deck . .
Vacuum or use compressed air to remove all dust and loose material from the deck . .
Remove all sharp ridges and projections that can puncture the membrane. . Patch holes or spalled areas in the concrete deck with patching concrete to provide a flat deck surface .
Refer to Section .
C. Joints and Cracks .
Bond a inch wide strip of woven fiberglass reinforcing to the deck over cracks and cold joints greater than inch wide using a compatible binder .
Implementation Waterproofing Membrane Page of January .
APPLY MEMBRANE A. Rubberized asphalt membrane Follow membrane manufacturers recommendations for application temperatures equipment and procedures. . Primer a .
Use primer furnished by the manufacturer of membrane material .
b .
Apply primer to all surfaces to be covered by the membrane according to the manufacturers recommended procedure and application rate. . Placement a .
Overlap prefabricated membrane strips at least inches or as required by the Manufacturer .
b .
Place joints in a shingling effect so water will drain effectively . .
Bonding a .
Use hand rollers or other satisfactory pressure apparatus on the membrane to assure firm and uniform contact with the primed surfaces .
b .
Use a wide tipped torch to cause tackiness if an adhesive is required to create a good seal at joints. . Placement a .
Place the membrane on the vertical face of the concrete curb to the height of the finished overlay surfacing plus inch . .
Defects a .
Protect the entire membrane from developing wrinkles air bubbles or other placement defects .
b. Patch any torn or cut areas and narrow overlaps using a satisfactory adhesive and a piece of membrane .
c. Extend the patch at least inches beyond any defect .
d. Bond the patch firmly to the surface. . Traffic a .
Allow only necessary rubber tire vehicles on the membrane .
b .
Do not allow public traffic .
c. Maintain the membrane in good condition until covered with pavement . .
Preparation for Overlaying a .
Apply a bond coat of an acceptable adhesive to the surface of the membrane if required by the membrane manufacturer .
Implementation Waterproofing Membrane Page of January .
ASPHALT SURFACING OVERLAY A .
Do not place overlay surfacing until the Engineer has inspected the membrane and authorization has been granted .
B .
Do not place the overlay surfacing until the membrane has cured according to manufacturers recommendations. . Deposit spread and roll asphalt material so the membrane will not be damaged .

Section Concrete Joint Control .

Manufacturers product data and recommended installation instructions for all materials .
PART PRODUCTS .
MATERIALS A .
Backer Rod .
Size the diameter of the backer rod to be a minimum of  inch larger than the widest point of the joint opening .
Implementation Sealing Existing Concrete Slope Protection Joints Page of January .
Use a closed cell foam expansion joint filler .
a .
Meets the physical properties in Table using test method ASTM D utilizing a inch backer rod specimen .

PART EXECUTION .
GROOVE JOINT AND CRACK LOCATIONS A .
Mark the limits of all grooves joints and cracks in the presence of the Engineer .
This applies to all grooves joints and cracks that require sealing. . Seal cracks inch and larger . .
PREPARE GROOVES JOINTS AND CRACKS A .
Remove the existing joint or groove material and all other debris from the designated grooves joints and cracks .
Remove curing compounds oil grease dirt moisture and any other foreign materials from the groove joint or cracked concrete surfaces by sandblasting. . SEAL GROOVES JOINTS AND CRACKS A .
Use a backer rod when the joint width is equal to or greater than  inch .
B. Seal the grooves joints and cracks as field marked .
C. Seal horizontal grooves joints and cracks by starting at one side and proceed to the other side .
Implementation Sealing Existing Concrete Slope Protection Joints Page of January D. Seal vertical grooves joints and cracks from the top to bottom. . SEAL WINGWALLS AND BACKWALL JOINTS A .
Place the rigid plastic foam against the surface of all structural members before placing the joint sealant .
B. Anchor the rigid plastic foam in place with a compatible adhesive .
C. Recess the rigid plastic foam  inch in the joints so a groove is formed above the rigid plastic foam filler .
D. Fill the recess above the rigid plastic foam with sealant so the joint is sealed over completely. . PLACE SEALANT A .
Place with a hand or power operated caulking gun after placing the backer rod .
B .
Tool the sealant using a concave pointing tool with soap solution .
C. Do not place sealant unless temperature is at least degrees F and rising .
D. Finish sealant in a neat and clean fashion. . Verify there are no irregular surfaces including peaks and valleys . .
Remove sealant outside of the joint .

B .

for the first field coat and No .
for the top coat following Federal Standard .
PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL A .
Use manufacturers information regarding the specified coating materials including required wet and dry film thickness project safety data thinning recommendations temperature requirements profile recommendations mixing and application procedures and required equipment . .
INSPECTION A .
Engineer examines surfaces before surface preparation and before application of each succeeding coating .
Correct any condition that is determined by the Engineer to negatively affect a proper coating application .
Implementation Painting For Structural Steel Page of January B .
Provide safe access to permit inspection of the steel before and after painting .
Use rubber rollers or other approved protective devices for scaffold fastenings .
Do not mar or damage freshly coated surfaces . .
PREPARE SURFACES A .
Painted steel Clean surfaces with clean petroleum solvents and then blast clean to a nearwhite condition following SSPCSP .
Use clean oilfree air . .
Grind off all fins tears slivers and burred or sharp edges present on any steel member or those that result from the blasting operation .
a. Reblast where needed .
b .
Remove all mill scale .
c. Do not scar metal .
d. Grind the edges of all flame cut steel until the hardened edge accepts the blast profile .
Refer to ASTM D method A. e. Produce a . mils uniform profile not to exceed manufacturers recommendation . .
Remove all abrasive and paint residue using either a commercial vacuum cleaner or by double blowing .
a. Equip commercial vacuum cleaner with a brushtype cleaning tool .
b .
Double blowing Vacuum the top surfaces of all structural steel including items such as top and bottom flanges longitudinal stiffeners splice plates and hangers after the doubleblowing operations are completed. . Keep the steel dust free and prime within hours after cleaning .
Reblast to a nearwhite condition if any rust is visible before priming . .
Protect freshly coated surfaces from subsequent blastcleaning operations .
a .
Repair surface if damaged .
b .
Mask all areas requiring field welding before shop painting. . Have the surfaces inspected and approved by Engineer or Construction and Materials Division representative of Department before applying shop coat . .
Apply the shop coat at the fabrication site .
Apply coatings at the fabrication site in an enclosure with a controlled environment to match optimum conditions for application and curing as stated in the manufacturers product data sheet . .
Apply mist coat to the top flange .
Implementation Painting For Structural Steel Page of January B .
Field Painting .
Repair all damage to shop coat that occurs during shipping handling and erection. . Power wash steel without the field coat to remove contaminants or other foreign matter from the primed surface . .
Blast clean bolt heads fasteners and any rusted areas to a near white finish .
Thoroughly clean the coating surrounding the blasted area and reprime the same day using organic zinc from the same paint manufacturer and the same dry film thickness specified for the shop coat .
Follow SSPCSP . .
Remove all concrete drippings abrasive and paint residue .
Vacuum items such as the top and bottom flanges splice plates longitudinal stiffeners and hangers after completing doubleblowing operations . .
Allow the touchup coat to dry according to manufacturers recommendation as listed on the product data sheet . .
PREPARE PAINT MATERIALS A .
Mix and thin paint materials according to manufacturers product data sheets for both shop and field painting .
B .
Mix the paint to a lumpfree consistency with a high shear mixer such as a Jiffy mixer according to the manufacturers directions. . Do not use paddle mixers or paint shakers. . Keep paint in the original containers . .
Mix until all the metallic powder or pigment is suspended and until all paint solids that may have settled to the bottom of the container are thoroughly dispersed .
C. Strain the paint through a screen having openings no larger than those specified for a No .
sieve according to the material standard .
Refer to ASTM E . D. Strain and continuously agitate the mixed material up to and during application . .
APPLY PAINT A .
Apply field coats at the construction site after steel erection work is completed. . Do not apply field coats until Engineer verifies the surface. . Dry film thickness of the first field coat must be greater than mils. . Keep the dryfilm thickness of the top coat greater than mils .
Implementation Painting For Structural Steel Page of January B .
Use wet and dry film thickness gauges for testing the coating thickness during and after application .
C. Apply each coat at required consistency and thickness according to the manufacturers recommendations including field coating .
Use pressures recommended by the manufacturer of the coating system when using spray nozzles .
D. Produce a uniform even coating that bonds to the underlying surface .
Refer to SSPCPA .
E. Weather .
Follow the manufacturers recommendations if weather conditions require paint thinning . .
Temperature of the air and the steel must be above degrees F but not so hot as to cause the paint to blister . .
Relative humidity must be less than percent or the combination of temperature and humidity conditions must inhibit surface condensation. . Test humidity by applying a thin film of water to a small area .
Surface may be painted if the film evaporates within minutes . .
The steel temperature must be a minimum of degrees F above the dew point .
F. Use necessary equipment for the proper application of the specified coating .
Observe safety practices found in SSPCPA Guide Guide to Safety and Health Requirements .
G. Blast clean any shop coat that shows any indication of mudcracking or adds more than mils to a soundly bonded coating or bare steel .
Refer to SSPCSP .
H. Thoroughly clean areas that have deficient primer thickness to remove all dirt .
I .
Apply an intermediate and top coat to any surface at the fabrication site that will be inaccessible for painting after field erection .
J .
Do not load structural steel for shipment until shop paint is dry to the touch .
K. Protect all paint systems .
Place softeners between plates of cross frames and diaphragms .
Implementation Painting For Structural Steel Page of January .
PROTECTION A .
Stop work if protection is unsatisfactory .
B .
Protect pedestrian and vehicular traffic .
C. Protect all portions of the structures that are not to be painted from splatter splashes and overspray including superstructure substructure slope and highway appurtenances .
Protect areas during painting and blast cleaning operations where other damage can occur .
D. Use barriers during any blastcleaning operations to protect pedestrians and vehicles and to prevent spreading or falling of abrasive materials and debris on the traveled portions of the pavement .
Remove any abrasive materials and debris on pavement shoulders or slope paving before reopening work areas to traffic .
E. Provide employees performing the blastcleaning operations airsupplied blasting hoods approved by the Mine Safety and Health Administration and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health .
F. Minimum requirements for the air supply system .
Airline filter pressurereducing valve with gauge and pressure release valve. . Do not allow the air supply to be contaminated with harmful materials or elements .
Refer to ASTM D . . QUALITY ASSURANCE A .
Minimum Coating Thickness Apply two or more coats if the required film thickness can not be obtained by one coat without producing runs bubbles or sags .
B .
Refer to SSPC PA . END OF SECTION Implementation Concrete Coating Page of January SECTION CONCRETE COATING PART GENERAL .
