PART PRODUCTS .
CONCRETE COATING SYSTEM A .
Water Repellent Use a clear penetrating water repellent as a base coat as described .
The water repellent coat must be compatible with the concrete sealer. . Meet VOC content of gL or less .
Refer to ASTM D . B. Tinted Concrete Sealer Use a high silicone content acrylic concrete sealer that provides a durable opaque deep penetrating water repellent decorative finish to concrete and masonry surfaces. . Tint the concrete sealer to provide the colors as described .
Meet VOC content of gL or less .
Refer to ASTM D . PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL A .
Use only one concrete coating system on an individual structure .
B. Furnish prepare apply cure and store all materials according to the product manufacturers directions and as specified in this Section. . Do not freeze material subjected .
Deliver concrete coating materials to the project site in sealed containers bearing the manufacturers original labels with the brand color and type clearly marked on each container .
C. Apply the water repellent and tinted concrete sealer to the concrete surfaces shown .
Implementation Concrete Coating Page of January .
CONCRETE SURFACE PREPARATION A .
Finish minor defects to blend with the balance of the textured surfaces. . Repair visible vertical or horizontal seams or conspicuous form marks to the satisfaction of the Engineer .
B .
Cure all new concrete surfaces a minimum of days before applying coating . .
Cure days as an alternate to days if the concrete has a pH level of or lower according to ASTM D and no surface moisture according to ASTM D . Test concrete surface for pH and surface moisture in four locations as directed by the Engineer . .
Cure concrete patches a minimum of seven days before being coated. . Meet manufacturers requirements .
C. Clean the concrete surface to be coated by pressure washing. . Use a minimum water pressure of psi at a flow rate of to galmin. . Use a fan nozzle held perpendicular to the surface at a distance of inches to inches . .
Prevent overblasting exposing additional air pockets disfiguring the surface or reducing architectural surface textures. . Clean the final concrete surface to be free from release agents grease dirt and any other contaminants .
Remove curing compounds that deter penetration of the coating system. . Rinse with potable water if detergents or degreasers are used in the cleaning process .
D. Perform pH test according to ASTM D before coating concrete surfaces. . Add acidetch to the power wash stream to reduce the pH if the pH exceeds refer to ASTM D . Rinse acidetched surfaces with potable water no sooner than one hour after acid etch application and before retesting the pH level. . Repeat process until the pH level does not exceed . . Do not perform pH test when applying coating over an existing coating .
E. Perform chloride test using Chlortest by ChlorRid Company SCAT test by KTA Tator or approved equal. . Add a salt remover to the power wash stream to reduce the chloride level and retest the surface if the chloride level exceeds ppm .
Implementation Concrete Coating Page of January .
Repeat the process until the chloride level does not exceed ppm .
F. Comply with the manufacturers recommendations for surface preparation . .
COATING SYSTEM APPLICATION GENERAL A .
Do not apply the coating if the surface is wet due to rain or other precipitation . .
Allow all wet surfaces at least hours to dry before coating .
B .
Do not apply if rain is expected within hours following application .
C. Coat only when the outside air temperature will remain between and degrees F during and for at least hours after application . .
Obtain authorization for a Weather Deviation for temperatures outside of this range .
D. Reclean contaminated surfaces as defined in this Section article .
before the application of the next coat if surface becomes contaminated between coats .
E. Stir the coating materials thoroughly before and during application .
F. Reduce pressure to prevent atomizing of product which causes dry spray when applying the coating by spray application. . Use a sprayer with a . to .
inch tip opening or as recommended by the manufacturer. . Spray from multiple angles to ensure that all surface texture impressions are covered. . Spray upper areas from raised platforms .
G. Protect coated surfaces from damage or detrimental elements during drying and curing. . WATER REPELLENT APPLICATION A .
Apply water repellent when shown or specified .
B Water repellent is a base coat under two coats of concrete sealer .
C. Follow manufacturers recommendations for temperature requirements application rate equipment and any other requirements for application .
Implementation Concrete Coating Page of January D. Thoroughly cure the water repellent a minimum of hours or as recommended by the manufacturer before applying the tinted concrete sealer. . TINTED CONCRETE SEALER APPLICATION A .
Apply a minimum of two coats of the tinted concrete sealer . .
Apply the first coat evenly at an application rate of gal sealer to sq ft working in one direction . .
Cure the first coat of the tinted concrete sealer a minimum of hours or as recommended by the manufacturer before the second coat of the tinted concrete sealer is applied . .
Apply the second coat evenly at an application rate of gal sealer to sq ft working in the opposite direction of the first coat .
B .
Remove graffiti on previously coated areas by applying the tinted concrete sealer over affected area .
Apply multiple coats as determined by the Engineer to completely cover the graffiti . .
Evenly apply the tinted concrete sealer at an application rate of gal sealer to sq ft. . Use the same color as the original application .
C. Dilute the tinted concrete sealer with Xylene at a rate of galdrum or approximately percent when applying the first coat over smooth dense steel formed vertical surfaces. . Do not dilute on more porous concrete or when applying the second coat .
D. Comply with the manufacturers recommendations for application. . FIELD INSPECTION A .
Do not apply any coat until the Department has verified compliance with manufacturers recommendations and this specification .
B .
Use rubber rollers or other approved protective devices on scaffold fastenings .
Implementation Concrete Coating Page of January .
PROTECTION FROM WORK A .
Protect all surfaces that are not to be coated including structures slopes and highway appurtenances from splatter splashes and overspray or when damage during power washing and coating operations may occur .
B .
Protect all citizens and private property from splatter splashes and overspray including but not limited to buildings pedestrians and vehicles . .
Prevent materials and debris from spreading or falling on the traveled portions of the pavement .
C. Suspend work if protection is unsatisfactory .
D. Remove any abrasive material and debris deposited on the structure pavement shoulders or slope protection before reopening work areas to traffic. . CLEAN UP A .
Follow the manufacturers recommendations for cleaning spills and spatters .
B .
Follow all federal state and local laws for hazardous material cleanup and disposal. . SAFETY PRECAUTIONS A .
Follow safety precautions according to manufacturers product data sheets and Material Safety Data Sheet .

PREPARATION REPAINTING STRUCTURAL STEEL A .
Clean surfaces including bearing units of all oil grease and dirt with clean petroleum solvents or steam cleaning before blasting operation .
B .
Blast surfaces clean to near white with .
to mil profile .
Refer to SSPC SP .
C. Discoloration light shadows or slight streaks caused by stains of rust is not allowed on more than percent of surface area .
D. Define acceptable surface preparation using SSPCVis .
E. Use SSPCSP to clean areas such as backside of base plates and corners that can not otherwise be cleaned .
F. Prime the surface within hours after blasting .
G. Do not prime the surface if rust has started to form .
Clean the surface again before applying the prime coat . .
PREPARATION OVERCOATING STRUCTURAL STEEL A .
Clean designated surfaces of all oil grease debris and dirt with clean petroleum solvents .
Follow with highpressure wash SSPCSP .
B .
Remove all corrosion and all paint that shows peeling brittleness checking scaling or general disintegration including bearing units. . Use vacuum shrouded power tool cleaning SSPCSP . .
Remove paint from the area and beyond the edges of the area so that remaining paint system shows no rusting or blistering underneath and adheres tightly to the surface .
Remaining paint system should have sufficient adhesion that can not be lifted as a layer by inserting a blade or putty knife under it .
Meet requirements of ASTM D and D . . Feather the edges of the remaining paint system around the cleaned areas so the repainted surface appears smooth .
Implementation Cleaning and Repainting or Overcoating Structural Steel Page of January .
PREPARE PAINT MATERIALS A .
Mix the paint to a lumpfree consistency with a high shear mixer according to the manufacturers directions. . Do not use paddle mixers or paint shakers. . Keep paint in the original containers and mix until all the metallic powder or pigment is suspended. . Continue mixing until all solids or pigments that may have settled to the bottom of the container are thoroughly dispersed .
B .
Strain the paint through a screen with openings no larger than those specified for a No .
sieve .
Refer to ASTM E . C. Strain and continuously agitate the mixed material up to and during application . .
APPLY PAINT GENERAL A .
Field Inspection .
Do not apply paint until the Engineer verifies the prepared surface. . Use rubber rollers or other approved protective devices on scaffold fastenings. . Do not use metal rollers clamps and other types of fastenings that mar or damage freshly coated surfaces .
B .
Consult with the manufacturers technical representative for answers to technical questions related to the application of the specified coating materials .
C. Project ConditionsWeather Limitations .
Follow the manufacturers recommendations if weather conditions require paint thinning . .
Apply paint only when the following weather conditions exist a .
The temperature of the air and the steel are above degrees F but not so hot as to cause the paint to blister .
b .
The relative humidity is less than percent or such that the combination of temperature and humidity conditions inhibits surface condensation .
c. Apply a thin film of water to a small area to test humidity .
The surface may be painted if the film evaporates within minutes .
d. The steel temperature is a minimum of degrees F above dew point .
Implementation Cleaning and Repainting or Overcoating Structural Steel Page of January D. Use necessary equipment for proper application of the specified coating .
Observe safety practices found in SSPCPA Guide Guide to Safety and Health Requirements .
E. Apply paint with spray nozzles at pressures recommended by the manufacturer of the coating system .
F. Use wet and dry film thickness gauges for testing the coating thickness during and after application .
Refer to SSPCPA .
Use equipment capable of taking dry film thickness readings on all portions including nuts and bolts .
G. Apply two or more coats if the required film thickness could not be obtained by one coat without producing runs bubbles or sags .
H. Apply paint to produce a uniform even coating that bonds to the underlying surface .
Refer to SSPCPA . .
APPLY PAINT REPAINTING STRUCTURAL STEEL A .
Prime Coat .
Maintain the dry film thickness of the prime coat between .
and .
mils . .
Blast clean any coat that produces mudcracking or adds more than .
mils to a soundly bonded coating on bare steel .
Refer to SSPCSP .
Recoat the surface . .
Thoroughly clean areas that have deficient primer thickness with power washing equipment to remove all dirt .
Wirebrush vacuum and recoat the area .
B .
Intermediate Coat .
Use the coating type and minimum dry film thickness specified. . Produce a dryfilm thickness of the intermediate coat greater than mils .
C. Top coat Keep the dry film thickness greater than mils . .
APPLY PAINT OVERCOATING STRUCTURAL STEEL A .
Intermediate Coat .
Spot paint any areas with bare steel followed by another full intermediate coat over the entire steel surface . .
Apply a minimum dry film thickness of mils for the spot coat and a minimum of mils for the full intermediate coat .
Implementation Cleaning and Repainting or Overcoating Structural Steel Page of January B .
Top Coat .
Apply top coat to entire steel surface. . Keep the dry film thickness at mils or greater .

D. Furnish an internal heavyduty nonmetallic cable storage rack system on two opposite fiber vault walls. . Furnish and install two stanchions on each rack wall .
a. Fasten to the fiber vault wall according to the manufacturers instructions .
b. Stanchions are a minimum of inches for Type IVCV fiber vault racks .
c. Stanchions are a minimum of inches For Type VCV fiber vault racks. . Use cable rack arms that are appropriate for the amount of slack cable being installed but not be less than rack arms in a Type IV vault and rack arms in a Type V vault capable of supporting a minimum of lb .

Implementation Precast Concrete Fiber Optic and Utility Vault Page of January .
Fiber vaults with hinged metal lids will be rated for AASHTO LRFD HL loading according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications . .
Fiber vaults with round manhole style lids will be rated for AASHTO LRFD HL loading according to AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications .
F. Provide hinged metal lids that have doubledoors split and double hinges . .
Provide a lid that operates freely over degrees . .
Provide a lid with drop handles for easy opening . .
Provide a neoprene gasket between the hinged lid and the vault frame .
G. Provide lids with a grounding lug with  NC female threads on the underside of the manhole and hinged metal lids .
H. Provide hinged and manhole lids with PentaHead vandal resistant stainless steel bolts with washer. . All bolt holes must be selfdraining .
I. Furnish hinged metal lids that have a nonskid diamond pattern or similar surface that has a raised pattern of at least inch high .
J .
Provide lids for all vaults that are marked UDOT FIBER OPTIC using a minimum inch high letters with inch line thickness. . Form the letters by engraving casting stamping or with a precise weld bead .
K. Manhole Lid Access Points recessed steel pull slots or holes to allow removal or opening of the manhole with a hook or lever . .

PART EXECUTION .
GENERAL A .
Maximum spacing between junction boxes and vaults .
ft for electrical cable. . ft for fiber optic cable on tangent surface street installations. . ft for fiber optic cable on tangent highway installations. . Reduce maximum spacing if horizontal or vertical deflection incurred during installation prevents the installation of cable within maximum pulling tension rating of the cable . .
Notify the Engineer if utility avoidance requires junction box and conduit locations differing from requirements for deflection in this Section article ..
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January B .
Minimum Cover of Conduit .
Minimum cover under pavement is ft and minimum cover under sidewalks is ft. .
Minimum cover in highway rightofway greater than ft from the edge of the pavement is ft. .
Minimum cover in highway rightofway within ft of the edge of the pavement is ft. .
Refer to State of Utah Administrative Rule .
INSTALLATION A .
Prevent conduit from deflecting vertically or horizontally along its length by a ratio greater than no more than inch deflection per inch in length when installing conduit that houses communication cable .
B .
Prevent sum total of the vertical and horizontal conduit deflection or bend between any two junction boxes from exceeding degrees when installing conduit .
C. Install conduit within ft of existing parallel conduit run if the planned location of conduit is parallel to the existing traffic signal or ATMS conduit .
D. Obtain approval for field bending of conduit with the Engineer in cases where factory sweeps are not appropriate .
Field bending must be performed using a heat box or heat blanket .
Torch heating conduit is prohibited .
Install all conduit bends to have a radius that is not less than the following .
inches within the cabinet and pole foundations .
inches in all other locations .
inches for MD microduct bundle .
inches for MD microduct bundle .
inches for MD microduct bundle .
inches for MD microduct bundle .
inches for individual microduct E. Install conduits that cross finished curbs and gutters sidewalks concrete flatwork or textured or decorative surfaces by boring jacking or drilling .
Replace any damaged concrete sections joint to joint .
Refer to Section .
F. Proof all conduit before installation of cabling and detectable pull tape. . Use a mandrel at least percent of the conduit diameter at least twice as long as the conduit diameter and composed of rigid material . .
Schedule proofing with the Engineer at least working days in advance of performing the work .
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January .
Proof all conduit with a Department representative witness present . .
Complete and submit a completed Conduit Mandrel Test Form for all ATMS conduit . .
Proof microducts using proofing balls. . Proofing balls must maintain a minimum percent fill ratio of inside diameter of the microduct being tested. . Proofing must occur after all junction boxes have been installed to final grade including placement of flowable fill or handmix grout at junction box walls and after all excavation in the immediate proximity of the conduit system has been completed .
a. Reproof any conduit segment where excavation has occurred near the conduits following initial proof testing .
G. Provide detectable pull tape in all conduits . .
Install continuously between junction boxes. . Fasten securely to conduit plug and leave ft of pull tape slack inside of the conduit. . Do not splice detectable pull tape in conduit. . Use flat profile low stretch polyester lb tensile strength detectable pull tape that is sequential footage marked. . Verify that the pull tape is detectable throughout its entire length by performing a continuity test or equivalent verification. . Detectable pull tape not required in microducts .
H. Encase open trench conduit in sand backfill covered by flowable fill within existing roadway proposed roadway and sidewalk pavement areas only. . Seal junction box wall around conduits using flowable fill or approved handmix grout. . Use inches of sand backfill covered with native material in all other areas . .
Refer to AT Series Standard Drawings .
I .
Use rigid metal conduit or schedule PVC conduit for above ground application. . Liquidtight flexible metal conduit LFMC or liquidtight flexible non metallic conduit LFNC is permitted in lengths not exceeding ft where not subject to physical damage . .
Apply corrosion protection to any portion of rigid metal conduit buried in the ground or encased in concrete .
J .
Use PVC or HDPE conduit for underground application .
K. Warning Tape .
Install orange warning tape with black legend Caution Buried Communication Cable in all trenches containing multiduct conduit or conduit containing communication cables .
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January .
Install red warning tape with black legend Caution Buried Electric in all other trenches. . Not required when flowable fill is directly overlaid with asphalt pavement or PCCP. . Not required when boring or plowing conduit .
L. Install a bushing or adapter at ends of all conduits that contain a conductor according to the NEC .
M. Furnish and install Utility Marker Posts along the longitudinal conduit running line .
Refer to AT Series Standard Drawings and Section .
N. Install a AWG solid insulated locate wire inside of new or existing conduit with individual microducts. . Verify that all locate wires are detectable throughout their entire length by performing a continuity test or equivalent verification. . TRENCH A. Paved Asphalt Surface .
Install Tpatch over trenched area according to AT Series Standard Drawings. . Cut pavement from roadway surface to roadway base on both sides of trench to provide a clean straight wall for Tpatch before any backhoe use according to Section . .
Refer to AT Series Standard Drawings for depth of flowable fill under paved surfaces . .
Evenly apply tack coat on final backfill before installing Tpatch. . Place restoration patch match the composition density and elevation  inch of the existing surface according to Section . .
Apply a hotpour rubberized asphalt joint sealant or approved equal after the patch is installed .
B. Sidewalk or Decorative Pavement .
Use flowable fill to bottom of new pavement or sidewalk . .
Match existing pavement thickness .
New pavement thickness must be  inches minimum and inches maximum . .
Restore sidewalk or decorative pavement to original condition or better after work is completed .
Refer to Section .
C. Unpaved Surface .
Backfill using native material if suitable that matches the composition density and elevation .
inch of the existing surface according to Section . .
Dispose of surplus material promptly .
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January .
Sand Backfill a .
Use sand backfill in trench sections outside of existing roadway proposed roadway and sidewalk pavement areas including exposed conduit locations when plowing or boring .
b .
Provide inches of sand backfill above conduit in trench .
Backfill trench above sand to finished grade using native material .
a Backfill and tamp in inch lifts .
c. Compaction of sand backfill is not required .
D. Sleeve foreign utilities that cross a trench so they are not encased in flowable fill .
E. Place all conduits in the same trench whenever possible .
F. Flowable Fill or Handmix Grout .
Install flowable fill or approved handmix grout to the wall of junction box to seal conduit entry into junction box. . Clean excess flowable fill or handmix grout from the inside of the junction box .
G. Install all conduits so the flowable fill or sand backfill completely encases all exterior surfaces of the conduit . .
Separate multiduct conduits using a commercially available conduit spacer or approved equivalent. . Place spacers no more than ft apart and not more than ft from each coupler .
H. Anchor the conduit in trench at ft intervals to maintain the required conduit depth during flowable fill placement .
I .
Minimum separation between all conduits and the wall of the trench is  inches . .
BORE OR PLOW A .
Immediately contain remove and properly dispose of all excess drilling fluid. . USE OF EXISTING OR OCCUPIED CONDUIT A .
Maintain the physical condition and functional integrity of all cabling and wiring in existing or occupied conduit .
B .
Cable or wire installation in an existing or occupied conduit . .
Remove any existing fiber optic cable or copper wire .
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January .
Test the integrity and clean the conduit by successfully pulling a Departmentapproved mandrel through the conduit. . Repull existing and new fiber optic cable or copper wire together . .
Perform all necessary splices and replace any impacted fiber cable and spider fanout kits according to Section .
C. Use existing conduit insitu only if shown and as approved by the Engineer .
D. Intercept individual microducts from existing microduct bundle midspan and reroute to new junction box location .
Type IIPC junction box a .
Bury at existing microduct bundle depth .
b .
Notch the inch box walls and install junction box over existing microduct bundle .
c. Provide inches of free draining granular backfill borrow underneath junction box .
d. Encase all conduit in flowable fill orhandmix grout where the conduit enters the junction box .
e. Place locate ball or disk in junction box .
f. Ground rod and grout floor are not required. . Conduit and microduct bundle inside of buried Type IIPC junction box .
a .
Install conduit from buried junction box to new junction box location for rerouting of individual microducts .
Provide AWG solid insulated locate wire inside of new conduit between junction boxes .
b .
Extend conduit and microduct oversheath inches beyond inside wall of the junction box .
c. Expose microducts by removing no more than inches of oversheath .
d. Identify and cut only the individual microducts to be rerouted .
e. Use approved couplers and extend microducts to new junction box using corresponding microduct color .
f. Splice all locate wires together using an approved waterproof connector .
Verify that the locate wire conductors are not exposed. . New junction box location a .
Install new junction box within ft of buried junction box or within ft of edge of roadway when existing microduct bundle is underneath roadway to provide access to locate wire for mapping and locating purposes .
Implementation ATMS Conduit Page of January .
REPAIR OR RESTORATION A .
Restore all areas including landscaping concrete pavement asphalt finished curbs and gutters box culverts sewers underground water mains sprinkler systems sidewalks concrete flatwork colored textured or decorative surfaces damaged during conduit and junction box installation .
B .
Coordinate with local utilities for utility repair .
C. Notify the Engineer of all necessary repairs .
D. Replace all damaged facilities in kind .
E. Buried microduct bundle coupling and repair .
Expose microducts by removing no more than inches of oversheath beyond area to be coupled or repaired .
a .
Trim microducts to length as necessary to eliminate all bends and deflection. . Use approved couplers. . Splice the locate wires together using an approved waterproof connector .
a. Verify that the locate wire conductors are not exposed . .
Protect exposed microducts couplers and locate wire using split duct .
a. Seal split duct joints and split duct ends around microduct bundle oversheath using approved waterproof sealing tape or other approved methods prior to backfill .
b .
Do not use heatshrink or coldshrink protection methods .

Refer to AT Series Standard Drawings for dimensions of junction box types .
B. Furnish boxes rings and lids that meet all the requirements of ANSISCTE including Tier loading .
C. Use split lids with Type IIIPC junction boxes .
D. Use lids for all junction boxes specified by application . .
Manufacture lids with the following marking in the logo area in inch cast in place recessed letters a. UDOT Fiber Optics when the junction box contains only fiber optic cable or future use multi duct conduit .
b .
Traffic Signal Street Lighting Electrical Communications and Landscaping may also use this type of description as an alternative to using attached name plates .
Implementation Polymer Concrete Junction Box Page of January .
Manufacture lids with a recessed area to accommodate name plates used for all other Traffic Signal Street Lighting Electrical Communications and Landscaping applications .
a .
Attach name plates to each removable lid section as well as one to the inside wall of the junction box using adhesive and noncorroding screws .
Use an adhesive that meets or exceeds the following criteria .
Tensile Strength psi .
Service temperature cured subzero to F. .
Cure time hours b. Insert two noncorroding tamper resistant screws after adhesive is cured . .
Determine the name plate description using the Junction Box Logo Decision Chart found on the UDOT Standards and Specifications References httpwww.udot.utah.govgostandardsreferences E. Lid Access Points recessed reinforced steel pull slots rated for pounds to allow removal of cover with a hook or lever .
Replace lid if damage occurs to the pulling point .
F. Lid Bolt Holes self draining .
G. Bolts Zinc plated recessed hex head coil bolts with washer .

LOCATE BALL OR DISK A .
Place a marker ball or disk in each junction box. . Color orange .
Requires no particular orientation when buried .
Place in bottom of each box .
Must produce a uniform spherical RF field in all directions .
Signal peak when directly over the ball .
Meets RUS Specifications PART EXECUTION .
BACKFILL A .
Place inches of free draining granular backfill under junction boxes .
B .
Compact granular backfill borrow or approved native soil around the junction box collar .
Match the top inches to the composition density and elevation of the surrounding surface. . JUNCTION BOX AND EXTENSION A .
Install according to manufacturers recommendations .
B. Precast junction boxes with precast conduit holes or drill holes to match conduit entry where required without damaging the box .
Use grout to create a complete seal between conduit and the junction box wall .
Finish grout smooth and flush with the interior wall. . Make drilled holes in junction box not more than  inches larger than conduit diameter. . Seal conduit and microduct ends inside all junction boxes with at least inch thick duct seal after cables are installed. . Seal vacant conduit and microducts with a manufactured conduit plug and attach detectable pull tape where applicable .
Refer to Section .
C. Level the top of junction box and grade with positive drainage away from the box .
Implementation Polymer Concrete Junction Box Page of January D. Conduit in junction box .
Do not install conduit within inches of junction box corner . .
Extend PVC conduit inches HDPE conduit inches microduct oversheath inches and individual microducts ft beyond the inside wall of the junction box. . Align ATMS conduit ends by color at each side of the box . .
Enter conduit through the sides of the junction box and not from the bottom. . Place the conduit in the bottom half of the junction box wall at least inches above the floor . .
Install bushings on all conduits before cable installation according to Section . .
Refer to AT Series Standard Drawings .
E. Remove concrete sidewalk or other surfaces that require removal by saw cutting . .
Remove entire section of concrete joint to joint .
Refer to Section . .
Replace with inkind materials to match the existing grade texture and color of concrete or other surface .
F. Install Engineerapproved  inch preformed expansion joint material around entire periphery of ring for junction boxes installed in paved surface .
G. Encase all conduit in flowable fill or approved handmix grout where the conduit enters the junction box .
H. Provide a castinplace inch thick grout floor with a inch diameter drain at the low point for all Type I II and IIIPolymer Concrete Junction Boxes or provide a box with a prefabricated floor with a inch drain hole .
Use grout according to ASTM C and ASTM C . I .
Do not stack boxes . .

INSTALL PEDESTALMOUNTED CABINET A .
Install pedestalmounted cabinets so the door that accesses the front face of the control equipment is adjacent to the Type IIPC junction box. . Securely fasten the cabinet onto the concrete foundation . .
Install the cabinet door to be able to fully open and close after the cabinet has been installed on the foundation .
B. Orient cabinet on foundation with the vented door downstream of traffic .
C. Caulk between base of cabinet and top of foundation to form a watertight seal .
Provide a raintight seal that does not degrade the NEMA R enclosure rating . .
Refer to NEMA Standards Publication for ratings of the enclosure for all conduit fittings and chases to adjoining enclosures .
D. Isolate dissimilar materials from one another by stainless steel fittings .
E. Make all power connections as shown in the contract and comply with the NEC. . Isolate the neutral bus from the cabinet and equipment ground. . Terminate the neutral bus at the neutral lug attached to the meter pedestal . .

Splice only in junction box. . Splice cables only in detection circuits where the wire type changes in the junction boxes .
a .
No other splices are allowed .
b .
Use a nylon tie wrap to secure the loop leads at the best location possible inside the pull box .
c. Provide loop leads that are at least inches long as measured from the top of the pull box to allow the Contractor to work on the splice above the box .
d. Carry the shield over the splice .
B .
Install detector homerun cable from loop wire to cabinet . .
Refer to Section . . Connect homerun cable to input file in cabinet to make loop detection fully functional at cabinet controller location . .
Install cabling neat and tight within the ATMS cabinet .

DEFINITIONS A .
Backbone Cable that connects two buildings or a building to a HubNode B .
Drop Cable that originates at a distribution splice interface cabinet or device and terminates at or links served devices .
C. Fiber Distribution Unit FDU A storage and management box for use in cabinets and communication hubs for the terminated ends and splice points of the fiber optic cable .
D. Full Splice A splice that has had all fibers spliced .
E. Ring Cut Splice A splice where only selected fibers are severed and others remain intact .

FIBER OPTIC CABLE INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS A .
Do not cut fiber cable or perform fiber splices in locations that are not shown in Department furnished Splice Plans .
B .
Notify the Engineer a minimum of five business days in advance of installing fiber optic cable into any existing conduit ATMS site or building facility or before beginning any testing required to be witnessed by Department .
C. Perform all work in facilities on conduits junction boxes cabinets and buildings containing the Departments existing equipment only in the presence of the Engineer or his authorized representative .
D. Restore contractorcaused damage or breaks to inuse project fiber cable and its conduit within hours of damage .
E. Lubricate cable with a lubricant designed for fiber optic cable installation .
Use the following minimum lubricant quantity for each cable pull Q .
D L Where Q the quantity of lubricant gallons D the diameter of the conduit inches L the length of the pull feet F. Use shear pins or other failsafe means to prevent exceeding the maximum cable pulling tension as rated by the cable manufacturer .
Implementation Fiber Optic Communication Page of January G. Maintain the following minimum bend radii .
times Cable Diameter during installation. . times Cable Diameter installed .
H. Cable Slack Requirements .
Pull and store excess cable slack at designated intervals including at each pull box splice box hub and each TMC or TOC . .
Equally distribute the slack on either side of the splice enclosure . .
The following are minimum required lengths of slack cable slack at locations with splice enclosures is measured from enclosure end plate to conduit .
a .
Type II and III Poly Concrete Junction Box No Splice ft b .
Fiber Splice Point Junction Box or Vault Cable End ft Ring Cut Location ft c. Future Splice Point total slack ft d. Bridge Barrier Wall Each End of Bridge ft e. Device Cabinet ft f. Hub Building Outside ft g. TMC and TOC OSP Entrance ft Max h. TMC and TOC IP at Equipment Room ft Max i .
Drop Cable ft or equal in length to existing fiber cable plus ft for splicing .
Provide proper storage of slack cable both long term and short term .
a .
Do not leave slack cable lying free on the ground or floor of a Device CabinetHubTOCTCC except during the pulling process .
b .
Neatly bind cables to be spliced together from conduit to splice enclosure with tape .
c. Submit shop drawings of the materials and installation of the anchored mounting channels to be installed in these areas for approval by the Engineer .
I .
Damage to the fiber optic cable defect or nonconformances of this Section must be resolved by removing and replacing entire segments of fiber optic cable between full splice points .
J .
Install microfiber cable into standard conduit sizes by jetting or blowing method or by pulling method while adhering to the maximum cable pulling tension as rated by the cable manufacturer .
Implementation Fiber Optic Communication Page of January K. Install fiber optic cables into conduits or microducts .
Conduit colorcode according to Section a .
Install cables in the following order blue orange green brown slate white red and black. . Microduct colorcode according to Section a .
Install cables in the following order .
Oversheath blue orange green and brown .
Microduct blue orange green brown slate white red and black .
L. Install fiber optic cables continuously within one conduit or microduct color throughout the entire cable run .
M. Terminate fibers as described in the Splice Plans .
N. Install new cabinet FDUs to replace any fanout kits or FDUs that must be severed to make fiber terminations O .

ENTRY AND REENTRY OF FIBER OPTIC SPLICE ENCLOSURES A .
Perform all work in an environmentally controlled atmosphere . .
Acceptable environments include office type environments in buildings splice trailers and splicing tents with floors. . Do not splice test connect or open fiber ends in locations with freezing temperatures rain snow or windblown dust. . Verify connectivity of all working fiber. . Verify connectivity and test according to this Section Article .
paragraph B before closing. . FUSION SPLICING A .
Use fusion splice method for all fiber splicing .
B .
Perform fusion splices as follows .
Use equipment with automatic fiber alignment and automatic light injection with detection devices or profile alignment algorithms to estimate splice losses . .
Provide splice enclosure as a protection for all splices and stripped cable. . House all splices in splice trays .
Implementation Fiber Optic Communication Page of January .
Use heat shrink tubing containing internal strength member to provide additional protection and strain relief of each fusion splice inside of splice tray . .
Comply with maximum splice loss allowance of .
dB as measured with a fusion machine as described in this Section Article .
paragraph B. . SPLICE ENCLOSURE AND TRAY LABELING REQUIREMENTS A .
Provide a minimum of ft of buffer tube slack from end plate .
B .
Provide label for each buffer tube located inch from the splice tray . .
Description on label will identify which fiber cable and direction cable is coming from. . Label will also include device type such as CCTV VMS or TMS. . Label distribution buffer tubes with tags marked Distribution and include direction of path such as westbound or eastbound .
C. Provide to ft of fiber optic strands outside of buffer tube from each cable before splicing .
D. Store all excess splice enclosure parts and hardware within the manufacturer supplied plastic bag and place inside of the enclosure for future use. . Verify parts and hardware are securely fastened inside of the enclosure to prevent damage of fiber optic buffer tubes and strands .
a .
Loose parts and hardware inside of the enclosure are strictly prohibited . .
ACCEPTANCE TESTING A. PreInstallation Test reel test .
Test the fiber optic cable at the site storage area before installation. . Test two optical fibers from each buffer tube from one end with an OTDR compatible with wavelength and fiber type. . Test for continuity length anomalies and approximate attenuation. . Record each measurement with color location and type of fiber measured. . Test for contractor protection only .
Submit to the Engineer upon request. . Use no less than ft of launch cable .

Perform all fiber optic testing with an OTDR capable of producing output files that are compatible with Department OTDR software or furnish the software necessary for viewing the OTDR data. . OTDR Testing Requirements a .
Test every fiber strand passing through any open splice tray after completing the required work .
Test all fibers both within the trunk cable and the drop cable .
b .
Conduct all traces with a launch cable or fiber test box between the OTDR and the fiber under test .
c. Do not exceed insertion loss .
dB .
d. Conduct all traces at both nm and nm .

Vertical Axis Attenuation scale in dB .

Cursors positioned at cable ends .

g. Provide an event table showing all events with more than .
dB loss containing event type position from OTDR end loss and reflectance .
h. The maximum total allowable attenuation is .
dB for cables less than ft km in length .
i .

END OF SECTION Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January SECTION ATMS INTEGRATION INSPECTION TESTING AND ACCEPTANCE PART GENERAL .
SECTION INCLUDES A .
Integrate all project ATMS devices including successful completion and documentation of all required inspections and operational tests .
B .
Installing connecting and configuring all incidental equipment and components as required for a complete and operational system .
C. Provide all necessary test equipment and other products necessary to test the integrated ATMS device subsystems and systems with no additional cost to the Department. . RELATED SECTIONS A .
Section Precast Concrete Fiber Optic and Utility Vault B .
Section ATMS Conduit C. Section Polymer Concrete Junction Box D. Section Fiber Optic Communication E. Section Electrical Power .
REFERENCES Not Used .
DEFINITIONS A .
Integration The process of enabling the completed ATMS device to function as intended .
This includes but may not be limited to connecting all items such as required communication control and power cables entering all required device parameters aiming devices such as antennas calibrating or adjusting devices enabling communication to the device from the TOC and completing all specified tests to verify that integration is complete .
Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January .

INTEGRATION A .
Provide qualified staff or sub consultants to perform ATMS device integration. . Use only those firms precertified by the Department to perform ATMS integration .
B .
Do not apply AC power to any device cabinet or system until after the Engineers Site Inspection and without the oversight of qualified integration personnel . .
INSPECTION AND TESTING A .
Testing and acceptance process .
Follow the required steps in the ATMS device testing and acceptance process shown in Table . .
Conduct testing and inspection steps in sequence .
a .
Multiple steps may be conducted on the same day with adequate notification and scheduling .
Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January .
Completion of all required submittal integration and testing steps as well as receipt of notification from the Engineer is required for acceptance . .
Perform testing except for Day ATMS burnin test in the presence of the Department and document with Department signature .
Table ATMS TESTING AND ACCEPTANCE PROCESS MATRIX REQUIRED TEST PREREQUISITES DESCRIPTION Punch List from Engineers Site Inspection ESI Complete and submit at the time of the Engineers Site Inspection ESI .
Include on the ESI Punch List items that must be completed or adjusted before any part of a device or system installation is energized .
Day ATMS Testing Pre Notification Submit days in advance of proposed test dates Test form to the Engineer days before each test or inspection that must be witnessed by the Department or authorized representative .
ATMS Cable and Conductor Test Basic construction of conduits boxes wiring and cabinets .
Perform this test after wire has been pulled but before devices are energized The ATMS Cable and Conductor Test is used to confirm that cable is not faulty and has not been damaged during installation Engineers Site Inspection ESI Receipt of all required submittals as noted in Sections and completion of basic construction elements The ESI is used to confirm that the device or system has been constructed according to the project requirements and is ready to be energized and begin the integration process .
The ESI will note any obvious issues with wiring configuration incorrect inventory differences from Project Plans or general cleanliness of the site .
Local Field Operations Test LFOT Successful completion of local configuration and integration as well as completion of operational punch list items from the ESI The LFOT is used to confirm that the device or system has been configured and integrated according to the project requirements and is ready to be tested centrally .
Systems Test if required Successful completion of LFOT and integration of device to central TOC control Project specific by Special Provision .
Certain projects or types of devices may require a complete system test where multiple elements applications or devices are tested simultaneously Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January ATMS TESTING AND ACCEPTANCE PROCESS MATRIX REQUIRED TEST PREREQUISITES DESCRIPTION Substantial Completion Inspection SCI Successful completion of the LFOT successful integration of device to the Traffic Operations Center active central communications to device The SCI is used to confirm that the ATMS device subsystem or system meets the operational parameters described within the project plans specifications and Special Provisions .
The Contractor must demonstrate the remote device sites communicate to the TOC and operate as a single integrated system as required in the project requirements in addition to having all construction and integration tasks completed .
The system will be considered substantially complete and may begin the day ATMS burnin period with the successful completion of this inspection and testing .
Day ATMS BurnIn Period Successful Substantial Completion Inspection and submission of the day ATMS burnin test form .
The day ATMS burnin period confirms that the ATMS device or system was properly constructed and integrated .
Acceptance Satisfactory completion of the day burnin test completion of all items on the Engineers Site Inspection punch list and submittal of approved As Built drawings .
Acceptance transfers ownership of the system or devices to the Department .
At that point the warranty begins and the ownership and maintenance of the site or system transfers to the Department .
Written notification from the Department to the contractor is required for Final Acceptance to occur .
Construction AsBuilt Drawings Within days after the Day ATMS Burn In Test .
AsBuilt drawings will be reviewed verified and accepted before final device or system acceptance .
AsBuilt drawings of each ATMS device installation showing actual locations of all installed conduit boxes and cabinets and any differences in construction from plans .
Fiber Optic Test Results Fiber optic cable test results .
Refer to Section Fiber Optic Communication for specific testing and submittal requirements .
B. ATMS Cable and Conductor Test .
Perform the Cable and Conductor Test before making any connections . .
Complete and submit Conductor Test Form. . Verify that all cables and conductors are installed according to the project requirements and the manufacturers recommended best practices before testing . .
Perform all resistance testing after final termination and cable installation but before any electronics or field device connections .
Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January .
Replace cable and retest if any cable fails to meet the parameters of the test or if any testing reveals any defects in the cable. . Furnish all equipment appliances and labor necessary to test the installed cable and conductors .
C. Engineers Site Inspection ESI .
Prepare for and complete the ESI after the completion of civil construction of device . .
Generate maintain submit and track a punch list of items that must be complete before a .
The device may be energized b .
The device may be accepted .
Complete the ESI and critical punch list items before energizing the cabinet or any internal device .
D. Local Field Operations Test LFOT .
Conduct the LFOT after completing the ESI punch list items and receiving . .
Complete and submit LFOT form. . Verify that all devices and material are installed according to the project requirements and manufacturers recommended best practices before testing. . Repair replace adjust or otherwise address issues with the device that prevents all test steps from passing .
a. Repeat test steps during and after repair until step is passed .
E. Substantial Completion Inspection SCI .
Prepare for and complete the SCI after completing the LFOT and receiving . .
Notify Region Blue Stakes Coordinator of the SCI walkthrough. . Verify that central communications to the device is active before initiating the SCI . .
Generate maintain and track SCI punch list of items .
F. Day ATMS BurnIn Test .
Conduct the Day ATMS burnin test after completing the SCI . .
Complete and submit the Day ATMS burnin test form. . Verify that central communications and electrical power are continually available during the day test period . .
The Engineer or designated representative will coordinate and oversee the full lifecycle of the burnin period .
a .
Operators at the TOC will monitor and exercise the devices remotely during the burnin test .
b .
The burnin period will continue for days unless an equipment failure occurs .
Implementation ATMS Integration Inspection Testing and Acceptance Page of January .
Perform a diagnostic test in the event that an equipment failure occurs .
a .
Respond and conduct diagnostic test within hours of notification by the Engineer .
b .
The burnin test will be suspended during diagnostic testing . .
Complete all necessary work to correct the problem within hours of notification unless the Engineer allows additional time . .
Submit Equipment Failure Report to the Engineer within hours after notification of the problem .
a .
Fully describe the problem its cause and all actions taken to rectify the failure .
b .
Provide the manufacturers name model field location and serial number for all equipment materials or software listed in the report .
c. Meet the operational requirements and project specifications for all equipment or modules used in the replacement or repair subject to the full testing process. . Do not perform field repairs on electrical or electronic equipment .
a .
Replace malfunctioning electrical or electronic equipment will in kind . .
Within two working days after receiving the Equipment Failure Report the Engineer will notify Contractor whether the day burn in test will be continued extended until a set time is reached or restarted by setting time back to day aero . .
ACCEPTANCE A .
The device system or subsystem may be accepted upon completion of the successful Day ATMS burnin test .
To complete the acceptance process a .
Confirm AsBuilt drawings have been submitted verified and approved .
b .
Confirm required submittals have been submitted .
c. Complete all ESI and SCI punch list items .
d. Request device acceptance .

MEDIUM VOLTAGE TERMINATIONS A .
Solid terminations Comply with the following classes of IEEE .
Insulation class is equivalent to that of cable . .
Include shield ground strap for shielded cable terminations. . Class terminations modular type furnished as a kit with stress relief tube multiple moldedsilicone rubber insulator modules shield ground strap and compressiontype connector. . Class terminations heatshrink type with heatshrink inner stress control and outer nontracking tubes multiple molded nontracking skirt modules and compressiontype connector. . Class terminations modular type furnished as a kit with stress relief shield terminator multiplewetprocess porcelain insulator modules shield ground strap and compressiontype connector .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January B. Separable insulated connectors modular system complying with IEEE with disconnecting singlepole cable terminators and with matching stationary plugin deadfront terminals designed for cable voltage and for sealing against moisture. . Terminations at distribution points modular type consisting of terminators installed on cables and modular deadfront terminal junctions for interconnecting cables. . Loadbreak cable terminators Elbowtype units with A load makebreak and continuouscurrent rating coordinated with insulation diameter conductor size and material of cable being terminated .
a .
Include test point on terminator body that is capacitance coupled. . DeadBreak Cable Terminators Elbowtype unit with A continuouscurrent rating designed for deenergized disconnecting and connecting coordinated with insulation diameter conductor size and material of cable being terminated .
a .
Include test point on terminator body that is capacitance coupled . .
DISCONNECT SWITCHES A. Fusible switches .
Type HD heavy duty single throw UL and NEMA KS with clips or bolt pads to accommodate indicated fuses lockable handle and interlocked with cover in closed position. . Internally mounted grounding and insulated neutral buses labeled for copper and aluminum ground conductors . .
Stainless steel NEMA Type X enclosure rating .
B. Nonfusible switches .
Type HD heavy duty single throw UL and NEMA KS lockable handle and interlocked with cover in closed position. . Internally mounted grounding and insulated neutral buses labeled for copper and aluminum ground conductors . .
Stainless steel NEMA Type X enclosure rating .
C. Enclosed Molded Case Circuit Breakers .
Comply with UL NEMA AB and NEMA AB with interrupting capacity to comply with available fault currents. . ThermalMagnetic trip unit with inverse timecurrent element for lowlevel overloads and instantaneous magnetic trip element for short circuits. . Internally mounted grounding and insulated neutral buses labeled for copper and aluminum ground conductors . .
Stainless steel NEMA Type X enclosure rating .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January .
PANELBOARDS A. Feeder and branch circuit panelboards comply with NEMA PB . .
Phase neutral and ground buses made of harddrawn copper percent conductivity. . Equipment ground bus sized adequately for feeder and branch circuit equipment grounding conductors bonded to box . .

B .

CONDUCTOR IDENTIFICATION MATERIALS A .
Colored mil thickness selfadhesive vinyl electrical tape complying with UL .
B .
Polyethylene or weather resistant nylon .
flag or wrap type cable marker. . Tag area is markable with manufacturers permanent marker or machine printed laminated label .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January PART EXECUTION .
INSTALLATION STANDARDS A .
Comply with NFPA NEC . .
PREPARATION A .
Comply with local power utility requirements . .
Contact power utility at least days before the connection date and verify the exact location voltage procedure and materials required by the power utility. . TRENCHING AND DIRECTIONAL BORING FOR CONDUIT A. Trenching Paved Asphalt Surface .
Do not use backhoe. . Make the trench inches wide or less. . Use flowable fill to within inches of the existing roadway surface unless otherwise specified . .
Apply tack coat evenly before final backfill when placing HMA . .
Match the composition density and elevation within inch of the existing pavement section .
B. Trenching Unpaved Surface .
Use backfill that matches the composition density and elevation within inch of the existing surface . .
Install conduits that cross finished curbs and gutters sidewalks concrete flatwork textured or decorative surfaces by jacking drilling or pushing . .
Dispose of surplus material promptly .
C. Minimum Conduit Cover .
Traffic Signals a .
Refer to SL series standard drawings. . All others a .
Refer to AT series standard drawings .
b .
Refer to Utah Administrative Rule D. Directional Boring .
Directional boring is an approved alternative to trenching unless otherwise specified . .
Immediately contain remove and properly dispose of all drilling fluid outside the bore .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January .
INSTALL CONDUIT A .
Use rigid metal conduit or Schedule PVC conduit for above ground application. . Liquidtight Flexible Metal Conduit or Liquidtight Flexible Non Metallic Conduit is permitted in lengths not exceeding ft where not subject to physical damage . .
Apply corrosion protection to any portion of rigid metal conduit buried in the ground or encased in concrete .
B .
Use PVC or HDPE conduit for underground application .
C. Install a bushing or bell end adapter at ends of all conduit .
D. Seal uncapped conduit ends inside junction box .
Conduit inches and smaller Seal with at least inches of duct caulking or PVC cap. . Conduit larger than inches Seal with duct plug or PVC cap .
E. Do not use a torch for bending or shaping PVC conduit. . Use equipment specifically designed to heat PVC conduit to shape any required curves or radii .
F. Use couplers specifically designed to couple PVC conduit to HDPE conduit .
G. Install weatherproof junction box with breakaway receptacle or fuse holder at breakaway structures .
H. Do not exceed degrees of conduit sweeps between individual junction boxes .
I .
Route conduit entering junction boxes to enter on the narrow side at an angle perpendicular to the box. . Run conduit to the junction box by the most direct route using the fewest bends possible .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January .
INSTALL CONDUCTORS A. Verify conduit is clean dry and free of dirt and debris before installing conductors .
B .
Use conductor manufacturer approved pulling compound or lubricant where necessary . .
Compound used must not deteriorate conductor or insulation .
C. Do not exceed manufacturers recommended maximum pulling tensions .
D. Install equipment grounding conductor in all conduits. . Copper grounding conductors must run continuously between and be bonded to ground rods in each junction box. . Aluminum grounding conductors must run continuously between junction boxes and be bonded to the ground rod in each junction box using a inch insulated copper pigtail conductor .
a .
Match copper pigtail gauge to aluminum grounding conductor gauge .
E. Install conductors from source to load in continuous lengths without splicing .
F. Terminate conductors. . Use wet location connectors in wet locations including all underground and inground locations. . Dry location twist type connectors may be used in dry above ground locations. . Do not use vinyl electrical tape as the sole means of insulating a connection or connector .
G. Identify each conductor by circuit phase voltage source and load. . Conductors AWG and smaller must have continuous outer insulation color complying with NEC requirements. . Conductors AWG and larger may be identified by use of colored phase tape at all junction boxes and terminations. . Group all conductors of each circuit using wrap around or flag type cable markers .
a .
Identify source and load location by description and milepost .
b .
Do not use Station Numbers to describe location .
H. Leave ft of slack conductor measured from the opening of each junction box that the conductor passes through .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January I .
Make aluminum conductor connections in accordance with NECA .
J .
Neatly arrange and support conductors within cabinets junction boxes and fixtures. . GROUNDING AND BONDING A .
Bond equipment grounding conductors to ground rods metal equipment enclosures metal poles and ground busses . .
Comply with NEC Article requirements .
B .
Bond neutral conductors to metal equipment enclosures and equipment grounding conductors only at electrical service equipment and at transformer secondary terminals and other separately derived systems . .
Comply with NEC Article requirements .
C. Install concrete encased electrodes where shown and as required by the NEC .
Bond existing concrete encased electrodes such as pole anchor bolts to metal pole or equipment enclosures and equipment grounding conductor . .
Concrete encased electrode consists of Conductive metal in structure foundation encased by at least inches of concrete where foundation is in direct contact with the earth .
Use one of the following conductive metal elements a. AWG bare copper conductor ft minimum length .
b. Bare or zinc galvanized steel reinforcing bars or anchor bolts inch minimum diameter ft total length .
Connect lengths of bar together with steel tie wires to meet total length requirement .
Epoxy coated reinforcing bar may not be used as part of the grounding electrode .
c. No additional conductive metal is required in the concrete foundation where anchor bolts or other conductive metal satisfies requirements above .
D. Install ground rods where shown and as required by the NEC. . Drive ground rods until tops are inches below final grade at services and separately derived systems . .
Install ground rod to extend a minimum of inches and a maximum of inches above box floor in junction boxes. . Space ground rods minimum of feet apart where multiple rods are shown or are required by the NEC . .
Provide inch copper jumper from ground rod to aluminum equipment grounding conductor .
Implementation Electrical Power Page of January .
INSTALL DISCONNECTS PANELBOARDS AND TRANSFORMERS A .
Install equipment level and plumb .
Securely mount equipment to support frames .
B .
Install rain shields and verify drain openings are unblocked .
C. Close and seal any unused openings .
D. Install fuses in fusible devices .
E. Provide and install onetime use locks on all lockable equipment . .
Install State furnished padlocks where provided . .
TESTING A .
After installation but before terminating test each conductor for insulation integrity to adjacent conductors and ground using VDC megohmmeter. . Record insulation resistance in megohms after seconds and seconds R and R. .
Calculate polarization index by dividing the second resistance by the second resistance R R. .
Replace any conductors with a polarization index value less than .. B .
Measure transformer secondary voltage while loaded to final load and record voltage and submit for information .
C. Record insulation test resistance values polarization index and transformer voltage measurements and submit for information .
